story:
Perceptions Theatre started as an idea by its founder and Artistic Director, Myesha-Tiara
McGarner in her undergraduate years in Louisiana, where she received her Bachelor's in Theatre and Directing from Northwestern State University. She noticed the lack of diversity in the theatrical arts and those underserved communities that aren't exposed to those arts as often as they should, be it monetary reasons or lack of diversity, and decided to do something about it. After being a touring and regional theatre  actress for three years she moved to Chicago. the theatre capital of the world, to learn the ropes. Myesha-Tiara worked as a actress her first year learning new skills, then her second year she balanced acting and directing in the Chicagoland area. During this time she met like minded artist that are all currently working in the arts and they worked together to form Perceptions Theatre! 

We are looking to change the way people, perceive the world around them one
show at a time by shining light on underserved communities with theatre that: eliminates
prejudice and discrimination by showing cultures in their natural settings and educating on said
cultures, lessening neighborhood tensions and that defends human and civil rights, to name a few, specifically on the southeast side of Chicago.

As a full service theatre company we plan to help people from the very beginning of their acting career from headshots, to resume help, classes, full productions and more. We chose the southeast side of Chicago because there is so much diversity in this area, we live within this community and see the need for more arts related fields for the residents. Being able to understand what a great impact it has for the community to learn and be entertained from a diverse company that reflects them is priceless. It gives you hope that you can do the exact same things and we want to help you accomplish that!

We also have a very unique casting style: We are a company that believes in the Rodgers & Hammerstein’s “Brandy’s” Cinderella version of casting, meaning that we are hyper vigilant when it comes to the ethnic makeup of our shows. Unless specifically stated from the playwright or if the content of the show itself leans directly toward a specific ethnic group then all parts are open race wise.

Your contributions will help us get through our infancy stage, first year, and beyond by providing:

  • the ability to produce two readings and one full stage production in our 2020 season
  • the ability to pay actors and technical staff
  • material for classes
  • lower rate classes
  • an education department for our younger theatre goers
  • updated technical equipment
  • material for set designs
  • costumes
  • rental space
  • marketing material
  • playbills
  • a permanent residence
  • and so much more! 

We have already officially become a Non-Profit 501 c3 (EIN 84-3272459)  and with your generosity and assistance, you can help us reach our goal of $7,500!

If our goal of $7,500 isn't met we will still use the money that is raised to contribute to making our company a permanent residence on the southeast side of Chicago that educates and entertains its community. We want to be a company that works with our community and contributes to fulfilling the needs of our community.

What You Get

Check out our Perks Section to find out!

Risks & Challenges

As many know a theatre company cost a lot of money to run, however we have been able to cut corners so far with the development of our company by being frugal in our spending. With so many artists in the area we were able to acquire company members and boards members, some who are well versed in the arts and others who run their own successful companies to help guide Perceptions in the right direction. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We also know that sometimes you just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • We ask you to get the word out by sharing our fundraiser link on your social medias and by word of mouth!
  • If you have clothes, props, tools or equipment that you would like to donate instead let us know by emailing: perceptionstheatre@gmail.com

story:
Summary … Slinky the Musical

I am Becky Brabham and I am leading the production team for Slinky the Musical, along with theatrical producer Gary Broughman and my dad, Bob Brabham. My dad and I are both professional musicians and musical arrangers who have enjoyed success nationally in the advertising world writing music sometimes called “jingles.” Gary is a proven producer who recently staged full length plays by renowned playwrights Neil Simon and Stephen Adly Guirgis at the Atlantic Center for the Arts. He specializes in performing arts that “feed the spirit.”

We will bring Slinky the Musical into history with a premiere run of four shows January 13-15, 2017, in Daytona Beach, Florida.

“Back in the day” Bob Brabham shot 90 percent of the Slinky commercials that America saw on television for (Barton and Cureton). Before she passed away, Betty James, the remarkable woman who made Slinky the icon it is today, asked Bob Brabham and advertising executive Tom Cureton, to write a musical based on her story. Bob and Becky collaborated to write the music, Tom Cureton helped write the script, and Bob and Becky brought Gary on board to manage the complexities of production.

The script has been written and refined, the music has been recorded and is stunningly beautiful, the Gillespy Theater at the News-Journal Center in Daytona Beach has been secured, and we are ready to begin auditions.

Slinky has been in space with NASA, is in the Smithsonian and the National Toy Hall of Fame, and has appeared in movies like Ace Ventura. We believe it is headed for Broadway to take its place next to fresh new musicals like Hamilton. We want to make sure it is done right — with professional direction, actors, and a set worthy of a toy that has sold 250 million copies worldwide. That is why we are asking you to join us in “taking it to the max!”

We have compiled a budget of $16,023 which includes $5,323 for the venue, $2,500 for personnel (production team), $1,200 for set and costumes, $400 for insurance, $2,000 for talent (i.e., actors and singers), $2,000 for advertising, $300 for printing, $1,000 for rehearsal space, $300 for musical development, $500 for  transportation. $500 for miscellaneous

How We Show Our Appreciation

We want contributors to know they are truly part of Slinky the Musical, which is why we offer the following to show our appreciation for your contribution:

$20 … Choose a commemorative Slinky toy or unique Slinky the Musical Tee Shirt sent to your home.

$40 … A commemorative Slinky toy and a unique Slinky the Musical Tee Shirt sent to your home.

$100 … Two tickets to your choice of shows during the premiere run of Slinky the Musical, January 13-15, 2017, in Daytona Beach Florida.

$200 … Two tickets with VIP seating to your choice of shows during the premiere run of Slinky the Musical, January 13-15 2017, in Daytona Beach Florida, plus listing in the playbill as a Gold Sponsor that brought Slinky the Musical to life.

$500 … Two tickets with VIP seating to your choice of shows during the premiere run of Slinky the Musical, January 13-15 in Daytona Beach Florida, one free night in the host hotel on the ocean in Daytona Beach, plus listing in the playbill as a Gold Sponsor that Brought Slinky the Musical to life.

If we do not reach our full fundraising goal, we will produce Slinky the Musical anyway and will stage a beautiful show. All “perks” described above will be honored. Our budget of $16,023 is designed to allow us to work at the highest level, but like many families we are skilled at “stretching” when necessary.

Impact

We believe America needs an inspiring story like Slinky the Musical right now—a true story of a working class family that caught a break and ran with it, and a woman who defied the odds when the going got tough and reached the pinnacle. This is a true story, not a manufactured fable. A popular song once said “what the world needs now is love …” That is still true, and more than ever it also needs beauty. Slinky the Musical is beautiful through and through.

The people behind this project have made wonderful entertainment happen in the past are dedicated making this their career achievement.

Risks and Challenges

Producing theater is a labor of the heart. Everyone knows it carries risks and is not a surefire investment (if there is such a thing!). But when skilled, talented, and experienced people combine with artful material, the opportunity to produce something grand is like nothing else in this world. The feeling such success brings has to be something like what Betty James felt when Slinky finally went viral!

Please, if you are inspired by Slinky the Musical, use Indiegogo’s Share tools to let others know!

story:
Hello! My name is Justin Maurer and I want to invite you to join us in mounting our debut production of Falling on Deaf Eyes, an autobiographical play we've written about my family and a very pivotal and formative period in my early life.

I am a CODA (Child of a Deaf Adult) and my first language was American Sign Language. Very recently I had the exhilarating honor of being the primary ASL Interpreter for the duration of the LA Teacher’s Strike, during which I had the pleasure of making many new friends and acquaintances.  This included meeting Jevon Whetter, a striking Deaf teacher who is now the director and co-author of this play!

We are very excited to be launching our Los Angeles theatrical debut with our play Falling on Deaf Eyes as part of this summer’s Hollywood Fringe Festival!

When my parents divorced in 1992, my Deaf mother, Sherry, suddenly found herself overcoming extraordinary personal challenges as a newly-single parent raising a family of three hearing youngsters in a small provincial town. Each of us - my mom, my sister Jenny, my younger brother Jamie, and I – were forced to find ways to cope with new circumstances in unfamiliar surroundings. 

This is our story.

Sometimes harrowing, often funny, but always compassionate in its depiction of a family in transition, Falling on Deaf Eyes is a unique, one-of-a-kind show and an inspirational and universal portrayal of human courage and survival.

Falling on Deaf Eyes is an exciting multi-media theatrical experience incorporating music, sign language, storytelling, and theatrical visuals, with at least 4  out of 7 shows with American Sign Language interpreters to ensure access to the deaf and hard of hearing. While hugely entertaining and accessible to families, music fans, the literary community, and beyond, Falling on Deaf Eyes will also educate and inform the general public about American Sign Language and some of the daily issues facing the deaf and hard of hearing community.

With the talent we've assembled, Falling on Deaf Eyes promises to be a remarkable and timely production. Now we need additional funding to make it happen!

As I mentioned earlier, the play will be part of this year's  Hollywood Fringe Festival, and we’ll be doing seven performances. Our projected budget includes our venue rental, compensation for our technical and production staff (stage manager, technicians, musicians, actors, ASL interpreters), promotional and PR materials, and more. We're looking to raise $10K and our deadline is Wed. May 1st. Anything you can contribute would be greatly appreciated. We need to make this happen!

All contributors to the campaign will be thanked in our program. The first 60 contributors in the Los Angeles area who donate $50 or more will be invited for a Private Preview of the play along with an after-show party with complimentary refreshments, beverages, and a meet-and-greet with the actors and production staff. (For anyone wishing to donate at a higher level, we have additional opportunities available as well.)

Thank you in advance for helping make Falling on Deaf Eyes the resounding success we know it will be!!

~Justin Maurer and the Falling on Deaf Eyes Production Team

We’ve assembled an amazing team: 

Justin Maurer (Writer/Producer/Actor) is a writer, musician, ASL Interpreter and LA native. He is a CODA (Child of a Deaf Adult), and his first language was American Sign Language. He most recently rose to local prominence ASL Interpreting for the L.A. Teacher’s Strike. He has toured the world and released records with his punk bands CLOROX GIRLS, MANIAC and SUSPECT PARTS. He has worked as a traveling dental supply salesman, Hollywood tour bus driver, and as a graveyard shift delivery boy for Crispy Pork Gang restaurant in Thai Town.

Jevon Whetter (Director/Co-Writer) is a deaf educator, producer, writer, and director who lives and works in Los Angeles. Mr. Whetter earned his MA degree in Theatre Arts from San Diego State University, earned an MFA degree from the American Film Institute Conservatory, and is currently a professor at California State University, Northridge. Jevon’s professional stage experience includes performing with the National Theater of the Deaf on its Ophelia tour and appearances in Aladdin, A Christmas Carol, and Road to Revolution at Deaf West Theatre. In 2006, Mr. Whetter made his professional debut as a director at the Deaf West Theatre, and has since worked on over fifteen films and has written and directed numerous productions for the stage.

Lisa Hermatz (Actor) a member of the American Sign Language Teachers Association, has taught college-level ASL for 19 years. She currently teaches at Pierce and Glendale Community Colleges. Lisa has also translated ASL for several projects, including Dawn Sign Press’ Once Upon a Sign video-series and Deaf West Theatre (DWT), where she also has done thespian work. She earned an L.A. Ovation Award nod for her translation work on DWT’s first-ever musical, “Oliver!”

Jann Goldsby (Voice Actor) has been an actor and an ASL interpreter for many years and is STILL learning. She is also a proud member of SAG-AFTRA, which came in handy when performing the role of “the interpreter” on THISCLOSE ‘s 2nd season with the lovely Shoshannah Stern. She can also be seen in the delightful film, You & Me written by Hilary and Alexander Baack.

Delbert Whetter (Producer) JD, MBA, served as the lead Business Affairs executive for numerous entertainment and digital content providers for nearly two decades. Delbert has worked on Exodus Film Group animated features, “IGOR”, “The Hero of Color City”, and “Bunyan & Babe”, receiving Co-Executive Producer credit on Exodus’ two recent films. Delbert serves on the Board of Directors of RespectAbility, a national non-profit organization that works with Hollywood to promote positive, accurate, diverse and inclusive media portrayals of persons with disabilities on TV and in film. He has also been appointed by the City of Santa Monica to serve a four-year term as Commissioner on its Disabilities Commission.

STACEY (Original score) this Toronto singer-songwriter is a romantic for the apocalypse generation. Her sophomore EP First Move allows a rare glimpse into the dark, solitary lucid daydreams of a Lynchian heroine. STACEY’s works have received glowing press, while her soul-stirring, captivating live presence has led her to share stages with the likes of Charlotte Day Wilson and Cameron Avery (of Tame Impala). Her songs have been featured on over fifteen television shows including Lucifer, Orphan Black, and Degrassi. Since fall 2017, STACEY’s First Move EP has amassed over 750K streams on Spotify. Surrounding the buzz of her sold out Toronto release show, STACEY played multiple Canadian national TV shows, international showcases in New York and LA, and two back-to-back sold out sets at Toronto’s Royal Ontario Museum for the Christian Dior: 70th Anniversary Exhibit.

Vanessa Gonzalez (costume designer) Since 2010, Vanessa Gonzalez has been designing and constructing costumes for film, commercials, and music videos for clients including Funny or Die, The Syfy Network, and Sawhorse.

Tim Maurer (Video Designer) Cousin. Recovering Rude Boy. Image Magician. Undeniably “Maurer.” Banged Grandpa’s drums and broke antique guitar strings with Justin, the toe-headed shadow who remains his partner in crime to this day. He dabbled in video-music-sketchcomedy and finds joy in connecting the beat and finding the visual rhythm.

Andrew Leyva (ASL Interpreter) Andrew S. Leyva is a nationally certified interpreter with 20 years of experience in the performance arts. He has worked rehearsals and talkbacks on Deaf West Theatre’s Children of a Lesser God, Pinocchio, and Spring Awakening, and Fountain Theatre’s Arrival and Departure. His theatrical interpreting training includes the Juilliard School / Theatre Development Fund Interpreting for Theatre being chosen to interpret Thoroughly Modern Millie with the instructors at the Marquis Theatre, NYC. Most recently he has interpreted A Streetcar Named Desire, Signin’ in the Rain, Legally Blonde, Newsies, Shakespeare’s Midsummer Night’s Dream, and has consulted theatrical interpreters on When At Last We Arrive, Night Light, and Little Shop of Horrors. Presently employed as an interpreter and mentor at the National Center On Deafness and the Deaf Studies Dept at CSU, Northridge where in collaboration with the Theatre Dept he passes on what he has learned to interpreting students and working interpreters. He also has taught a Performing Arts Interpreting class at College of Southern Nevada.

Follow us on
FB: www.facebook.com/fallingondeafeyes
IG: @fallingondeaf
IG: @maurerjustin
Twitter: @justinmaurer17

He has worked rehearsals and talkbacks on Deaf West Theatre’s Children of a Lesser God, Pinocchio, and Spring Awakening, and Fountain Theatre’s Arrival and Departure. His theatrical interpreting training includes the Juilliard School / Theatre Development Fund Interpreting for Theatre being chosen to interpret Thoroughly Modern Millie with the instructors at the Marquis Theatre, NYC. Most recently he has interpreted A Streetcar Named Desire, Signin’ in the Rain, Legally Blonde, Newsies, Shakespeare’s Midsummer Night’s Dream, and has consulted theatrical interpreters on When At Last We Arrive, Night Light, and Little Shop of Horrors. Presently employed as an interpreter and mentor at the National Center On Deafness and the Deaf Studies Dept at CSU, Northridge where in collaboration with the Theatre Dept he passes on what he has learned to interpreting students and working interpreters. He also has taught a Performing Arts Interpreting class at College of Southern Nevada.Follow us onFB: www.facebook.com/fallingondeafeyesIG: @fallingondeafIG: @maurerjustinTwitter: @justinmaurer17

story:
The 'Aiea Asian-American Amateur Acting Association or AAA-AAA will be devising a show based on the history of comedy in Hawai'i. Led by Suzen Murakoshi, MFA, with mentoring by Aitor Basauri of SpyMonkey, UK, "The Things dat Makes You Laugh" will explore the different Hawaii-centric comedians, funny songs and cultural contexts within the world of comedy (Commedia del Arte, Shakespeare, Clowning).
The funds will be used for devising "The Stuff dat Makes You Laugh" with Aitor Basauri, actors from Hawai'i . The support will allow contributors to be invited to watch the creative process from workshop to performance. The AAA-AAA's goal is for a 2018 premiere of "The Stuff dat Makes You Laugh" at the ARTS at Marks Garage and the FRIGID Festival in NYC in February, 2019. The AAA-AAA will be most grateful for any support of this show for the community of Honolulu, the State of Hawai'i, as well as to share the unique culture of the Islands globally.

story:
Who am I? 

My name is Camille Thomas. I am a multidisciplinary actor, writer, and creative. My work takes an intersectional look at what it means to be a Black, half first-gen, Jamaican woman in America. I graduated from Michigan State University in 2019, double majoring in Arts and Humanities and Acting. It was during my tenure at school that I discovered my passion for social justice. Unfortunately, while I was finding what I wanted to do with the rest of my life, I also learned how EXPENSIVE higher learning is. After five years of college, I became disillusioned with education and the debt I was accruing. Therefore, I did what any disgruntled artist does, and I created art! 

The Show

“yOU CaN TAke ouT a PArEnT pLUs lOaN”, a one woman show that draws its specific font size from the mocking Spongebob meme, follows Camille Thomas as she navigates a predominantly white institution in pursuit of an undergraduate degree through rising tuition costs, familial expectations, and her own personal aspirations. This show merges monologues, slam poetry, projections and character defining moments from her past to analyze the racket that is student debt and how it affects students of color.

So far this show has been workshopped at Sacred Circle Theatre Company in New York, with Blackboard Playreading series in New York via Zoom, and most recently with The Women's Theatre Festival in North Carolina via Zoom where it won the jury selection for outstanding performance. Now my team and I are taking are show to the next level and this is where YOU come in.

Check out our review!

https://chathamlifeandstyle.com/features-%26-re...

What's Next?

We are collaborating with the Women's Theatre Festival to produce another, more advanced edition of my show. Initially, a team of two (me and my director Molly Bennett) created the show. We did not have a Sound or Graphic Designer, a Stage Manager, or any other essential theatre production personnel. These roles are even more critical now that theatre has gone virtual.  We need your help fundraising $2,500 to continue to grow our show and take it to the next level.

The end goal is to have a fully fleshed-out production. That way, we can eventually tour –virtually and in-person someday- to high schools and colleges across the United States and educate students, especially BIPOC scholars, about higher education costs and navigating as a student today.

story:
INTRODUCING THE DIME CIRCUS!

THE SLAUGHTER BROTHERS DIME CIRCUS is a dark clown play that jacknives into a fantasy horror of transformation, revenge, fate, and parasitical insects preying on the guilty.                  Buster Keaton meets Guillermo del Toro!

THE SLAUGHTER BROTHERS DIME CIRCUS. Words and music by Sean Sullivan, critically-acclaimed theatre performer/creator, who has been called ‘a virtual Nijinsky of performance art’ by the New York Times, and whose work has been called ‘hilariously funny, demented, even dangerous and always kinetic’ by the Toronto Sun

This is our second and final campaign. The first was to make our pre-production workshop a reality, and thanks to donors like you, we did it! This time, we are asking you to help push us over the top to achieve our ultimate goal: a full production in the Spring of 2020!

With your help, and only with your help, we can make this one-of-a-kind theatrical adventure         into a reality.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our goal is now $7000. We have received a significant grant amount from the Canada Council for the Arts that gets us close, but not quite there. This campaign aims to take us across the finish line.
  • What happens if we come up short in our campaign? Don't worry. With what we do earn, we'll still produce the show! The difference will not affect the quality of our work because we are 100% committed to this play, but our production elements, (set, lighting, costumes, etc), and company salaries will be noticeably cut back. Other Ways You Can Help

The Impact

When a play makes you laugh AND cringe AND think about something important, it is pretty special. That's what THE SLAUGHTER BROTHERS DIME CIRCUS is going to be, if only we can raise the money to bring it to life.

In our previous company Baby Monster Productions, we were able to produce two highly successful productions under the heading of 'Avante-Vaudeville.' Both shows toured Central Europe as well as New York, (multiple times), Toronto, and Los Angeles. Both were critical and popular successes. Both won lots of awards. We know what works in our little corner of the theatrical world. And what we have now is something we know will be entertaining and thought-provoking... if we raise the money to produce it.

Risks & Challenges

Anytime you bring a new creation into the world there are hurdles to overcome. There are so many productions at any one time in a major city like Toronto that the odds are stacked against any play without a track record. We know this, we know that nothing is a sure thing.

But we have had the experience of dealing with these issues many times before and we know a thing or two about standing out. THE SLAUGHTER BROTHERS DIME CIRCUS will benefit from that experience. From painstaking attention to detail in our script, to instinct honed over many years as to what makes a play thrilling, to marketing techniques such as flash performances on city streets and public parks, we will spare no effort in giving our production the best chance to thrive in both an artistic and popular way.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that, even if you love the idea of our show, you might not be able to help us with a financial pledge. If that is the case, don't worry! There are other ways to help us!

Ask your colleagues and comrades to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it!

story:
Who We Are & What We're Doing

Futile Gestures is a movement collective co-founded by Dot Armstrong, Kyra Smith, Lea Torelli, and Liana Kleinman. Through offbeat, playful, and unexpected performances, we explore the nuances of human connection through immersive and site-specific works. 

We’re putting our thoughts, feelings, and physical experiments under one roof for our first self- produced evening-length show. We are exploring tenderness and defiance, with variations on the theme of care. The space we inhabit will be just as much a collaborator as the other artists we bring on board. We are excited to see what directions our research leads us and we hope you can join us for the ride! Your contribution tells us you believe in our big dreams. Your contribution is a tangible expression of care.

 

What We Need & How You Can Help

We are in the process of creating an evening of movement-based work, premiering in May 2020. It is our biggest undertaking thus far and we’re ready to make the leap. But we need your help to stick the landing! To realize our wildest dreams AND pay all of our collaborators, we need you to join the team.  

The $5,000 will cover costs for creative efforts both large and small. Our biggest expenses will be space rental and collaborator compensation.  We are adamant about paying our contributing artists a rate that reflects all the hard work and love they are pouring into this production. The rest of the funds will go towards purchasing props, costumes, sets, and anything else that enlivens our work. We’re offering lots of fun incentives, based on different levels of donations, to fuel your generosity. No matter how much you give, you'll get the satisfaction of contributing to a female-run arts organization--what could be better than that?! So put that pocket change to good use. 

 

Thank You!

From a social media shout-out to your entire life savings, every contribution helps. It makes us feel like a million bucks to know our community supports the work we’re making. Tell your best friend, your mom, your dog, your Lyft driver, your second cousin twice removed, your weird aunt in Kansas, your upstairs neighbor who practices tap dancing at 2am… we want all of you to come with us on this adventure!

From the bottom of our collective heart, we thank you and we love you! 

XOXO

---Futile Gestures

story:
Overview

 

At this hour

lie at my mercy mine enemy...

"The Reckoning" is a one hour theatrical and optional behind-the-scenes experience being offered by The Trick 'R Treaters this summer.  Enter the dark recesses of a barber's mind as he plots revenge on the man who took everything he ever loved.  Join Kilburn as he explores the depths of his insanity...

 

Who Are We?

 

We are The Trick 'R Treaters, the premier performing arts company of York, Pennsylvania.  We formed out of a desire to bring something new and totally unique to the community.  Our mission is to create high quality entertainment experiences that inspire and spark creativity in those around us while creating a way for local artists to form a livelihood from their skills in the arts.  We do not believe that one should have to live in an overcrowded and overpriced area like New York City or Los Angeles in order to "make it" as an artist.  We also feel that one should not have to be part of a union in order to obtain respect and a decent wage.  We create a campaign for each theatrical production that we produce as one of several ways to offer you, our supporters, a chance to be actively involved in creating this masterpiece with us.  It literally takes a community of people to put on a production of any size.  Our last production, The Ledge, surpassed our financial goal thanks to 3 amazing local businesses and 14 generous individuals from across the globe.  Our financial goal for this production is quite a bit higher.  We are confident that you, our theatre family, will help us achieve our new goal so that we can bring you our next piece of living art.

 

What We Need To Succeed:

 

This production will cost us approximately $5,600.00.  This money will cover...

  • $1,750 in base salaries for the artists (both cast and crew) involved in this production.  This is very conservative for the 6 months of hard work that they have each put into making this a stellar show.
  • $100 for costs associated with creating programs for each audience member.
  • $850 for costuming and makeup for each performer.
  • $875 for set pieces and props.
  • $1,500 for the rehearsal/performance space.  The space actually costs way more than this, but our host, Alba Rosa Cat Parlour, is choosing to give us a huge break on space rental.
  • $525 in processing fees.

Individuals who contribute to this production will be listed in the show program as a sponsor of this project.  Local contributors will be invited to a special preview showing where you get a behind-the-scenes experience and get to see the show before the general public.  For our supporters who are not local, you will have access to a private online performance of the show so that you don't miss all the action.  This is a flexible campaign because every penny helps.  If we go over our goal, any extra money will go towards our overhead costs to run The Trick 'R Treaters.

 

The Impact Of This Production On Our Community

 

The arts give us a safe space to explore the deepest and darkest parts of the human experience.  Every person who takes part in one of our productions has an opportunity to push their boundaries as an artist, learning lots of new things about their personal craft along the way.  In this production, we get to explore the depths of how grief can change one's perception and sense of morality.  We hope to entertain you while teaching the very dark lesson of what can happen when a good person is wronged, leading to irreversible trauma.  Revenge crosses a very blurry line between what is moral and what is not, and what true justice means.  It will be interesting to see if audience members think Kilburn is justified in his actions.  After all, how far would you go if someone took everything you held dear?  In a modern world where chaos and violence are becoming more and more common and the law is hardly just, how far would you go to serve true justice for those you love?

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

We totally understand that not all of you are in a position to financially contribute to this particular production.  But don't worry, you can help us too!  Simply share our campaign all over your social media accounts.  Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, whatever you got!  Just remember to tell your friends and fans why our mission is important to you so they understand why they should care too.  You know a lot of people that we don't, so we're counting on all of you to help us reach them.

If you own a business or know of a business that would love to reach a whole new audience, consider purchasing an ad in our program for this show.  We have 3 half page ads and 2 full page ads currently available, and all money goes to support this production.  Anyone interested in claiming an ad should email us at albarosacats@gmail.com and put "The Reckoning Ad" in the subject line for more information.

story:
Who are you?

I'm Willy. I'm from Exeter. I like Beyoncé, knitting, and making theatre.

 

 

If Beyoncé ever made theatre shows I'd like to think they'd look a little like mine. I've just finished training at the Oxford School of Drama and am an Associate Artist of the Exeter Phoenix. I like untangling social hangups through fusing theatrical forms, honest and funny storytelling, and cracking soundtracks.

 

Who's that?

That's Rachel Lemon. The director. We started collaborating when I had the idea for this show. I showed her a ten minute monologue in a pub basement. She thought it 'had potential'....thanks Rach. 

Rachel trained as an actor at Rose Bruford. Since graduating Rachel has created her own shows as well as assisting directors at venues such as The Other Room and The Young Vic. 

What's Bottom? Will I see yer bum? Can my nan come?

Bottom is about bums, Beyoncé and burnt fish fingers. It's a queer coming of age remix. 

A couple of years ago I started getting anxious about the top/bottom position in queer sex. I tried to top for the first time, I couldn't do it and developed erectile dysfunction. I couldn't see my story anywhere, didn't know how to talk about it, and felt like this was only happening to me. So I decided to write a show about it.

It's FUNNY though, I promise. 

This show puts the queer experience centre stage, through storytelling, song, and dancing to Beyoncé. The story unfolds during a disastrous third date, in a world of zero-hour contracts, online dating and late-night clubbing. Bottom confronts attitudes towards masculinity, femininity and confidence in modern queer culture. 

You MIGHT see my bottom.

and YES. bring your nan. 

 

 

Why do you need my CASH?

If I saw this show a few years ago it would have made things a lot easier for me - to help understand, find myself, and move forwards within queer culture. I believe this show can do that for people, whilst bringing awareness to queer issues and problems that aren't widely discussed. (In an entertaining way though, promise)

I'm taking it to the Edinburgh Festival, the biggest arts festival in the world. Performing it for the whole month of August, 2018.

Which is great, but, I need money to make it all happen and get this story told.

Edinburgh is quiiite expensive.

Things I need to pay for:

Venue
Bottom is programmed at Summerhall, one of the top, exciting venues at the fringe. But with a top, exciting venue comes a top, exciting price tag -  £2800 for the months run. 

Marketing/Print
I've got 100 seats to fill everyday day for 23 days. We need to get as many people as possible to know about Bottom. So that's loads of flyers and posters. And all the other marketing stuff. I'm going to print some fabulous pink tshirts to wear as we hand out our fabulous pink flyers, so you can't miss us. 

Design/Tech/Costume/Set

I want Bottom to look and sound good. And professional. We have an amazing lighting designer on board, and a fab sound designer creating Beyoncé inspired sounds. They need to be paid. Then there is costume, set and props - for these we are keeping costs as low as possible without compromising on the quality of the show. 

Accomodation/Travel

Yup. Getting to and staying up in Edinburgh is another wad of cash. 

Previews

We've got 3 previews in Exeter, Bristol and London in late July. We need to cover the production costs for these.

 

What have you got so far?

We've estimated and budgeted total costs to hit the £9000 mark.

At the moment we've raised £3000 through fundraising and artist support programs. I've got £1200 saved from working my day jobs and will be adding that to the pot. We're expecting to get another £2300 through further fundraising activities, pending applications and knocking on doors (not literally...although maybe). Which will take it up to £6500.

So if we can raise £2500 from gorgeous humans like you we will hit our target and be able to make Bottom happen. We can't do it without your help!

If you are still reading THANK YOU <3 you dream. Any support you can give is going to be a massive help. If you don't have any coins to spare please do share, like, or just stand on a stool in a pub to shout and spread the word. 

Huge cheers and thank yous to Exeter Phoenix, Arts Council, Bristol Old Vic Ferment and Bryony Kimmings for the ongoing support.  And the recently closed Bike Shed Theatre (miss you bad). And anyone that has helped the project so far in some way - reading scripts, taking photos,  watching scratches, carrying mannequin legs around,  helping decide what shade of pink is more 'me'-  there have been LOADS of you and I am so so grateful you have no idea.  

Love,
Willy X
story_txt: Who are you?I'm Willy. I'm from Exeter. I like Beyoncé, knitting, and making theatre.  If Beyoncé ever made theatre shows I'd like to think they'd look a little like mine. I've just finished training at the Oxford School of Drama and am an Associate Artist of the Exeter Phoenix. I like untangling social hangups through fusing theatrical forms, honest and funny storytelling, and cracking soundtracks. Who's that?That's Rachel Lemon. The director. We started collaborating when I had the idea for this show. I showed her a ten minute monologue in a pub basement. She thought it 'had potential'....thanks Rach. Rachel trained as an actor at Rose Bruford. Since graduating Rachel has created her own shows as well as assisting directors at venues such as The Other Room and The Young Vic. What's Bottom? Will I see yer bum? Can my nan come?Bottom is about bums, Beyoncé and burnt fish fingers. It's a queer coming of age remix. A couple of years ago I started getting anxious about the top/bottom position in queer sex. I tried to top for the first time, I couldn't do it and developed erectile dysfunction. I couldn't see my story anywhere, didn't know how to talk about it, and felt like this was only happening to me. So I decided to write a show about it.It's FUNNY though, I promise. This show puts the queer experience centre stage, through storytelling, song, and dancing to Beyoncé. The story unfolds during a disastrous third date, in a world of zero-hour contracts, online dating and late-night clubbing. Bottom confronts attitudes towards masculinity, femininity and confidence in modern queer culture. You MIGHT see my bottom.and YES. bring your nan.   Why do you need my CASH?If I saw this show a few years ago it would have made things a lot easier for me - to help understand, find myself, and move forwards within queer culture. I believe this show can do that for people, whilst bringing awareness to queer issues and problems that aren't widely discussed. (In an entertaining way though, promise)I'm taking it to the Edinburgh Festival, the biggest arts festival in the world. Performing it for the whole month of August, 2018.Which is great, but, I need money to make it all happen and get this story told.Edinburgh is quiiite expensive.Things I need to pay for:VenueBottom is programmed at Summerhall, one of the top, exciting venues at the fringe. But with a top, exciting venue comes a top, exciting price tag -  £2800 for the months run. Marketing/PrintI've got 100 seats to fill everyday day for 23 days. We need to get as many people as possible to know about Bottom. So that's loads of flyers and posters. And all the other marketing stuff. I'm going to print some fabulous pink tshirts to wear as we hand out our fabulous pink flyers, so you can't miss us. Design/Tech/Costume/SetI want Bottom to look and sound good. And professional. We have an amazing lighting designer on board, and a fab sound designer creating Beyoncé inspired sounds. They need to be paid. Then there is costume, set and props - for these we are keeping costs as low as possible without compromising on the quality of the show. Accomodation/TravelYup. Getting to and staying up in Edinburgh is another wad of cash. PreviewsWe've got 3 previews in Exeter, Bristol and London in late July. We need to cover the production costs for these. What have you got so far?We've estimated and budgeted total costs to hit the £9000 mark.At the moment we've raised £3000 through fundraising and artist support programs. I've got £1200 saved from working my day jobs and will be adding that to the pot. We're expecting to get another £2300 through further fundraising activities, pending applications and knocking on doors (not literally...although maybe). Which will take it up to £6500.So if we can raise £2500 from gorgeous humans like you we will hit our target and be able to make Bottom happen. We can't do it without your help!If you are still reading THANK YOU <3 you dream. Any support you can give is going to be a massive help. If you don't have any coins to spare please do share, like, or just stand on a stool in a pub to shout and spread the word. Huge cheers and thank yous to Exeter Phoenix, Arts Council, Bristol Old Vic Ferment and Bryony Kimmings for the ongoing support.  And the recently closed Bike Shed Theatre (miss you bad). And anyone that has helped the project so far in some way - reading scripts, taking photos,  watching scratches, carrying mannequin legs around,  helping decide what shade of pink is more 'me'-  there have been LOADS of you and I am so so grateful you have no idea.  Love,Willy X

story:
Few words on why directing The White plague and why your HELP will matter

After not being able to understood the madness called war, as well as spending money for weapons production, I Gorjan Arevski, as theater director for my graduation play decided to work The White plague, which, although written before the Second World War, is too accurate and absolutely critical of the modern world. As an individual, I realized that in real life, it is dangerous if I am struggling to transfer Capek's request (through Dr. Galen) - ABSOLUTE PEACE, but because in theater fighting can be done on beautiful way, because the art is more organized than life, and as such there is an opportunity to criticize the chaos we live in.

If you are also passionate about peace, I hope you will help me by donation or by sharing this campaign with people that will be willing to support this theater process. 

The team of my Graduation play is consisted of more than 40 people who share the same values and are ready to work hard and devoted through the process of this first production of Karel Capek's THE WHITE PLAGUE being staged in Macedonia ( and we hope later on it will travel to many countries as well)

Theater with an attitude 

Every day it's harder and harder to create  an engaged theater when what the market can sell are comedies that make people laugh. The world has never been in a more complex situation - so many fronts and so many wars, and the population that has the opportunity to make changes – measures it values through the number of likes and clicks.


They say to the young world remains, but after all it does not seem that there is much left?!


We want a world and a theater in which we can freely ask questions, but also actively work in creating better conditions. For all of us. Art has the power to make changes. But only if it is sincere and committed.

The whole team involved in this play does not base their engagement on material gain. In the funds planned for setting the performance, the costs are provided for the needs of scenery and costume design. Our  biggest desire is to stage it as many places as possible, and therefore the remaining money are planned for travel costs.


Setting this text on Capek is not a coincidence. This team tried to get the support of cultural institutions in Macedonia, but for the play that promotes peace, education and humanity, all doors were closed.


We get knocked down, to get back up.
And this is the time to do it we need your help.
 

Brief budget explanation 

- Actors and director work without honorarium 
- Costumes for 16 actors will cost 1300 euros
- Scenography 1200 euros
- Marketing 500 euros
- Traveling fund 2000 euros 
Total 5000 euros

The scenography and costumes which will later on be donated to the Faculty of Dramatic Arts in Skopje where most of the students who are part of the team were/are studying. This equipment will be of a great use for the future theater plays they and their future colleagues will perform.

About the Faculty of Dramatic Arts


The director Gorjan Arevski is a graduate student at the Faculty of Dramatic Arts in Skopje, in the class of professor Zlatko Slavenski and assistant Kushtrim Bekteski. Up to now, during his studies, he has worked on the following dramatic texts:„Pečalbari“ (A. Panov), „All my sons“ (A. Miller), „The Seagull“ (A.P. Chekhov) and the „Enemy of the state“ (H. Ibsen).


Gorjan prefers socially engaged plays, which speak locally, and act globally.


Most of the actors will be students at the Faculty of Dramatic Arts, as well as some already completed (employed and unemployed actors).


The rest of the collaborators will also be young, mainly students who deal with their concerns of interest, such as music, production, architecture, costume design, film directing, etc.

story:
About us

Dance, intentional movement through space, shares with giving-care-to-an-elder, the need to deal with the ubiquitous presence of gravity and the passage of rhythmic time. Choreographed performance dance expresses feeling and tells a story to viewers. Perhaps dance is a mode to express the caregiving experience when written and spoken words fail. Join us in our exploration of reflecting individual experience and expressing the caregiving journey through dance. 

The CareGivers' Project is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization with a vision of effecting a cultural change in the way giving care to elders is felt and perceived.

 

Your donation

While the dancers are helping us realizing In Time & Space without compensation, we need to pay our choreographer, Teresa Perez-Ceccon and documentary videographer-photographer, Mickey Hoelscher.

We are creating a documentary of this process which includes interviews with the dancers and talk-backs with audiences.

Your donation will also cover the cost of rented rehearsal space, costumes, publicity, and social events that bring forth discussion about dance and caregiving with you

And the curtain won't come down yet, if we raise funds  beyond our goal, we plan to recruit more dancers for additional caregiving story solos. And why not plan a multi-generaltional group dance work?

Your donation is charity tax deducible minus the value of the perks of class with Teresa Perez-Ceccon.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't give, you can always show up for performances and conversations on giving care to elders and share. 

Use the Indiegogo share tools

Follow The CareGivers' Project on Facebook facebook.com/CareGiversProject

Follow The CareGivers' Project on Twitter twitter.com/ShareReflect

story:
Who We Are

A Dead Whale Productions is a theatre collective based in Chicago that creates bold and innovative works that challenge traditional theatrical convention through rigorous collaborative ingenuity.

Joining A Dead Whale as our sponsor and co-producer is Obie-winning director and co-founder of The New York International Fringe Festival John Clancy and his new artistic consultancy firm Little Pharaoh Enterprises based in Mt. Carmel, IL.

 

What We’re Doing

This past season, audiences fell in love with Bouff'honestly Though! A live bouffon talk show starring Slather & Gibbs at Nox Arca Theatre in Chicago. Described by audiences as "unlike anything I've ever seen," the show parodies the late-night talk show genre while examining our media-obsessed savior culture. Bouff'honestly Though! is such a ridiculous good time that we knew this show needed to continue. That's when we began hatching a plan with Obie-winner John Clancy and his new artistic consultancy firm, Little Pharaoh Enterprises, to take Bouff'honestly Though! outside of the Windy City...

...and we need your help to make it happen.

This opportunity to collaborate with Little Pharaoh Enterprises and share our work with Mt. Carmel audiences will help us develop Bouff’honestly Though! into the touring production it craves to be. With your help, Bouff'honestly Though! will spread from Mt. Carmel to Philadelphia’s FringeArts Festival, FringeNYC, Scotland’s Edinburgh Fringe, and beyond.

Take the plunge: help us take this first step to present Slather and Gibbs to audiences around the world.

How You Can Help

In order to make this tour possible, we need to raise $2000.

Every donation made to this campaign will go towards travel expenses, advertising and marketing, renting rehearsal space, and paying our dedicated artists.

Donations of all sizes offer an exciting array of perks, including: credit in our program, video shout outs from Slather & Gibbs, Bouff’honestly Though! mugs, adorable A Dead Whale plushies, original artwork, and tickets to A Dead Whale’s next season.

Spread The Word

Some people just can't contribute monetarily, and that’s okay. If you still want to help us out, please share our campaign on Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, through the mail - wherever! The more folx who see this campaign, the more chances we have of reaching our goal.

To learn more about A Dead Whale Productions, visit www.adeadwhaleproductions.com.

Like us on facebook at www.facebook.com/adeadwhaleproductions.

Follow us on Instagram at @adeadwhale.

story:
Summary

When Colleen Snell and Noelle Hamlyn were 3 and 5 years old, they created a performance in their backyard with cast of frogs performing tricks. From this whimsical debut springs the name "Frog in Hand," and our belief that art can happen anywhere. Frog in Hand has evolved into a collective of professional artists who create and perform in unusual spaces. We incorporated as a not-for-profit in 2016. We provide paid opportunities for dance artists to nurture a sustainable, meaningful artistic practise. Our artistic genre is contemporary dance.

While we have been working as a collective for years, we have never self-produced a performance, or participated in the Toronto Fringe. We need your help to do both. Frog in Hand is creating an evening-length work for 16 dancers, called "The Fall." This work will explore the battle to stay upright, the influence of gravity, exhaustion and control. "The Fall" will use large high jump mats ten inches thick, onto which the dancers will land and fall. These will also be our set. "The Fall" will be presented in the site-specific category of the Toronto Fringe; it will be performed 8 times over the course of two weeks. 

While there will be box office revenue from our performances, Fringe tickets are only $11, meaning our income will not cover all of the costs of this production. We are asking for your help to cover the cost of the production. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising funds to cover honoraria for our dancers. We are also looking to cover standard production costs such as rehearsal and performance space, publicity expenses, costumes and the Fringe entry fee. We are hoping to raise $4000 - any and all support will make a difference.

We have a number of unique perks to thank you for your contribution!

$500 An hour-long dance party for you and ten friends, led by Colleen Snell 
$200 Invitation to a pre-show chat in the performance space, two tickets to the show 
$150 A unique purse created by Noelle Hamlyn, made from a vintage book
$100 An invitation to a closed rehearsal 
$50 A signed cast poster 
$25 A shout-out on social media and a personal thank you card
$10 A shout-out on social media

Impact

We know this opportunity to present "The Fall" at the Fringe will develop our site-specific skills, challenge us to make new discoveries, build our creative ability, contribute to place-making, amplify our social location and empower our voices. We know "The Fall" work will reach a wide spectrum of folks at the Fringe, including those who have never experienced contemporary dance. "The Fall" will develop Frog in Hand, building our strong history of producing unique dance works that genuinely support the artists involved.

Yet there is more, as this production is also an opportunity to bring together 8 professional dancers with 8 emerging artists. The emerging artists are all students returning to school. This is a unique opportunity to encourage mentoring and generational exchange between highly skilled dancers at different phases of their careers, as they work side by side to collaborate, rehearse and create.

Risks & Challenges

We understand producing a show involves certain risks and challenges. We have experience producing schedules, liasing with venues and managing budgets. We have secured insurance, and have a sustainable organizational infrastructure ready to mitigate any risks involved. We are prepared.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand a donation isn't within everyone's budget. Support our campaign by sharing among your peers - help get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. You can use the Indiegogo share tools. We'd be grateful for in kind donations if you feel you have goods or services you might offer. Every little piece helps us get that much closer to our goal of putting on a fantastic, unique show.

story:
Our next season...

Atlanta Dance Collective is entering its fourth season of performances, and we have some brand new projects on the horizon! February 2019, ADC will present a gallery exhibition series of Britt Whitmoyer Fishel dance films, an evening length live performance from Sarah Stokes, and our newest creation, the three day all-female dance artists' festival, FEMMEfest, sponsored by The B Complex. We will also be hosting our 4th Annual Opine Dance Film Festival, screening national and international dance film artists, in April 2019.

The Details...

Britt Whitmoyer Fishel will be premiering a series of dance films centered around the dehumanization and animalization of women. The series will be exhibited in the gallery space at the B Complex during the week leading up to, and during ADC’s 2019 Season of performances.

Sarah Stokes will be premiering an evening length work as part of our 2019 Season at The B Complex. Working collaboratively with a local artist, the piece will explore shifting perspectives of relationships through time. The work will feature Atlanta Dance Collective dancers as well as local guest artists.

FEMMEfest is...

A Three day festival celebrating Atlanta’s female dance artists.

Hosted by Atlanta Dance Collective, the festival will provide an avenue  for the innovative and insightful work that women are creating in our community. In producing this program, we aim to highlight Atlanta’s female dance makers, while building further opportunities to see and share work.

Your Support is Invaluable

Your contributions will launch our efforts to bring FEMMEfest to life, allow us to continue to produce and collaborate with other artists, and sustain our ongoing projects.

The Costs:

Production and Exhibition- $2600

Rehearsal and Performance Space- $2500

Tech and Editing - $1100

Insurance and Fees- $800

We are incredibly grateful for whatever support you are inclined to give. Your contribution to our project is invaluable and essential to our success. If you are unable to give monetarily, please share our project, spread the word through social media, email, or word of mouth! Use the Indiegogo share buttons to let people know about us!

Want to know more about ADC? Check out atlantadancecollective.com

story:
Ghost Quartet

Hello! We are the UC Irvine Ghost Quartet, consisting of Aaron Miller, Becca Rowland, Dani Honeyman, and Mark Metzger. Ghost Quartet is a musical/concert by Dave Malloy, and we had the incredible opportunity of undertaking his piece and making our own production of it at UC Irvine. Out of determination and passion, we applied for a research grant from the school and received enough funding to make our production possible. Collectively between the four of us, we rehearsed for 10 weeks, learning the score and directing the piece entirely on our own, and performed this musical in the Robert Cohen Theatre at UC Irvine from June 6-8, 2018.

Our production received tremendous praise from students and faculty alike, often resonating deeply within our audience members. From suggestions and encouragement from those who saw our production, we are reaching out to theater companies to continue performing, and immediately received attention and opportunity from Tenth Avenue Arts Center in San Diego, California. They have graciously offered us their space to perform Ghost Quartet from August 17-19, but without the university's research grant, we need funding to continue this production. Your contribution will allow us to share this unique and beautiful piece of theatre with more and more people, sharing an evening of music and storytelling unlike anything people have experienced before.

The Show

Ghost Quartet is a musical/concert that is written and composed by Dave Malloy, and is a song cycle about love, death, and whiskey. The piece lives in a grey area between drama, concert, and concept album, very much being an undefined genre. The story follows the intertwining narratives of Grimm’s “Rose Red and Snow White,” Edgar Allan Poe’s “The Fall of the House of Usher,” Arabian Nights, and an original narrative of a murder on a modern-day NYC Subway platform. The piece also draws influence from The Twilight Zone, Into the Woods, Thelonious Monk, Rosemary Timperley’s “Harry,” Matsuzake, Stephen King’s Dark Tower series, 8-bit video games like Zelda and Castlevania, and a multitude of other sources.

The piece is performed by four actor/musicians. It is performed as an album; each track is announced and presented with minimal staging, and there are small breaks between each side. Side 3 is performed entirely in the dark. It is intended to be performed in a space recreating a living room-feel with rugs scattered across the playing space, lamps practically lighting the space, and cushions available for people to sit on the floor. We perform it in a 3/4 round with audience members directly next to us, creating an intimate experience. The show is highly collaborative between the performers and the audience, often giving instruments to audience members to play along with us, or maybe even drink some whiskey with us.

Testimonials

A few testimonials from students and faculty at UC Irvine:

“Ghost Quartet is a striking and poignant piece, held together by inspiring and delightful music. The cast of Ghost Quartet is striking and breath-taking. They make the show come to life in the truest sense of the word.”

“This group has taken a truly beautiful play and created an extraordinary experience for their audiences. Their voices transported me to many different worlds and completely immersed me in the many lives of these souls. Not only was this a night of incredible entertainment, but also magic, wonder, and thought-provoking questions.”

“This group has taken a truly beautiful play and created an extraordinary experience for their audiences. Their voices transported me to many different worlds and completely immersed me in the many lives of these souls. Not only was this a night of incredible entertainment, but also magic, wonder, and thought-provoking questions.”

“Ghost Quartet describes itself as a circular story and it certainly translates into a circular experience. It is aware of itself, inviting you present, echoes a recognized sense of play, and coaxes you into the unfamiliar. Unfamiliar is the structure of the play but, not the energy. The players work wonderfully to include you in a remembered feeling of eager story as a child. It can only be described as wonderful in the most literal sense of the word. It is a rounded comfort, like a nice sip of whiskey, or the silence around a campfire.”

"I was lucky enough to see the original off-Broadway production (as well as the reworked Edinburgh version) of Ghost Quartet, and I can say without a doubt that the UCI production revealed things to me that even the original cast did not. The specificity and care taken by the team at UCI was extraordinary and a treat beyond measure. Not only did the cast transport me into the vast array of worlds which encompass Ghost Quartet, they made me feel as if I was a part of their journey. I was influencing them. This openness was refreshing and made the incredible work that Ghost Quartet is shine so very brightly." 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $1,500 for this production of Ghost Quartet. Funding is broken down as such:

$400 - Rights: Dave Malloy and his representatives have graciously offered us the rights to perform Ghost Quartet at $100/performance. We are having an eight-performance run at Tenth Avenue Arts Center, so we need to raise this in order to perform the piece.

$400 - Lighting/Sound Equipment: We light our shows using practical household lamps, and now that we are independent of the university we need to invest in dimmers in order to raise and lower our lights throughout the show.

$300 - Programs/Advertisement: We need funding to print our programs out for all of our audience members, and funding to advertise our show via internet and posters.

$150 - Whiskey: Ghost Quartet is a very communal show between the actors and the audience, and at one point in the show we pass out and serve whiskey to all audience members (21+) that would like a drink. We need money to buy a bottle of Evan Williams for the audience every night.

$250 - Miscellaneous Necessities: There are always new issues that arise, such as last minute instrument repairs and replacements. This funding can also go towards cost of travel.

We're offering some very cool perks to you in return for contributing to our campaign! Please check them out in the perks section of our page.

We hope to have your support, and we hope you can see our show!

-Aaron, Becca, Dani, Mark

story:
We are a diverse group of makers who share an irreverent sense of humor. With backgrounds ranging from stage to film to comic books, we hope to make an impact on the Portland comedy scene with original sketches. Besides filmed sketches, we'll be producing live shows at The Chapel Theater located at Milepost 5, which is an affordable housing community for working artists.

We need $1,000, which will help us with the production costs of our live premiere that include the following expenses:

  • Lights

  • Costumes

  • Set pieces

  • Video production

  • Marketing

Each donor will receive a thank you in the Program Guide for our first show, In GOB We Trust. Additional incentives are listed in the Perks section.

Your contribution will help us achieve the following:

  • Producing future shows and filmed sketches

  • Diversifying the comedy scene in Portland

  • Enhancing the arts scene in the Montavilla community 

Below are some of the following challenges:

  • Balancing work with a creative project that demands time, energy and resources

  • Increasing visibility

  • Managing an independent production 

  • Keeping a team of eight individuals motivated and engaged

Since the formation of Escape Reality, we've made much progress with developing our first show and filming several videos. More importantly, we've  found a home at The Chapel.

If you're unable to donate money, there are other ways you can help:

  • Follow us on Facebook and Instagram @EscapeRealityPDX

  • Contact us if you're interested about potential opportunities by emailing us at escaperealitycomedy@gmail.com or messaging us on Facebook  

  • Spread the word about Escape Reality and our upcoming show scheduled for March 22 and 23

story:
Emily Cargill & Dancers wants to broaden Charlotte dance on a regional & national scale and a large and very important part of each of our seasons is touring to other cities and immersing ourselves into the dance communities while there.  From NYC to Detroit to Tampa to Durham, we have loved meeting the artists, dance makers and dance enthusiasts from across the globe that have made these cities their home.  Founder and Artistic Director, Emily Cargill, traveled to Boston as a teenager in the early 2000s to watch her sister perform with the Boston Ballet and vowed to always return. 

"Boston has been, without a doubt, a destination city for the company since our inception in 2014.  The vibe of Boston is so versatile, from the historical monuments to the retro theatres.  Boston has always been somewhere I knew I had to perform when I started my own dance company.  And now I feel as though this opportunity, being selected to perform at the prestigious and historical Huntington Avenue Theatre, is EXACTLY what my teenage self had in mind only a *handful* of years ago. We are thrilled and honored to be representing the Southeastern region of the U.S. at the Boston Contemporary Dance Festival this August and are looking forward to presenting our work alongside other leading dance makers of today."  

As a small, non-profit dance company, the ability of Emily Cargill & Dancers to successfully tour and have an impact on dance communities nation-wide lies with you!  Individual contributions such as yours will go directly towards our Boston debut.  The donations received will offset travel costs, including the artists' airfare, dancer & choreographer stipends, and lodging for the duration of the 2-day festival.  Help us kick off our 2019-2020 season by donating to our campaign and be a part of the success of our Boston premiere!  Any amount helps and we appreciate your donation to Emily Cargill & Dancers.  Check out our perks and donate the amount that speaks to you!

If you aren't able to donate financially, we still need you and love you!  Please help spread the word about our campaign on social media and share share share to your heart's content!  

__________________________________________________________________________________________

Emily Cargill & Dancers is presenting work all over the east coast, from Atlanta to NYC to Detroit to Richmond to Charlotte to Tampa and now Boston!  Their work has been presented at the High Museum of Art, Art on the Atlanta Beltline, Richmond’s 15th Annual Mid-Atlantic Choreographic Showcase, North Carolina Dance Festival, LadyfestCLT, Skwhirlhaus Theatre, Emory University’s Performing Arts Studio, Dance Canvas’ 2016 & 2017 Emerging Choreographer Initiative, New Grounds Dance Festival, New Seeds Festival, OneSpark Festival, Modern Atlanta Dance Festival, Detroit Dance City Festival and the NYC10 Dance Festival.  Emily has also been commissioned to set work by Staibdance, Jacksonville Dance Theatre, Braided Light Dance Project, Winthrop University, Belmont Abbey College, Kennesaw State University, Georgia College and State University, James Madison University, Washington and Lee University and Douglas Anderson School of the Arts.  

This past January, Emily Cargill & Dancers was commissioned by The Mint Museum Uptown to premiere a dance work as a featured event during the city-wide Connect with Culture Day, which is sponsored by Charlotte’s Arts and Science Council.  ECD premiered hollowed in response to three exhibits on display at the Mint’s Uptown location. 

Emily was the Choreographer in Residence at the 2013 Florida Dance Festival and a 2015 Small Plates Artist, a residency commissioned by the Atlanta Ballet and Zoetic Dance Ensemble. 

Emily was a founding member of the Atlanta-based modern dance company, Staibdance, as well as dancing in works by Gregory Catellier, Corian Ellisor, David Dorfman, Jacksonville Dance Theatre and Braided Light Dance Project.   

Emily has her MFA in Dance Performance and Choreography from Florida State University and her BA in Dance from James Madison University. 

Currently, Emily is an adjunct instructor of dance at Winthrop University, teaching modern technique and choreographing on the Winthrop University Dance Company.  Additionally, Emily has taught as a part-time professor of dance at Spelman College, Kennesaw State University, Georgia College and State University, and Douglas Anderson School of the Arts.  Emily has also been on faculty at the Atlanta Ballet, Georgia Ballet, Atlanta Academy of Ballet and Dance, Callanwolde Fine Arts Center, and the Performing Arts Center of Tallahassee. 

 

 

images by:  Taylor Jones

story:
The Show 

These Streets is a new play with original music, including musical performances. 

It’s 1961 at the height of the folk music scene in Greenwich Village. Eve Harper moves to New York City with dreams of becoming a singer/songwriter. She stumbles upon the local open mic scene, where she meets other aspiring artists Ben Phillips, a talented singer and bar tender struggling with stage fright, and Nancy Tate a writer who falls for Ben, proving to perhaps be the challenge he needs. She also meets folk singer Dennis McKinley. When she meets Dennis sparks fly until his new found career success creates tensions between them. Dennis then must rediscover who he is and what it is that matters to him most. 

A journey into the world of folk music nostalgia. 


Why we need your support:

So far this play has been self produced, but due to the huge expense of taking a show to the Edinburgh Fringe we need your help.

OVER ALL GOAL - $2500

Housing/  $1600

Venue/ $400

PR (posters, flyers)/ $120

Rentals/ $380

 

Other Ways to Help:

- Spreading the word about this campaign on social media.

- Spreading the word about the play at the Fringe to anyone you know who is heading over to Edinburgh Fringe Festival this August.

We would like to say a huge THANK YOU to all of you who took the time to read about this project!
