story:
Hello!

My name is Nicholas Salyer.  I love live theatre, have been working at it most of my life and love to share theatre with others.  I am producing an important stage play project called Storm Warnings to be performed in Poughkeepsie's own venue the Cunneen-Hackett Arts Center located at 12 Vassar St. Poughkeepsie, NY 12601.  

Scheduled for a July 3, 2015 premier, all those who attend will be treated with 3 Master Playwrights' work and 3 Unforgettable fully produced stage plays.  

SNIPER by Arizona renowned Gavin Kayner is the author's rumination of war/violence on the people we send in harm's way.

Gavin Kayner's plays have won numerous awards and been stage-read, workshopped and produced to generous critical commentary.  Some of his award-winning dramas include Noche de los Muertos, The Funniest Joke in the World, Thumbs.  Hokey Pokey and The Language of Flowers.  Critical notes for Flowers include 'a hauntingly beautiful play' - Shirley Gottlieb - Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle.  'A tragedy of Shakespearan proportions' - Chuck Graham for Tucson Stage.  'One of the most well written plays I've read in a long time.' - Audrey Singer - Actor's Forum - LA

LANDFALL by award winning playwright, also hailing from Arizona, Michael Fenlason tells the tale ignited by John Donne's poem Song of myth becoming reality while the tangible meets the intangible in the modern world.

Michael Fenlason is an accomplished playwright whose play The Last Red Book won the Arizona Theatre Company's New Play Prize.  His plays have been performed all over the map including  Pheonix, Tucson, Los Angeles, San Diego, San Francisco, New York, London and Edinburgh.  The American Association of Community Theatre bestowed a Special Recognition Award for his work.

The DANGERS of TOBACCO by Anton Chekhov is the story of a woebegone man's life while he delivers an insightful lecture to comical effect!

Anton Chekhov is one of theatre's most influential playwrights.  He lived in Russia from 1860 to 1904.  Universally recognized as a master of the short story, his plays are still staged worldwide and have influenced countless writers of all genres.

I need your help to cover production costs, 
venue fees, 
insurance for the event, 
set pieces, 
props, 
costumes and 
stipends for professional actors!

Like all difficult projects, there are risks and challenges but our team is confident  we will overcome with help from you, the community, in order to produce the best stage play of the year!

http://s292.photobucket.com/user/nsalyer12/medi...

story:
The SIETAR-Europa congress in Valencia, Spain and the Women Playwrights International conference in Cape Town, South Africa have invited me to perform ALIEN CITIZEN: An Earth Odyssey in May and June-July! These conferences will be highly attended by interculturalists or global theatremakers who might want to book the show at institutions or venues around the world.

HOW FUNDS WILL BE USED

• Roundtrip flights for Alien Citizen and technical operator:

LAX - Valencia (May)  /  LAX - Cape Town (June-July)

• Lodging in Valencia and Cape Town

• Buses, shuttles, taxis for 2 people

• Registration for both conferences 

• Pre-paid temporary international phones or SIM cards

• Meals for 2 people

ABOUT THE CONFERENCES

SIETAR-Europa Congress welcomes all those whose life and work puts them at the interface of cultures, from the perspectives of economy, society, and education with the aim of reshaping intercultural discourse, questioning our current cultural paradigms and exploring new thinking to help us navigate complexity in our emerging global world:

http://www.sietareu.org/seucongress2015

Women Playwrights International conference has brought together women playwrights and allied theatre artists, cultural workers, and scholars together since 1988:

http://www.wpiconference.com

ABOUT THE SHOW

Who are you when you’re from everywhere and nowhere? ALIEN CITIZEN: An Earth Odyssey is a funny and poignant one-woman show about growing up as a dual citizen of mixed heritage in Central America, North Africa, the Middle East, and New England.

I've had the honor and privilege to perform it at colleges and universities in the US, Tjarnarbíó creative center in Iceland, international schools and the US Embassy in Panama, festivals Off Off Broadway and in San Francisco, the FIGT and CMRS conferences, and in Hollywood (world premiere). It would be a dream come true to perform in Europe and Africa--at conferences that could lead to future paid bookings as part of a self-sufficient world tour! (No more crowdfunding after this!)

Trailer and excerpts: http://cargocollective.com/aliencitizen/Trailer...

Press and audience response: http://cargocollective.com/aliencitizen/Press-A...

INDIEGOGO FLEXIBLE CAMPAIGN INFO

IF THE GOAL IS REACHED: At the end of my 30-day campaign, if the combined total of all pledges meets the $12,000 goal, then I receive the funds to take the show to Spain and South Africa (minus some fees).

IF THE GOAL IS NOT REACHED: The money is still withdrawn from your account and perks are provided--and I may only be able to attend one of the conferences depending on how much is raised. 

IF THE GOAL IS EXCEEDED: Any extra funds will be used to film the show for DVD. 

WILL FUNDS BE USED FOR ANYTHING ELSE?

No. Aside from a 4%-9% IndieGoGo fee and a 3% credit card processing fee, all funds raised will be used directly to take the show to Valencia and Cape Town (and film it for the DVD if the goal is exceeded).

story:
How does dancing benefit kids? Let me introduce you to Shaila.

SHAILA was truant. Her grade-5 teacher never knew when she would show up for school. "Some days she's in her seat. Usually, she's not," he said.

I spotted her standing in the back, lurking in the shadows among the bleachers on the day I started the dancing-in-gym class. She caught my eye b/c she followed every move I taught from afar. And, she did it perfectly. For 20 mins, I kept glimpsing her dancing in the shadows, every move and gesture perfectly mimicking mine (in teacher jargon, Shaila is a "kinesthetic learner").

So, I invited her to join me at the front of the class. I was so taken by her quick learning that I asked her to demonstrate the steps w/ me. I was teaching Latin American Dancing, a style best done w/ a capable partner. 

Timid at first, Her confidence grew w/ every run-through. 

She attended school everyday that there was the dancing class. Her teacher was floored. On the day my program ended, Shaila cried. I told her to keep coming to school and I just might get to bring the dancing back.

Three years on, I bumped into a much older Shaila in the school lunch room. She had stayed in school after all. "Yeah," she said, "I came at first b/c I liked to dance, then I thought I'd stay b/c I liked to learn."

Nuff said.

.  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .

I only have a few days (until April 17th) to raise $1,500 to empower & inspire 150 kids. Please contribute to help other kids learn to dance, and dance to learn. Thank you.

.  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .

Fyi, I created "DARE-2-Dance" to teach children/youth discipline, effort, beauty, struggle, and joy.

Sometimes we act or dance or sing. Other times, we do all three. Mostly, we experiment, make mistakes, take creative risks, and a story and choreography emerges. Everyone can take pride in the final performance.

It's full immersion, on demand, reality dance education for schools, 

(I'd greatly appreciate it if you would share my request w/ your friends.)

story:
Support the Artful Badger as they present their biggest physical theatre production to date at the VAULT Festival 2015.

Please pledge something now, check out our amazing 'perks' and spread the word for us!! Every little counts and we appreciate every penny pledged.


About the Show:

Wild Worlds: Dark Sides is a physical theatre show comprised of a curated collection of acts exploring the animal instinct of the human condition.

Originally Wild Worlds was conceived as a one off for VAULT Festival 2014. This year we realised that we wanted to keep the format of curating several unique acts within one show and use it to present different themes or concepts that we are interested in. In the past year or so, many people we know went though some tough times mentally. Looking at our wider community within the events and festival industry there have been a few casualties who we will never see again and more who almost went the same way. Usually the Artful Badger is known for our light hearted, sexy, playful exuberance, but this year we wanted to see what would happen if the Artful Badger used our mischievous, wild nature to explore the darker sides of humanity. The biggest barrier to recovery is hiding, not connecting, not showing your weakness. We believe that it is important to have permission to feel and experience the dark sides in order to overcome them.

More details of this year here: Wild Worlds: Dark Sides 2015

Here is the video of Wild Worlds 2014:


Wider Program:
Alongside the show itself we are also running an amazing supporting program of events including Wild Wall Dancing & Mindfulness in Movement workshops.

Workshops

Student Mentoring

We are also delighted to be working with drama students from the Academy of Live and Recorded Arts who we are mentoring through The Artful Badger process of devised physical theatre for their first ever full production, Scratch Me if You Can.

Scratch Me If You Can by ALRA Students


What makes this special:

The show includes Aedin Walsh has is traveled from Sweden to develop her physical theatre/aerial act with a unique net structure that moves within the space. No one else in the world has this so it really is a new progression in aerial performance. We have developed a brand new piece for the last act of the show with Follow the Faun featuring the amazing projections by Jack Weir & wall dancing aerial performance with Zoë Cobb. Again a unique and spectacular development for all the artists. Most importantly the audience takes part in this show and we can promise that despite the subject matter of the show will leave feeling amazing, invigorated and alive!

Budget:

Every bit of the budget covers the production of the show: Includes multiple projections, a unique one off aerial rigging net requiring new 10 rigging points to be fitted in the venue. Aerial rigging, dancing. eight performers, rehearsal space, costumes, props, lighting, tech operators, flyers, posters, the PR needed to sell all the tickets, projectors, designers & everything we need to actually make this happen.

To achieve all this with the production standard needed to match the ideas, the work the vision, the meaning behind what this is all about.

Full show budget: £38,000

Sponsorship already secured: £22,000

Expected Income from ticket sales: £8000

Remaining needed: £8000.

We have chosen the flexible funding so if we don't reach the target we still get to keep the money which is really important as the show is going ahead no matter what!

But this money is what we need for the BARE MINIMUM to create the show so please help us reach it!

If the campaign is successful beyond £8000 due to overwhelming support then any extra money will go towards touring the show in 2015/16. This is why we have such amazing top 'perks' which are in themselves well worth the pledged amount.

About the Artful Badger:

Artful Badger was formed in 2007 and is directed by three multidisciplinary artists of Zoë Cobb, Freddy Drabble and Aoife Van Linden Tol.

Zoë Cobb’s talent as a movement director, choreographer, and performer Freddy Drabble’s specialism in events and Aoife Van Linden Tol’s artistic acclaim as a fine artist come together to form a professional artistic core at the heart of the company with years of creative experience in production and direction.

Our company's mandate is to facilitate participants to engage the wild and feral side of their own humanity. Through inclusivity we promote developmental engagement through play. We encourage the integration of these values into the daily lives of both those performing and experiencing our work. Concerning our effect on the audience we have an opportunity to work with Dr. Tamara Russell MSc, Neuroscience and Clinical Applications of Mindfulness. She is our Mindfulness Consultant, advising on content, creative process, and effects on the audience members. Her work will help us understand our effect on audiences .

Some of the places and spaces we have worked: Latitude, The Place's Resolution!, Secret Garden Party (SGP), Wilderness, The Museum of London, The National Trust, Cock and Bull Festival, The Valley, Summer Sunset, Big Noise, Pete the Monkey and LearnFest, as well as many different corporate and private events.


Our Perks!

We have some incredible perks lined up for you! For those who choose our VIB or special Badger experiences we look forward to meeting you and making new badger friends! We are especially exited about our top 'perks'

The question is will anyone book the badger curated Gambian Jungle Party Holiday? At £2000 per person it is actually an amazing deal and would secure all the money we need to make the show happen. We have fantastic connections in Gambia to make it a VIB holiday like no other.

A week long, Jungle Party, Eco Holiday in the Gambia for TEN Artful Badger supporters! A once in a lifetime, life changing experience in Gambia curated & hosted by a team of Badgers just for you! All expenses paid including flights, transport, beach side house with jungle garden, outside bar and pizza oven. 100% organic food, wildlife expeditions to see hippos chimps and hundreds of species of tropical birds, river trips and of course an intimate Badger Party with tribal performances & musical entertainment. You will create you own animal masks & have your own afro-chic outfits tailor made, optional African wrestler, go bareback horse riding along the beach, massage and pampering spa days plus so much more!

To find out more about any of our perks please do get in touch with Aoife:

Aoifetol@gmail.com 07866984727

story:
The Mission 

Our goal is to create a fun and entertaining music video to P!nk's song "Slut Like You" while raising money to donate to Operation USA. Operation USA is an LA-based non-profit organization that is currently helping with earthquake relief efforts in Nepal. 10% of our funds for this music video will go directly to the organization in addition to any extra funding we receive on top of our original goal. 

Budget 

We hope to raise 3,000 USD to fund our project. The funds will be divided between location rental, insurance, craft services, and other aspects of the film production.

The budget breakdown can be seen below.  

The Team 


Ally Arbogast 

Director/Producer/Choreographer

Born in Virginia, Ally currently lives in Los Angeles, California where she is Studying commercial dance at Relativity School. She hopes to create content that brings joy and excitement to her audience. 


Johan Erik Lallerstedt 

Director of Photography 

Johan is an award winning filmmaker from Sweden. He currently resides in Los Angeles where he is studying film at Relativity School. 


Devon Young 

Assistant Director 

Devon is a filmmaker currently living in Los Angeles. After studying theatre and fine arts in Las Vegas, she has decided to devote her craft to film production. 


Tyler Osika 

Camera Operator 

Tyler is a designer and animator from Illinois. He recently moved to Los Angeles where he is currently pursuing his career in film. 

Eli DiFiore

First Assistant Camera 

Eli is an action sports cinematographer originally from Massachusetts. He currently lives in Los Angeles where he is studying producing at Relativity School.

story:
The Show and Theater!

Johnny, Tunny and Will struggle to find meaning in a post-9/11 world. When the three disgruntled men flee the constraints of their hometown for the thrills of city life, their paths are quickly estranged when Tunny enters the armed forces, Will is called back home to attend familial responsibilities, and Johnny's attention becomes divided by a seductive love interest and a hazardous new friendship. An energy-fueled rock opera, American Idiot, features little dialogue and instead relies on the lyrics from Green Day's groundbreaking album to execute the story line. 
Founded in 1995 by owner Bruce Grossman, the Cultural Arts Playhouse of Plainview, Roslyn Heights and Wantagh is a year round off-off Broadway style theater that has produced over 500 productions including educational and touring shows. Named by Long Island Press as one of Long Island’s Best Live Theaters, the theater serves more than 20,000 people each year with its professional adult productions, children’s theater performances, and theater education classes for ages 7-18.  Along with its Musical Theater and Acting Academy (MTAA) and Young People’s Theater (YPT) more than 5000 students have had the opportunity to learn from the finest instructors in the New York area. With the over 150 years of combined experience of it staff, many of CAP’s students and performers have been able to use their CAP experiences and use the talents they have learned to do professional theater, recordings, television and film.

What We Need 

We need support from anyone who loves music and wants to see this show performed with live musicians with proper sound equipment. We have amazing professional musicians lined up to play this show, so let's help them out in return. Also, because this show called for a loud headbanging pit we need to make sure the cast gets heard!

The Impact

This album and then show has meant a tremendous amount to me and other people from my generation. Your contributions to make sure this show sounds awesome will be helping to make one of my dream shows come to life. The audiences that come to see it will also be blown away by what they are hearing from these musicians. Let's make the show the best it can possibly be! 

Anything you can give means a tremendous amount!

Risks 

Unfortunately if we don't meet our goal we will need to cut back on the band. American Idiot has BEAUTIFUL arrangements that call for a string section as well as a rock band. We will need to cut instruments out of it and the show won't sound as amazing it could. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Another way to help is to buy your tickets for the show in advance! There is a discount if you do it that way as well. You can purchase tickets for the show with this link: http://www.culturalartsplayhouse.com/tickets/am...

story:
THIS CAMPAIGN CLOSED, BUT ITS NOT TOO LATE:

CLICK HERE TO CONRIBUTE TO THE NEW CAMPAIGN

http://igg.me/at/UToXQyo4aDw/x/3947786

OR DIRECTLY TO FRACTURED ATLAS

https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=12439


-------------------------------------


Meta-Phys Ed. is a multi-disiplinary performance collaborative that explores the inseparable relationship between art and spirituality.

This July their new work, Karaoke Bacchae, written and directed by Jesse Freedman, will premier at the New Ohio Ice Factory festival in New York City.

Karaoke Bacchae is a dance theater adaptation of the Euripides’ tragedy, The Bacchae, imagined in a sports bar on karaoke night during the Stanley Cup. Karaoke is canceled to watch the game. The god Dionysus takes the human form of Iggy Pop and leads a horde of drunken sorority girls and cocktail waitress’ into a battle of submission for control of the karaoke machine, against the bars sado-masochistic management. Sung and shouted under the ultimate karaoke playlist, driven by dance and features text from Drunk J. Crew, deranged sorority girl email, and a sexually frustrated drunken high school english teacher.

July 22-25 2015

Ticket Info coming soon. 

Ice Factory is an OBIE Award-winning summer festival of new work.

Every summer  The New Ohio Theater invites the most exciting downtown companies to present their latest projects in an environment of generosity, dialogue, and inspiration. Ice Factory is a place where artists can take risks, try out new ideas, and bring their projects to a new level. 

Plays introduced in Ice Factory have gone on to garner Drama Desk nominations, OBIE Awards, Audience First Awards in Edinburgh, Off-Broadway productions, commercial runs, and national and international tours.


Funding for this project will go towards:

-Artist fees!!!!

-Rehearsal space in NYC$$$$

-Set and costume pieces.

-Renting a really nice projector


PROJECT HISTORY:
Karaoke Bacchae's development began at Sarah Lawrence College in the MFA Theater Practicum. 
In October 2014 a concert reading of the complete script was presented at La Mama Club, produced by Eugene Lange Colleges "Alumnight," curated by Zishan Urgulu.

story:
What happens when a young couple in need of some extra cash invites a scientist into their home to observe their every move?  

Playwright Colby Day developed Kitchen Sink Experiment(s) through our annual Read. Play. Write. reading series.  We not only loved the simplicity of his script, but also its profound effect on a live audience.  It was immediately clear to us that we needed to produce this universal, but also intimately specific piece.

Kitchen Sink Experiment(s) was written as a way to truly engage an audience in the science of observation and we have chosen a setting that is definitely unique: A real Brooklyn apartment.

Our audiences each night are limited to 20 people, who are encouraged to participate in the transformation that takes place when a young couple allows a scientist to observe the intimacies of their home life.  Crashbox is collaborating with director Andrew J. Scoville and a talented team of experienced artists to help create this hyper-realistic world. 

This is where your generous support is so greatly needed!  This is a major vehicle for our growing company as we secure a place as a visible, artistic force in the theater world that is dedicated to creating a physical space that will honor our playwrights story and intentions.  Your pledge not only supports this important production but is an important investment in our future.  We’re here on Indiegogo to raise $25,000, the minimum that we’ll need in order to rent the space, pay for insurance, costumes and other overhead, including payment for the actors and production team, and genuinely create the world of this play for our Fall 2015 production.



Meet our Crashbox Theater Company members and the production team for Kitchen Sink Experiment(s):


COLBY DAY
Playwright

Colby Day, a Brooklyn-based playwright and filmmaker, tells stories about people, robots, and monsters who deal with feelings. His plays have been developed and produced by Crashbox Theater Company, Pipeline Theatre Company, UglyRhino, Theater for the New City, and The Tank. He participated in Pipeline’s PlayLab in 2014 and 2015 and has been a writer in residence with TRE & The In-Between People. He wants you to recognize your feelings in his work, especially the dumb, bad, wrong ones. Because he thinks those are magical and aren't dumb or bad at all.


ANDREW J. SCOVILLE
Director

Andrew J. Scoville is a Brooklyn based theater director focusing on developing new work that merges science and performance. He most recently directed Molly Murphy & Neil deGrasse Tyson On Our Last Day On Earth at ANT Fest this past summer. He is co-creator of a podcast called 'People Doing Math' which presents music, drama and conversations inspired by mathematical concepts. He is the  director of Love Machine, a high-tech, interactive performance in three parts utilizing actor and audience responsive technology.  He is a co-Founder/co-Director of Fresh Ground Pepper, a not-for-profit dedicated to making it easier to create new work through a series of artistic challenges and developmental programs.  He worked as Associate Director for Alex Timbers on David Byrne’s musical Here Lies Love for both NYC and UK Productions.


MERIDITH JONES
Artistic Director

Meridith Jones is an actor, theater producer, Crashbox founding member and proud storytelling addict. She is a graduate of Atlantic Acting School Conservatory and former ensemble member of Kansas based company Theater On Consignment.  Stage credits include: The Liddy Plays (Crashbox), The Hurtling Stillness (The Whitelisted Theatre Co.), Three Sisters (Highly Impractical Theatre), Fool For Love (TOC) and The House of Yes (TOC).  She served as a Production Assistant on the Woodshed Collective 2011 production of The Tenant and has designed props for theater productions in the Midwest and East Coast, including the first NYC revival of Hunting and Gathering (Crashbox).  


BRITTANY CROWELL

Managing Director

Brittany Crowell is a theater producer and administrator.  She is currently the Production Manager for Third Rail Projects, working on their long-running, immersive hit Then She Fell and other projects in development. Brittany has worked as a Stage Manager and Production Manager on many productions, including collaborations with The Bower Group, Tinkers Collective, the Truf, and Anthill Productions.  She has assisted Broadway Producer Jill Furman and was the 2012 Management Coordinator for the revitalization summer season at the Bucks County Playhouse.


Crashbox Theater Company's mission is to examine the beautiful human struggle through all its awkward fragments.  Our company thrives on the relationships we build with incredibly brave playwrights, the risks that they challenge us to take and the creation of an ongoing platform where their work can be fostered.  Since 2010, we have produced and developed the work of more than fifteen emerging and established playwrights.  In 2013, Crashbox produced the first New York revival of Hunting and Gathering and the world premiere of The Liddy Plays in our season dedicated to playwright Brooke Berman.  This past August, Crashbox commissioned an evening of short plays, including Teeming Shore by Nick Gandiello, which will be published in Smith and Kraus's "The Best Ten-Minute Plays of 2015."  Our third annual reading series, Read. Play. Write., focused on the development of work by five exciting new writers, including Colby Day.

From top left:  Michael Sean Cirelli, Meridith Jones, Jon Friestedt, Jordan Smith. From bottom left: Thomas Muccioli, Brittany Crowell, Rebecca Schoffer, Rebecca Vineyard

CRASHBOX THEATER COMPANY MEMBERS:

Milee Bang, Michael Sean Cirelli, Brittany Crowell, Jon Friestedt, Jolenta Greenberg, Meridith Jones, Thomas Muccioli, Jenna Krasowski, Nila Sawyer, Rebecca Schoffer, Griffin Sherbert, Erica Genereux Smith, Jordan Douglas Smith and Rebecca Vineyard.


Personnel includes actors and staff = $5,070

Design includes costumes, sound, props, the set and lighting = $2,620

Space includes the theater, storage and rehearsal space = $7,420

Other costs include insurance, PR , printing, photos, transportation = $4,470

Indiegogo campaign costs include the 7-percent fee, film, marketing, perk costs, and our campaign manager = $5,420


THANK YOU FOR BECOMING A BACKER!

Crashbox is proud to be able to foster the work of incredibly talented emerging playwrights and we know it wouldn't be possible without our friends, family and community!  From the bottom of our hearts, we thank you for your support!!

story: The Ashley Bouder Project is raising fund to complete the editing of "In Passing," a new short dance film which ultimately will be available to stream for free, as well as the commission of a new work starring Ashley Bouder by Adriana Pierce, featuring costumes by Reid & Harriet and lighting by Jimmy Lawlor. Both new works will premiere at the Joyce Theater on August 8, 2015. These works will allow us to have the repertory to travel to smaller communities with these new works, as well as reach as many people digitally as possible to engage people with the art of ballet.

Both new works will premiere at the Joyce Theater on August 8, 2015. These works will allow us to have the repertory to travel to smaller communities with these new works, as well as reach as many people digitally as possible to engage people with the art of ballet.

story:
Opening Statement

Hi everyone! Thank you for taking the time to visit our page!

Both Obadiah Wright and I, Alessandro Cirafici, are starting our fourth year at Bard College. Being members of the College’s Conservatory of Music, we are working to complete a dual degree program which involves our studies in the Conservatory alongside our studies in an academic field. As part of the requirements for our college degree, we are required to write a Senior Thesis. Per my second major (I am a German Studies major) and my desire to connect my academic and conservatory studies, I am collaborating with Obadiah to write and produce an Opera for the Spring of 2016. For this project, I am responsible for writing the Libretto while Obadiah is responsible for writing the music; both Obadiah and I are also co-producers for this opera.

Since the Spring of 2014, both Obadiah and I have been collaborating to prepare each aspect of the project. Since then, we have put into motion a project involving a 40 piece orchestra and cast, and a 14 person production crew. Our goal is to raise the money to produce this opera and perform it at the Rhinebeck Performing Arts Center, which we are renting from March 31st-April 2nd of the 2016 year for the performance and tech rehearsals. In order to succeed with this project, we are hoping to raise $10,000 in order to pay for the rent of the hall, all production costs and subsequent budgets for internal works such as costuming and set, and in order to pay our production team, cast, and orchestra.

Every donation is appreciated and goes a long way in making this project a reality. We know that with your support we can bring this opera alive.

Please continue down the page to see our budget, who is involved, to read the German fairytale that has inspired our Opera, learn more about the hall we will be renting, and to learn more about the composer and librettist.

Again, thank you for your time, and we hope to see you in April 2016 for the premiere of Godfather Death.

Who is Involved

Librettist and Co-Producer: Alessandro Cirafici

Composer and Co-Producer: Obadiah Wright

Conductor: 1

Orchestra: 20 players

Cast: 20 members

Costume Director: 1 person

Technician: 1 person

Set Director and Crew: 4 people

Stage Managers: 3 people


When and Where

The premiere will be held at the Rhinebeck Performing Arts Center in April 2016

http://www.centerforperformingarts.org/


Budget

Rent: $2000

Set and Costume: $1200

Uhaul Rental: $300

50 people involved in the project: $120.00 ea. = $6500

Total= $10,000

The Original Grimm Fairytale

http://www.grimmstories.com/en/grimm_fairy-tales/godfather_death

Meet the Librettist

Alessandro Cirafici, born and raised in Brooklyn, New York, is currently a junior at the Bard College Conservatory of Music studying Oboe under the direction of Elaine Douvas and Alexandra Knoll along with prior instruction from Richard Dallessio and Nicholas Stovall. Regularly appearing in performances with the Bard College Conservatory Orchestra—those performances including its performances at Avery Fisher Hall, and performances at the Woodbourne Correctional Facility in Woodbourne, New York through their Prison Initiative Program—Mr. Cirafici has performed in numerous Chamber Ensembles—with the most recent performance of the Maslanka 3rd wind Quintet at the Hartt School of Music under the guidance of Peter Serkin, Laura Flax, and David Wakefield. Mr. Cirafici also makes frequent appearances with the Conservatory Baroque Ensemble under the direction of Dr. Alexander Bonus, performing a wide range of composers from Giovanni Paolo Cima to Pergolesi along with major known works such as Bach’s St. Johns Passion, Magnificat, and Handel’s Esther Oratorio. Along with his studies in the Conservatory, Mr. Cirafici is pursuing a second degree in German Studies.

Meet the Composer

Obadiah Wright is an undergraduate at Bard College Conservatory pursing a B.M. in music composition, under the direction of Joan Tower and George Tsontakis, and a B.A. in Religious Studies. Mr. Wright has played cello and harp for many years with teachers Cheryl Fippen and Verlene Schermer; however, recently he has picked up the Erhu, a Chinese instrument. At Bard Mr. Wright is the co-head of both the Tango Club and the Traditional Chinese Instruments Collective. A participant of the Tanglewood Music Festival, Mr. Wright has had his music played by various talented musicians which include, but are not limited to, the Vento Chiaro Woodwind Quintet and the Da Capo Chamber Ensemble.


Any donations made will automatically receive a thank you card on behalf of everyone who is working on this Opera, and their names printed in the playbill.

Again, thank you for your time,
and we hope to see you in April 2016 for the premiere of Godfather Death.

Who is InvolvedLibrettist and Co-Producer: Alessandro Cirafici Composer and Co-Producer: Obadiah Wright
Conductor: 1
Orchestra: 20 players
Cast: 20 members
Costume Director: 1 person
Technician: 1 person
Set Director and Crew: 4 people
Stage Managers: 3 peopleWhen and Where
The premiere will be held at
the Rhinebeck Performing Arts Center in April 2016
http://www.centerforperformingarts.org/Budget
Rent: $2000
Set and Costume: $1200
Uhaul Rental: $300
50 people involved in the
project: $120.00 ea. = $6500
Total= $10,000
The Original Grimm Fairytale
http://www.grimmstories.com/en/grimm_fairy-tales/godfather_deathMeet the Librettist
Alessandro
Cirafici, born and raised in Brooklyn, New York, is currently a
junior at the Bard College Conservatory of Music studying Oboe under the
direction of Elaine Douvas and Alexandra Knoll along with prior instruction
from Richard Dallessio and Nicholas Stovall. Regularly appearing in
performances with the Bard College Conservatory Orchestra—those performances
including its performances at Avery Fisher Hall, and performances at the Woodbourne
Correctional Facility in Woodbourne, New York through their Prison Initiative Program—Mr.
Cirafici has performed in numerous Chamber Ensembles—with the most recent
performance of the Maslanka 3rd wind Quintet at the Hartt School of Music under
the guidance of Peter Serkin, Laura Flax, and David Wakefield. Mr. Cirafici also makes frequent appearances with the Conservatory
Baroque Ensemble under the direction of Dr. Alexander Bonus, performing a wide
range of composers from Giovanni Paolo Cima to Pergolesi along with major known
works such as Bach’s St. Johns Passion, Magnificat, and Handel’s Esther
Oratorio. Along with his studies in the Conservatory, Mr. Cirafici is pursuing
a second degree in German Studies.
Meet the Composer
Obadiah Wright is an
undergraduate at Bard College Conservatory pursing a B.M. in music composition,
under the direction of Joan Tower and George Tsontakis, and a B.A. in Religious
Studies. Mr. Wright has played cello and harp for many years with teachers Cheryl
Fippen and Verlene Schermer; however, recently he has picked up the Erhu, a
Chinese instrument. At Bard Mr. Wright is the co-head of both the Tango Club and the
Traditional Chinese Instruments Collective. A participant of the Tanglewood Music Festival, Mr. Wright has had his music played by various talented musicians
which include, but are not limited to, the Vento Chiaro Woodwind Quintet and
the Da Capo Chamber Ensemble.Any donations made will automatically receive a thank you card on behalf of everyone who is working on this Opera, and their names printed in the playbill.

story:
Creative Moves "MASK" is heading to the Great Salt Lake Fringe Festival!

And YOU can help us get there!

Young lovers! Mischievous Servants! Grumpy (and greedy!) old men. “Mask” is a Commedia dell’Arte inspired movement theatre piece. Creative Moves takes its cues from traditional characters and story lines and gives them  their own unique twist. A fun and thoughtful show, with a surprise or two in store!

This show was originally created as part of the summer Renaissance Festival at  Old Town Actors Studio in Pocatello, and now we are taking it to the first ever Great Salt Lake Fringe Festival! We are very excited to be able to share this show with more audiences, but we need your help to get there!

What We Need

Our cast and crew is small and dedicated, but taking a show on the road is quite the undertaking! We will need funds to

  • Build a portable set
  • Pay venue fees for the festival
  • Pay royalties for music used in the show
  • Travel to Salt Lake (gas isn't cheap!)
  • Provide meals and housing for our performers for the duration of the festival
  • Pay rehearsal and performance stipends to the performers

What You Get

We are offering several perks, including downloadable art work, and a few special snail mail packages. There's also the opportunity to participate in a google hangout with the cast, either before the festival at a rehearsal, or after the festival to ask about our experiences. You will also be joining a long tradition of serving as a patron for the arts!

The Impact

Commedia dell'Arte is an art form that continues to echo through the theatre world today. This show takes that structure, and explores identity, power, and friendship, through a lens of playfulness and laughter. Bringing the show to a Fringe Festival takes our creation outside of Idaho, and brings attention to the performing arts scene in Southeast Idaho. I have directed, created, and produced several shows and performance installations in Pocatello, and I am looking forward to the challenge of sharing what we have created here in our small community with a wider audience.

Risks and Challenges

The Great Salt Lake Fringe Festival is in its inaugural year, and this will also be our first time taking a show "on the road." We are looking forward to overcoming any bumps and challenges along the way. Our cast is small and dedicated; our director and technical director are persistent and hardworking, and we all face the anticipated challenges with both determination and a sense of humor!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you are unable to contribute, but we would appreciate it if you would share our IndieGoGo page and help spread the word!

story:
What's Hootenanny, and why does it need my help?

When Monique LaForce pitched the idea of a play set backstage, during a performance of a bluegrass musical version of Macbeth, we got excited!

What a perfect show for Guillotine Theatre, a company devoted to presenting classic plays, and modern plays based on classic literature!

What a great chance to work with our friends, bluegrass band Dead Men's Hollow!


We were thrilled when the National Museum of Women in the Arts agreed to co-produce and to be our venue for 5 performances!

We were tickled pink when Ivy Hill Cemetery agreed to let us perform for 2 more performances in their receiving vault! 

Just one problem -- the $1000 grant from the Puffin Foundation, used to develop and workshop the play in 2014 was almost all spent.

We need $1000 more to present Hootenanny. $800 pays the actors and the band stipends, $200 covers costumes and props.

Help us out, and we'll make sure to acknowledge you in the program, and send you one of our fun perks!

Why is this particular show important?

Fifty-one percent of the population is female, and yet only about 24 percent of all plays produced across the country in the coming season are written by women, living or dead. 

Enter the Women's Voices Theater Festival. 

The Women's Voices Theater Festival invited Guillotine Theatre to present a new play by a woman playwright.

Why invite a classical theatre to present a new play by a woman?

Guillotine Theatre is the founder of DC SWAN (Support Women Artists Now) Day, a one-day celebration of women performers, writers, directors, and visual artists that takes place the final Saturday of March, at sites throughout Washington DC.

So to participate, we needed a brand-new play by a woman playwright. Who better than Monique LaForce, who wrote for Guillotine in 2011 and 2014?

Monique's plays include the critically-acclaimed Kenneth, What Is the Frequency? (co-written with Ian Allen) and The Blizzard Comes (one of the five plays that comprised Guillotine Theatre's 2011 Fringe Festival hit Belle Parricide), and last year’s Fringe Festival hit, Isis and Vesco Investigate the Curious Death of Dr. Freud. 

...and partnering with Dead Men's Hollow gives a literal meaning to the 'Women's Voices' name -- check out these harmonies!

So, why run an Indiegogo campaign?

Guillotine Theatre is a small theatre, operating on a shoestring budget. We are the oldest small classical theatre in the DC area, and what we can do with a few thousand $$ will impress you!

Theatre is a risky business, and -- just like Shakespeare and the King's Men, or Moliere and the Theatre Illustre -- we need patrons. Wouldn't you like to be a patron of the arts?

I can't contribute, but I'd like to help

There are other ways to help us bring Hootenanny to the Women's Voices Theatre Festival:

  • Like us on Facebook.
  • Follow us on Twitter.
  • Contact us, and volunteer.
  • Share this campaign with your friends, family, co-workers, people you meet at the bus stop, etc.
Please help us spread the word about Hootenanny. Tickets are on sale starting September 2nd. Please come and see us -- and bring your friends!

story:
The Show

MUSE takes us back to the 1930s to reveal the inspiration for Christopher Isherwood’s Sally Bowles – and uncovers a far more complex and talented woman. While many are familiar with the character from 'The Berlin Stories' further popularised by Kander & Ebb's musical and of course Fosse's film starring Liza Minelli, few are aware that the character was based upon the 'divinely decadent' Jean Ross.

With her green-painted nails and a string of lovers, Ross (who roomed in the same house as Isherwood) was indeed 'divinely decadent' but far from the air-headed floozy in the stories. Born in Egypt, RADA-trained and allergic to conventionality, she became a respected political journalist who filed reports from the siege of Madrid in the Spanish Civil War and brought up (as a single mother) a daughter who herself overturned convention. Along the way she was also the muse for a German pianist on his way to Hollywood, and of the lyricist Eric Maschwitz – his song These Foolish Things, written about Ross after their affair ended, is among the authentic songs featured in the production.  

This new one woman musical telling the story of Jean Ross previews on May 29/30/31 at Brighton Fringe ahead of a three week run at the Edinburgh Fringe. The show was developed from a concept - 'A Dozen Roses' - that performed in 2014 based upon the idea of what happened after 'Cabaret'. While researching Jean Ross, we felt that this formidable lady's rich life was perfect for a new, entertaining work.

The show features a fantastic three piece jazz band performing songs of the era by Cole Porter, Rodgers & Hart and Kurt Weill and we hope you enjoy this campaign's video of the previous show's highlights featuring Producer and Performer, Sophie Jugé and Writer and Musical Director, Gez Kahan.

MUSE is the first in a series of new shows by Jugé Productions about inspiring women of the 1930s. For Writer and Musical Director Gez Kahan, the varied lifestyles and nationalities of the characters provide an opportunity to create witty and entertaining works infused with multi-linguistic delights which perfectly suit this European production company.

Producer and Performer Sophie Jugé is taking on the challenge of playing the formidable Jean Ross, contrasting her free-spirited youth and diverse experiences with her subsequent more private personal life.

“Jean Ross is a fantastic role to play. I feel the responsibility to pique the audience’s interest in this lady accented by the great songs in our new show.”  - Sophie Jugé

Following previews at Brighton Fringe this May, a MUSE gala preview plays for one night at the Kenton Theatre in Henley-on-Thames. We have put together a Gala Sponsor Perk especially for this event.

The Team

If you are kind enough to support this project, you can do so knowing that the performing Company is an experienced team of creatives dedicated to making MUSE a success. The team has already committed to appearing at Edinburgh, Venue 38, SpaceTriplex from 10-29 August.

Producer & Performer Sophie Jugé...

...trained at Elmhurst Ballet School and London School of Musical Theatre. She has previously performed at Edinburgh Fringe and is excited by the challenge of staging her own production in Edinburgh.
Theatre credits include:

  • Kitty Velour in A Dozen Roses (Assembly Room, Marlow)
  • Angustias in Bernarda Alba (Union Theatre, London)
  • Mrs. Taylor and Dance Captain in The Remains of The Day (Union Theatre, London)
  • Nurse and Ensemble in Anyone Can Whistle (Jermyn Street Theatre, London)
  • Gladys in The Pajama Game (Rose & Crown Theatre, London)
  • Grace/Dot/Swan in Honk (Oxford Studio Theatre)
  • Miranda Ferrari in A Comedy of Arias (Edinburgh Festival, Jermyn Street Theatre and New Ambassador’s Theatre – West End)
  • Sophie in 100 (Camberley Theatre)
  • Woman 1 in Closer Than Ever (Edinburgh Festival and Jermyn Street Theatre)
  • Eliza de Feuillide in JANE – the musical (Artrix Theatre, Birmingham)

Sophie is also a classical pianist, musical director and stylist! www.sophiejuge.net

Writer & Musical Director Gez Kahan...

...played his first gig as a 15 year old, and later played and wrote arrangements for the National Youth Jazz Orchestra, before turning full-time pro in his early 20s. He has performed alongside names including Jimmy Page, Phil Collins and Marion Montgomery, in addition to countless recording sessions. Gez’s experience runs the full gamut of popular music, from solo piano stints in high class restaurants to backing cabaret turns in a strip club, from dance bands to out and out rockers, and from writing and arranging original material to providing music for commercials and promotions. He’s been a top demonstrator at international trade shows and in stores for musical instrument manufacturer Roland, he’s taught music and he also writes about music. He founded the UK’s leading musical instrument trade paper, MI Pro, and is a regular correspondent for Pianist magazine.
Gez is also the musical director and plays keys for Oye Santana.

Director Alexandra Karathodorou...

...was born in Athens, Greece.  She moved to the UK when she was 18 and has since completed studies in Psychology,  International Relations, Text and Performance and Acting.  She has acted in short films and the London Fringe Theatre and has recently directed the short film 'Don’t Call Us,  God, We’ll Call You'.

Your Support

Show Costs

Our budget to deliver this show in Edinburgh is £12,150 comprising:
  • venue hire £3,500
  • advertising, flyers & posters £1,500
  • travel & accommodation £4,000
  • venue technicians £450
  • band fees £2,700
Compensation for the members of the Production Company is all profit-based and we are extremely motivated to make this show a positively-reviewed success!
Staging a production in Edinburgh is an expensive undertaking! The show will perform for 18 nights in a 60 seat theatre with tickets priced between £7 and £10. Based upon an average 35% occupancy during the run the ticket sales of c. £3,000 will not cover the show's budget and we are seeking help to underwrite our Edinburgh debut so that we can do the show justice.

Ticket Sales

Staging a production in Edinburgh is an expensive undertaking! The show will perform for 18 nights in a 60 seat theatre with tickets priced between £7 and £10. Based upon an average 35% occupancy during the run the ticket sales of c. £3,000 will not cover the show's budget and we are seeking help to underwrite our Edinburgh debut so that we can do the show justice.

We are £9,000 short of break-even!

We have intentionally set a low campaign target on this funding campaign to ensure success and minimise crowdfunding fees. The target is not what we are aiming for however!
We have put together a range of Indiegogo Perks which we hope appeal and display our thanks for your kind support for this production.
We have a limited set of Sponsor £50 (100x) and Gala Sponsor £100 (49x) Perksin this crowdfunding campaign. While there are costs associated with these Perks, we'd love to achieve full backing from Sponsors and Gala Sponsors together with a good number of Supporter-level and Benefactor-level Perk donations so that we can break-even on delivering this fantastic show!

Other ways to support the production

If you like our show but are not in a financial position to make a donation, we'd still appreciate your help:

Please let your friends know about MUSE and talk about it on Facebook and Twitter!

Make use of the Indiegogo share tools!

...and if you've read this far, thank you so much for your interest in our show!

story:
Support Dog Sees God -

DOG SEES GOD - confessions of a teenage blockhead
June 5 - June 28, 2015
Tackling homophobia, bullying, coming of age, teen violence, sexual identify, suicide and eating disorders - and surviving high school!

CB begins to question the existence of an afterlife. But a chance meeting with the target of the group's bullying, offers CB a peace of mind and sets in motion a friendship that will push teen angst to the very limits. 
Drug use, suicide, eating disorders, teen violence, rebellion and sexual identity collide and careen toward an ending that's both haunting and hopeful.
We need to rent a piano for this production - and it just isn't in our budget, but you can help make that happen.  Donate now, to help us raise the $1500 needed.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to rent a piano for the stage production of Dog Sees God - and the $1500 rental for the 4 week performance run, just isn't in our budget.  Maryland Piano is giving use a great discount, but we still need your help. 

Anyone who donates $10 or more will be listed in our program and on our website as a Sponsor.

Anyone who donates $50 or more will receive an invitation for two to our Invited Preview Performances (plus the above).

Anyone who donates $100 or more will receive two tickets to our Opening Night Performance and Reception with Director and Cast (plus above).

Anyone who donates $500 or more will receive four tickets to out Opening Night Performance and Reception with Director and Cast, and Four Tickets to the next production at Spotlighters - ALTAR BOYZ (plus program & website listing, invitation to Invited Preview Performance).

All funds will be used to support this production - piano rental, costumes, sets, etc.  All designers and cast are donating their time to bring this powerful message to the Baltimore community and raise awareness of Bullying, Teen Violence, Suicide, Drug Use, Eating Disorders and more!


The Impact

DOG SEES GOD is an audience exercise in empathy. This cast has done such an incredible job of reaching into their own experiences in order to present this view of life for today's American teenager. What we want most of all is to be able to talk to you, the audience, in order to discuss these issues. We're by no means expecting this show to produce cut-and-dry solutions to these problems, but we hope that this play will facilitate better understanding of and communication with this younger generation both inside and outside of the theatre.

If you are a high schooler, I hope you and your parents come see this play. If you are an adult who has high schoolers at home or works with high schoolers, I hope you come see this play; and I hope you encourage your kids and students to see it, too. We look forward to having you.


Risks & Challenges

Spotlighters is a small non-profit theatre, with a 53 year long history of producing amazing theatre that challenges both actor and audience.  From shows that raised awareness of LGBTQ issues in the early 70s, to issues of sexual abuse, and bullying --- we continue to entertain and educate our audiences.   We do not have a large marketing or development team raising money for us or promoting our shows - we rely on our patrons and our individual donors.  This show is important, and the piano is central to the story --- so, we have tackled this challenge and with your help we will continue to succeed!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate - and we  understand that some folks can't -- but please share the announcement about the fund raising campaign and about the performances so that as many folks as we can tell, will come and see the show.  The message of DOG SEES GOD is powerful and moving, and heart-breaking --- but it is not written in stone, we can change the ending, if we all get involved.  Share our fund raising campaign, encourage folks to give - and come see the show!
story_txt:
Support Dog Sees God -

DOG SEES GOD - confessions of a teenage blockheadJune 5 - June 28, 2015Tackling homophobia, bullying, coming of age, teen violence, sexual identify, suicide and eating disorders - and surviving high school!CB begins to question the existence of an afterlife. But a chance meeting with the target of the group's bullying, offers CB a peace of mind and sets in motion a friendship that will push teen angst to the very limits. Drug use, suicide, eating disorders, teen violence, rebellion and sexual identity collide and careen toward an ending that's both haunting and hopeful.

We need to rent a piano for this production - and it just isn't in our budget, but you can help make that happen.  Donate now, to help us raise the $1500 needed.
   What We Need & What You Get We need to rent a piano for the stage production of Dog Sees God - and the $1500 rental for the 4 week performance run, just isn't in our budget.  Maryland Piano is giving use a great discount, but we still need your help. 
Anyone who donates $10 or more will be listed in our program and on our website as a Sponsor.
Anyone who donates $50 or more will receive an invitation for two to our Invited Preview Performances (plus the above).
Anyone who donates $100 or more will receive two tickets to our Opening Night Performance and Reception with Director and Cast (plus above).
Anyone who donates $500 or more will receive four tickets to out Opening Night Performance and Reception with Director and Cast, and Four Tickets to the next production at Spotlighters - ALTAR BOYZ (plus program & website listing, invitation to Invited Preview Performance).
All funds will be used to support this production - piano rental, costumes, sets, etc.  All designers and cast are donating their time to bring this powerful message to the Baltimore community and raise awareness of Bullying, Teen Violence, Suicide, Drug Use, Eating Disorders and more!

The Impact
 
DOG SEES GOD is an audience exercise in empathy. This cast has done such an incredible job of reaching into their own experiences in order to present this view of life for today's American teenager. What we want most of all is to be able to talk to you, the audience, in order to discuss these issues. We're by no means expecting this show to produce cut-and-dry solutions to these problems, but we hope that this play will facilitate better understanding of and communication with this younger generation both inside and outside of the theatre.
If you are a high schooler, I hope you and your parents come see this play. If you are an adult who has high schoolers at home or works with high schoolers, I hope you come see this play; and I hope you encourage your kids and students to see it, too. We look forward to having you.
   Risks & Challenges Spotlighters is a small non-profit theatre, with a 53 year long history of producing amazing theatre that challenges both actor and audience.  From shows that raised awareness of LGBTQ issues in the early 70s, to issues of sexual abuse, and bullying --- we continue to entertain and educate our audiences.   We do not have a large marketing or development team raising money for us or promoting our shows - we rely on our patrons and our individual donors.  This show is important, and the piano is central to the story --- so, we have tackled this challenge and with your help we will continue to succeed!
    Other Ways You Can Help If you can't donate - and we  understand that some folks can't -- but please share the announcement about the fund raising campaign and about the performances so that as many folks as we can tell, will come and see the show.  The message of DOG SEES GOD is powerful and moving, and heart-breaking --- but it is not written in stone, we can change the ending, if we all get involved.  Share our fund raising campaign, encourage folks to give - and come see the show!

story:
The Indiegogo campaign for Bgirls Do It Better 2016 is now over

Thank you everybody who contributed! You will get your perk by e-mail or snail mail during January 2016. Everybody who contributed has also earned a free entrance to the BDIB III event in Ljubljana on Saturday 5th of March 2016. Your name will be on the list by the door. 

For more info about this year's Bgirls Do It Better Jam Edition follow updates on the event Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/events/956891901070529/

****************************************************************************
If you still want to donate or redeem your ticket to the event in advance you can do it trough the Cultural and sports association GOR's PayPal account here: https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=5W6D7YLUD7REU

Or as a bank transfer to GOR's bank account SI56 0202 1026 0313 380. With bank transfers please mention BDIB 2016 with your donation.

Thank you.
****************************************************************************

Please help us organise the only event of its kind in Europe! 

Bgirls Do It Better is one of the only events inside hip hop culture dedicated to the women in hip hop: to bgirls, female DJs and graffiti writers and hopefully in future also for female MCs.

Bgirls Do It Better is a very unique event. It only happens once a year and it is extremely important platform for women in hip hop to meet, greet and exchange.

We haven't found any sponsors this year, so we try to make it happen with crowdfunding. Please support!

Bgirls Do It Better in short...

For the past two years we have successfully organised a unique event that the Slovenian dance scene had never witnessed before: Around the date of International Women's Day (8th of March) we have held an event that was aimed specifically at all the girls and women of the culture known as hip hop. 

Our aim is to help female dancers from all over the world to get to know each other, give them an opportunity to show what they're made of and raise the general level of female participation in hip hop.

We dare say that these events have had a positive impact on the vibe of Slovenia's as well as whole Europe's bgirl scene.

The success and positive feedback inspired us to the point of transforming what was then a once-in-a-lifetime event into an annual event. And so we are proud to announce that the next B-Girls Do It Better will take place on Saturday, 5th of March 2016.

For making it happen we would like to ask for your help in funding this project!

Why Bgirls Do It Better?

Bgirls because it is our expression for females in breakdancing, Do It Better because we do it better :)

...We Do It Better but we need funds for making it happen

All the funds we get will go into organising the event. More specifically for:

    • Renting out the place for the jam

    • Paying for the DJs and the DJ equipment rental

    • Paying for invited bgirls travel costs to get to the event and their accommodation costs in Ljubljana

    • Making the posters, flyers, stickers, T-shirts and other marketing material for the event and paying the designer(s)

    • Making the prizes for the winner(s)


Why are we doing this?

As we know, breakdance is a predominantly male sport and you can claim something similar for other elements of hiphop. Because of that, Bgirls Do It Better is dedicated particularly to the development of female participation in hiphop culture. It's the first event of its kind in Slovenia.

We are happy to notice that the activity of women in breakdance, DJing, graffiti and rap in Slovenian hiphop scene has risen significantly as a consequence of this event and other workshops we have organised in the 'women in hiphop' frame. With this, the purpose of BDIB is being fulfilled.

Nonetheless, this is not the end and we would like the growth to continue, so we decided to organise BDIB annually. It's important to emphasize that the visitors and competitors felt the event was made in a good spirit and with positive energy, which is the essential ingredient of the organiser association GOR's vision.

Because of the general recession we are still struggling with in Slovenia we have had a hard time finding sponsors this year. That's why we have decided to try the power of the crowd for funding our 2016 BDIB event.



Bgirls Do It Better III in 2016

For the third edition, we want to present Bgirls Do It Better JAM edition for the first time. It will be focused on dancing itself, in the form of jamming and cyphers, combined with getting to know each other. We will have our own GOR DJs and a live band to provide the music. This time we will pick 8 'Cypher Queens' which will compete for the BDIB title in the '7 to smoke' category. Of course we are expecting visitors and dancers from all across Europe.

About the GOR team

The voluntary and nonprofit association GOR (UP) is a sports and cultural society with the main goal being the collective development and growth of hiphop culture. It connects different actors of the hiphop scene in Ljubljana, from DJs of Good Foot and RDYO groups and graffiti collectives such as 1107 Klan and ZEK crew. At the moment its core is in the bboying or breaking movement with Flow from Below (FFB) crew at its helm. The willingness for organising events, openness for different arrangements and collaboration together with its team and all the fans of the culture have created an amazingly positive and constructive energy that has caused the birth of the association. Yearly GOR organises several different events for all tastes and generations, from jam sessions to gatherings like Cypher to the People, Prid'te GOR (Come Up), Lost Beats and internationally acclaimed breakdancing events King of the Concrete and Bgirls Do It Better.

As a youth organisation, GOR focuses extensively on children and young people, not with just teaching them the skills of individual elements of hiphop but also showing them the importance of community, cultural participation and expression with their example. Cooperation is very important, on a local level GOR works together with other youth and cultural organisations such as Zavod BOB, Zavod O, JKZM Medvode and MOL (The Municipality of Ljubljana); besides that GOR connects and collaborates in Erasmus+ projects on an international level through the Europe du Hip Hop partnership. The motto is Saaaaaam' GOR (Oooooonly UP)! 

Please share the love!

We value donations highly 'cause we really want to make Bgirls Do It Better III to happen. But even if you can't support us financially please show your love by sharing the campaign.

Thank you!

Oooooonly UP!

story:
The Men of the Deeps and The Savoy Theatre have been providing entertainment to Cape Breton Island for a combined 139 years! In 2016, the Men of the Deeps will celebrate their 50th anniversary while the Savoy Theatre enters its 89th year in operation.  Please help support these two Ambassadors of Cape Breton Island. 

50 YEARS OF SONG FOR THE MEN OF THE DEEPS 

For the past 50 years, Cape Breton's own Men of the Deeps (MOD) choir have been travelling the world as Canadian Ambassadors, singing and story-telling their way into audiences' hearts. That's why, in 2016, we hope to proudly celebrate the choir's success with an anniversary event. The MOD have spent 50 years delivering moving and emotional performances on large and small stages; 50 years giving us a sense of what life was like as a miner in our mining communities; 50 years of preserving and presenting to the world in song, some of our rich Cape Breton folklore and culture.



 

The Men of the Deeps have toured throughout Canada and most of the United States. They have had opportunities to connect with audiences in the People’s Republic of China and even Kosovo in the former Republic of Yugoslavia ( at the request of Canada’s Department of Foreign Affairs, where they performed in a gala festival organized by actress Vanessa Redgrave on behalf of the United Nations Children’s Fund). The choir has also been as far north as the Ekati diamond mines in the Northwest Territories, and as far south as Arizona, Alabama, Florida and the Appalachian coal mining communities of Kentucky, Virginia and Pennsylvania. The group was even invited to perform in Las Vegas at the international MineExpo conference, where sold out audiences enjoyed its unique blend of songs and stories for six consecutive nights. These larger tours are accompanied by regular Miner's Museum Tuesday night performances and the many festivals and events they're invited to attend. 


Today the Men of the Deeps are so much more than a singing group - they are a social institution. The camaraderie amongst the members carries over to their audiences wherever they perform, pulling show-goers to their feet, time and time again; making those who aren't home, homesick and those who are home, proud. 

To be a member of the MOD, you must have served a minimum of two years in the mine. Each of the members have earned the right to wear their signature coveralls. Clad in those coveralls and hard hats, they make an impressive impact when they enter a concert hall in total darkness with only the lamps on their helmets for light. 

THE SAVOY THEATRE - SOME HISTORY

In 2015, the Savoy Theatre entered its 88th year of providing cultural entertainment to Cape Breton Island. Established in 1927, the Savoy Theatre first opened as a live performance venue and hosted acts of every kind until the mid 1950's when it became a movie theatre.  By the early 1970's the Savoy had fallen into a state of disrepair and was refurbished by the Town of Glace Bay. The Savoy Theatre reopened its doors in 1976 as "Cape Breton's Entertainment Show Place." 

Today, the Savoy Theatre plays an essential role in the local community, providing an opportunity for residents and visitors alike to enjoy a great diversity of entertainment. From community Remembrance Day services to debut recitals of young local dancers, the Savoy presents and produces over 150 events per year and admits more than 30,000 people annually. 

The majority of Savoy performers are Cape Breton artists, many of whom got their start at the Savoy.  We have been honoured to have the best of the best at the Savoy including Rita MacNeil,  Men of the Deeps, The Barra MacNeils, J.P. Cormier, The Rankin Family, Ashley MacIssac and Natalie MacMaster. The Savoy Theatre also attracts national and international performers, some of which include Blue Rodeo, kd Lang, Ron James, Serena Ryder, The White Stripes, Gerry Dee, Tommy Hunter, Stompin' Tom Connors, Melissa Etheridge  and Leonard Cohen.

The Savoy Theatre returned to its musical theatre roots in 2013 with a major community theatre production of Les Miserables:


The production was a resounding success and also served as a testament to the wealth of talent that we have on Cape Breton Island. This production led to further Savoy Theatre-produced shows such as Chicago, Into the Woods, Disney's Little Mermaid JR., The Cape Breton Tenors, The Cape Breton Summertime Revue -The Next Generation and The Sound of Music (November 2015). 

(Scene from the May 2014 Savoy Theatre production of Chicago  - Photo: David MacVicar)

Over the past five years, the Savoy Theatre has made many essential repairs such as facade restoration and a new roof (Phase 1).  Phase 2 will include repairs to our heating systems as well as further facade restoration. The Savoy Theatre raises funds through ongoing community fundraising campaigns and grants. However, we are now broadening our appeal in order to secure funding for urgent and necessary upgrades to our sound system.  As our old equipment degrades, we have had to rent systems for our major musical productions and concerts.  Having our own system in place will allow us to save money and do so much more. 

These upgrades will provide the basic components of a modernized system allowing the Savoy to continue to produce quality entertainment. 

THE MEN OF THE DEEPS & THE SAVOY THEATRE: A RICH HISTORY

The Men of the Deeps have been a part of many of the Savoy's fundraising campaigns over the years. Volunteering their time to appear on stage with Cape Breton's First Lady of Song - Rita MacNeil, the Men of the Deeps have also performed at the Savoy in countless concerts. The Men of the Deeps have contributed a great deal to the Savoy Theatre.  And now, we come together again to raise funds that will go towards the Men of the Deeps' 50th anniversary gala and enable the Savoy Theatre to upgrade its sound equipment for the 2016 Season!



YOUR SUPPORT IS APPRECIATED

We need your help. The Men of the Deeps and the Savoy Theatre are both  not-for-profit organizations. Money raised for the Men of the Deeps 50th year and the Savoy Theatre  will ensure this iconic group is celebrated with a 50th Anniversary Gala Event and Commemorative CD with the help of a modernized Savoy sound system. 

Please consider helping us to reach our goal. The choir has made us proud on hundreds of occasions. Let's support them and the Savoy  by celebrating their continued commitment and success. Our goal is $50,000. Every dollar counts and your donation could earn you a free gift.

UPDATES - TWO RECENT ARTICLES ON OUR CAMPAIGN!

"Joining Together" From The Cape Breton Post Nov 6 2015

"A Deep Connection" The Cape Breton Post November 6th 2015

story:
Myth Keeper: A True Story

Katharine Scarborough's intimate and brave semi-autobiographical piece will be making its world premiere at The Brick in Williamsburg, December 29th, 2015 through January 9th, 2016. Developed in residency with Mabou Mines, and successfully workshopped at Dixon Place in May, 2015, we are so excited to be presenting a fully realized production to New York audiences. 

Myth Keeper is a play that explores the mythology of a southern family through monologue, neo-fairytales, and a father's jailhouse correspondence. Truly unique in execution, it's part Alice in Wonderland, part documentary theatre, part comedy, and finally, part family tragedy.   

How Your Support Will Help Us

https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=13539

All tax-deductible donations will support the execution and promotions of the production:

  • Compensation for all artists and designers involved in this production, including lighting and set designers, stage manager, technicians, our director and actors, and more!
  • Rental of rehearsal space.
  • Rental of the theatre space.
  • Set, costume, and lighting to build upon our previous workshop production and increase production values.
  • Marketing and advertising costs to reach a much wider audience.  

A Father Incarcerated  

In 2012, Katharine's father, Doctor Charles Scarborough's medical license was revoked, and he was arrested for 821 counts of insurance fraud. Held on half a billion dollars' bail, and at 77 years old, his family thought he would spend the rest of his life behind bars. 

Not the first crisis the Scarborough family had endured, Katharine realized her unorthodox and often comical upbringing was innately theatrical. Utilizing 25 years of correspondence from her Dad, family legends, stories from her childhood, and southern mythology, Katharine and her team have created a theatre experience like no other! 

This production explores the criminal justice system, family dysfunction, and a daughter's deep love and respect for her misanthropic father.    

Bringing a Family Crisis to the Stage

This project is composed of several layers of realities, jumping between past and present, realistic dialogue and fantastic style, mythology and fairytale. The production will require heightened technical elements and design expertise to take you on this adventure! And we can only do it with your generous contribution!  

Donations, Come See Us, Share on Social Media

Along with whatever you're able to donate, please help us spread the word on Facebook, and we'd love to see you at the production! 

Get tickets here! https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/953650

Check us out at the Brick website here!http://bricktheater.com?type=show&id=1224

Follow us, like us, and spread the word on Facebook here! www.facebook.com/mythkeepernyc

story_txt:
Myth Keeper: A True Story Katharine Scarborough's intimate and brave semi-autobiographical piece will be making its world premiere at The Brick in Williamsburg, December 29th, 2015 through January 9th, 2016. Developed in residency with Mabou Mines, and successfully workshopped at Dixon Place in May, 2015, we are so excited to be presenting a fully realized production to New York audiences. 
Myth Keeper is a play that explores the mythology of a southern family through monologue, neo-fairytales, and a father's jailhouse correspondence. Truly unique in execution, it's part Alice in Wonderland, part documentary theatre, part comedy, and finally, part family tragedy.      How Your Support Will Help Us https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=13539
All tax-deductible donations will support the execution and promotions of the production:


Compensation for all artists and designers involved in this production, including lighting and set designers, stage manager, technicians, our director and actors, and more!
Rental of rehearsal space.
Rental of the theatre space.
Set, costume, and lighting to build upon our previous workshop production and increase production values.
Marketing and advertising costs to reach a much wider audience.  

    A Father Incarcerated   In 2012, Katharine's father, Doctor Charles Scarborough's medical license was revoked, and he was arrested for 821 counts of insurance fraud. Held on half a billion dollars' bail, and at 77 years old, his family thought he would spend the rest of his life behind bars. 
Not the first crisis the Scarborough family had endured, Katharine realized her unorthodox and often comical upbringing was innately theatrical. Utilizing 25 years of correspondence from her Dad, family legends, stories from her childhood, and southern mythology, Katharine and her team have created a theatre experience like no other! 
This production explores the criminal justice system, family dysfunction, and a daughter's deep love and respect for her misanthropic father.    
    Bringing a Family Crisis to the Stage This project is composed of several layers of realities, jumping between past and present, realistic dialogue and fantastic style, mythology and fairytale. The production will require heightened technical elements and design expertise to take you on this adventure! And we can only do it with your generous contribution!  
    Donations, Come See Us, Share on Social Media Along with whatever you're able to donate, please help us spread the word on Facebook, and we'd love to see you at the production! 
Get tickets here! https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/953650
Check us out at the Brick website here!http://bricktheater.com?type=show&id=1224
Follow us, like us, and spread the word on Facebook here! www.facebook.com/mythkeepernyc

story:
We are Faceache Theatre 

An ambitious grassroots theatre company, established in 2011, that tours collaboratively devised work to non-traditional theatre spaces around London. The plays are forward thinking, community focused and design to reflect and unite the multi-cultural society we live in .

Knipe Point 

Based on a true story about Scarborough based artist Kane Cunningham. 
He bought a house at the edge of a cliff condemned to fall to the sea. With a desire to get the community involved he had the idea to have people post their secrets and confessions to the house that would plummet off the edge of the cliff with it. Close to its demise the house crumbled with the weight of secrets before the council stepped in to scupper Cunningham's plans. 

Come and watch as this artist deals the weight of hundreds of secrets while trying to manage his own. 

Aims and Objectives

  • To provide more regular access to the arts in Tower Hamlets in East London
  • To build a stronger network of producing performing artists in East London
  • To encourage more artists to collaborate across medium. (theatre, art, dance, design, photography, video... etc.)

The Production 

Venue: Bow Arts Nunnery Gallery, Tower Hamlets
Date: 1st, 2nd, 3rd April 2016
Time: 7.30
Tickets: £10 (£8 concession)
 

Ethos and Code of Conduct 

Faceache endeavours to create theatre that offers an invitation for everyone:
  • Embrace and entertain the multi-cultural society we live in
  • Ticket prices to suit every budget
  • Opportunities to get involved 
  • Workshops for young people
  • Post show Q and A sessions
  • Social media competitions 
We are:
  • Advocates of #EqualOpportunity, 
  • Friends of #ActorAwareness, 
  • Activist for #BameActors 
  • Vocal about #FairPay
  • Supporters of #EmergingArtists
  • And aim to keep our company squeaky clean and GREEN!

What We Need What 

We are looking for £2,500 to pay for:
  • Venue overhead costs
  • Actor and Crew fees
  • Van Hire
  • Insurance 
  • Promotional material
  • Merchandise

We're made up of a core team of experienced professionals:
Andrew McPherson - Founder and Co-artistic Director
Trained at East 15 Acting School, Andrew has built an excellent reputation as an innovative director, facilitator and playwright. His continuing work with the Stephen Joseph Theatre, Churchill Theatre and the African Cultural Association has given him the space and time to develop his practice with fierce ambition and constant inspiration with the love and support of reputable establishments.
Sofia Calmicova - Co-artistic Director
A World Performance graduate from East 15 Acting School, originating from Maldova. Sofia's eye for the absurd, the weird and the wonderful ensures Faceache's shows are unlike anything you've seen before. Benefiting from training in Maldova, Germany, the USA and London, Sofia is a creative powerhouse and a force to be reckoned with.
Daniela Fleckenstein - Marketing and Creative Brand Strategist
An exquisite photographer, marketing director and brand strategist from Germany. Daniela's experience business mind, combined with a wild sense of creativity makes her an essential and much loved part of the team. 
Ernest Aquah - Music and Sound 
Music is an essential part of Faceache's work and Ernest Aquah keeps us with our fingers firmly on the pulse of nuanced and creative sound that elevates and uplifts our work. 
Mark Richards - IT Coordinator. 
The ultimate tech-man. Mark keeps Faceache Theatre up to date and on trend with the latest Apps, technology and social media strategies.
