hemos vencido y celebrado. Una y mil veces. Y es que ya no estamos tan chicos,
tenemos entre 30 y 40 años. 
“La humilde dinamita” es una obra de teatro que cuenta la historia de
Jonás, un chico reclutado por su propia hermana para ser parte de una columna
terrorista. La obra relata la transformación de Jonás, de su triste timidez
hacia una explosiva agresividad. Jonás camina por todas las etapas de la
guerra, vinculándose con diversos personajes: militares, civiles, políticos y seres metafísicos… La obra es una oportunidad para escuchar a cada uno de los personajes y comprender sus posturas, las razones que cada uno tuvo, para optar por la violencia. 
La historia es dramática pero no hemos podido huir del humor. Hemos creado un texto intenso aunque enfocado de forma lúdica (no somos fans del dramón). Además nos encanta mezclar lenguajes, así que teatro, video, danza, lucha y música, todo irá junto.
Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes

Necesitamos s/.42,000  o  $14,000 
Ese dinero es para cubrir todos los gastos que cuesta poner la obra en escena. Escenografía, Vestuario, Musicalización, Realización de video, Iluminación, Arte Gráfico, Traslados, Coreografía, Seguros, Sala de ensayos etc etc etc. 
Lo interesante de aportar en este proyecto, es que tu apoyo será milimétricamente sustentado ante Sunat (entidad que fiscaliza los tributos en Perú). LA HUMILDE DINAMITA se realiza bajo la razón social Asociación Teatro Veloz (asociación cultural sin fines de lucro en la que cada ingreso y egreso debe estar registrado). Y si algo sobrara (dificil pero posible), ese dinero debe reinvertirse en la Asociación. Si por ejemplo, sobraran s/.1000, podemos ofrecer una beca para que alguien de escasos recursos entre gratuitamente a los talleres que dictamos.
Entonces, todo tu dinero será utilizado formalmente y con transparencia (:
IMPACTO  

Todo lo que sale del forro impacta. Y más si vamos a contar una parte dura de la historia del Perú. Y más, si es una historia con la que cualquier ciudadano del mundo podría identificarse. Y más si la obra busca respuestas a la violencia humana… Y más si las llegamos a encontrar! Y más aún si las podemos compartir con un público! Y más si alguito llega a cambiar. 
Tal vez solo movamos un centímentro a la montaña, pero la moveremos. Y  de cm en cm avanza el mundo.
Estrenamos en Lima (¡El 4 de mayo del 2016!), pero luego llevaremos la obra por toda América. Queremos contar lo que pasó en el Perú y compartir nuestras reflexiones con países que también tengan problemas de violencia... (Y quién no los tiene...). Desde siempre nos ha gustado movernos y llevar nuestras creaciones por todo el continente.

story:
"Hero Worship is a must for every comic fan” – Theatre in Scotland

Hi everyone, I’m Kenny Boyle and last year I went on an adventure. I decided to write a play. That in itself wasn’t really a big milestone for me; I’ve written a few plays in my time. But this one was different. This was a story I’d been waiting to tell ever since I first put pen to paper (or fingers to keyboard) to write drama. I just hadn’t been brave enough. And this time I wasn’t going to be content with doing a production of a few days in one venue… I was going to take it on tour. Because when you make something important you want as many people to see it as possible…

But I’m getting ahead of myself. You might know nothing about me! It’d be rude of me to go on without some kind of introduction. So here goes:

I’ve been producing plays since 2010, most notably the return of Still Game to the stage in the Tron Theatre and the Ayr Gaiety.
Two of my plays “Forever” and “We Never Land” have been to the Fringe before.
I’m a graduate of the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland and have the odd pleasure of holding a master’s degree in acting.
And you can find out a whole heap more about me at kennyboyle.co.uk.

“Filled with pop culture references, everyone is bound to find something they can relate to but the piece is as easily digestible by those who can’t separate Superman from Batman.” – The Public Reviews

So, back to our tale. Ultimately the play I wrote was called Hero Worship, a play absolutely packed full of pop culture references about all our favourite superheroes or heroines. If you don’t think you like theatre but absolutely adore The Avengers, or Deadpool, or Batman then this play will have you doing the whole emotional gamut from knowing smirks to outright belly-laughing to sad nostalgia for simpler times spent reading comics and not worrying about the world outside - rumbling away behind your bedroom curtain. But it was more than that…

“Inhabits the inner world of generation superhero with a creative passion and humanity that’s hard to resist.” – The Scotsman

Generation Superhero… that’s us. This generation who are devoted even more than any before us to men in tights and robot fights and the fantastic fantasy world of the comic book. And why wouldn’t we be? Our generation grew up full of hope that we would be able to achieve so much and belief that if we worked hard we’d be able to accomplish the things our parents did. In actual fact our poor fragile economy belly-flopped and left us all hopelessly searching for a job and wondering why all the doors around us seemed to suddenly be closing.

We’re a generation of underdogs who just wish we had superpowers. Something to make us special.

And those are the perfect ingredients for our arch nemesia:

Anxiety.
Depression.
Hopelessness.

And that’s what Hero Worship is really about, recapturing that spirit of belief in ourselves and the tenacity that we lost somewhere along the way. It’s here to raise awareness of these mental health issues but also to offer some insight into how we might manage them if we have them.

And the target market is young people from age 10 all the way up to slightly less young people in their late twenties or, hey, early thirties.

Because you’re never too young to be reminded that your worth isn’t in a job title or salary, you’re so much more than that. You have a super power, you’re incredible at something, and that’s what gives you worth.

And you’re never too old to be reminded of it either.

“This play was really inspiring; it reminds you that there is a Superhero in everyone. “ – Eden Court audience member, age 15

I took Hero Worship on tour around Scotland out of my own pocket and it cleaned me out! But it was worth it. Particularly when it was clear it had had an impact on people.

But there’s so much more good it can do.

And that’s where you come in.

Hero Worship has been offered a spot in C Venues for nine days at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, which is a spectacular opportunity for it to reach a huge and international audience. But the costs are much more than I can manage to raise alone.

Your contribution could make the all the difference. At some point mental health issues touch us all… even those we may sometimes think are too young to suffer from them.

And this is just another step along the road of bringing those issues out into the open and talking about them.

“Sometimes all we need to be a hero is our empathy, and our sensitivity to those who depend on us.” – The Outlier

What We Need & What You Get

So, as you may or may not know, the cost of bringing a show to the Fringe, even for a short run, is almost ridiculously high. But this particular fund raising campaign is for two things

The first – the cost of the actual venue itself. Performing in CNova for nine days will cost  £1300 and of course without the venue hire cost the show, sadly, can’t go on.

The second – advertising. Obviously there’s no point putting on a show if you don’t have flyers, posters or any other kind of advertising. Particularly not during the fringe when there are thousands of other shows competing for people’s attention. So for advertising the aim is a  modest £300, which will allow for a reasonable amount of flyers to be printed for distribution and also posters to be displayed in the venue and its sister venues. The remaining £400 will go towards paying crew such as a sound and lighting operator.

Sadly, because of limitations and restrictions put in place by the venue – I can’t offer tickets as perks! What I can offer however are these:

-  A professionally printed copy of the Fringe script for Hero Worship: perfect bound and glossy covered, this script will look right at home on your book shelf.

-  A professionally printed copy of the extended script for Hero Worship: full of additional or extended scenes, poems and commentary.

-  A professionally printed copy of the ultimate script for Hero Worship: featuring the extended script and also “An idiot’s guide to becoming a Super Villain” – a how to guide to villainy from the writer of Hero Worship.

-  Every single backer will also receive special thanks in the program for making Hero Worship a reality.

If the project doesn’t reach its goal – then what ever I HAVE raised will go towards the cost of the show and I’ll try my luck raising the funds by some other means. I’m determined so hopefully life will find a way!

If the project surpasses its goal any additional funds raised will be used for additional marketing, a street team and inclusion in the Fringe brochure.

The Impact

A big part of the play is about having fun. It will (and has) entertain audiences whether they are massive comic book geeks (like me) or have never picked up a comic in their life. It’s a heartfelt and funny look into the massive pop culture phenomenon that is the superhero genre.

But the impact, the payoff, is reaching young adults or people in their twenties with the message that talking about mental health problems like anxiety and depression is perfectly healthy and normal and could very well help. My hope is that this play will start discussions and banish some of the stigma that surrounds the idea of mental health issues. If one young person in one audience comes forward and tells someone that they’ve been suffering and been afraid to talk about it… well then the play will have been well worth it, because that first step could change that young person’s life. If it reaches even more, then even better. The impact could be huge. I hope it is. But it can only happen with your contribution.

As a producer, I have a very strong track record! My previous productions have received critical acclaim and the tour of Hero Worship picked up a bag full of four and five star reviews all of which you can read here: HeroWorshipPlay.com

As well as a great many audience reviews from young audience members at all the venues which I place even more value in as it shows the play reached the people it was meant to. Sometimes in very moving ways.

“Still have this show replaying through my head. Both funny and thoughtful” – message from Eden Court audience member a week after the show. Age 14.

Risks & Challenges

Of course, with any creative endeavor there are risks. I may not raise the funds, which would most likely result in the loss of a deposit of hundreds of pounds and the show not being seen at the fringe. The advertising may not successfully draw in audiences. The show could clash with other popular shows in nearby venues and audience numbers could be harmed. At the Edinburgh Fringe there are hundreds of possible problems.

But I’m not new to this. As I said two of my shows have been to the Fringe before and I’ve performed in the Fringe for three years running. I have a good amount of knowledge in how to navigate many of the festival’s common pit falls. The biggest hurdle to Hero Worship is raising this initial £2000. Everything after that is just a matter of experience!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute financially. I get that!  But that doesn't mean you can't help: please share this campaign. Get the word out! Not only if you’d love to see a play about superheroes and how they have become a massive part of our culture, but also if you’re passionate, as I am, about spreading awareness about anxiety and depression and opening the dialogue that might change a young person’s life.

And that's all there is to it!

story:
Short Summary

We will be performing the play in Los Angeles, CA. at the Stephanie Feury Studio Theater and  in Edinburgh, UK. in the Nightclub at The Gilded Balloon.

LA Performance Dates: July 21st at 8pm, July 22nd at 8pm, July 23rd at 8pm, July 24th at 2pm

Edinburgh Performance Dates: August 3rd-28th at 12:10pm

Less than 33% of plays produced in the USA and UK are directed by women. Less than 20% are written by women. Fewer than 10% are produced by women. Make a difference: join us in putting women's voices front and center on stage, and help us create paid opportunities for professional women in theater.

"Out of Our Father's House" features the stories of seven American women, drawn from their letters, stories, and diaries. Supported by an all female crew and Director Marya Mazor, the actors bring to the stage stories and voices that have been lost for generations. Help us bring this production back to the stage in Los Angeles and Edinburgh.

What We Need & What You Get

Your support pays the cast and crew, and covers costs of four shows in Los Angeles and twenty-five in Edinburgh. In return for helping support a portion of the $60,000 needed to mount this production, you can receive:

  • Credit - at our highest levels, you will be recognized for creating opportunities for women and women's voices in theater, both in Los Angeles and the UK.
  • Exclusive Access - meet the crew, have drinks with cast, and dinner with the producers.
  • Memories - see the show live and take home a signed and personalized poster.

The Impact

The percentage of plays produced by women on Broadway has stayed at a meager 12% since its inception. The biggest qualification for women to be chosen as theater directors remains "found your own company." Without your support, this will not change. Join us in providing twelve paid positions for female theater professionals. Help us put the voices and stories of women on stage, front and center. With your support, we can make a difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out. Connect donors and foundations. Bring this production to schools, colleges, and universities. Tweet us on twitter, tag/share on facebook, and follow us on snapchat and instagram #OOFH

The Future and Beyond

Red Compass Productions is dedicated to bringing unique and untold stories to the stage and screen. Your donations will help us to produce more shows, promote diversity on the stage, and continue to give opportunities to professional theater women. Find us at www.redcompassproductions.com, on Facebook, and on Twitter.

story:
Our Campaign

We are Some Kind of Theatre, an Edinburgh-based theatre company.  We are fundraising for our first ever show, a steampunk production of William Shakespeare's The Tempest which will be performed at this year's Edinburgh Fringe (6th-15th August, Sportsters, 8-9pm).  

But we don't just want to perform at the Fringe: we are hoping to tour the show around living rooms, gardens, offices, care homes, and hospices in Edinburgh and the Lothians in order to bring the Fringe Festival and the Shakespeare 400 celebrations to those who aren't able to access theatre in traditional venues.  In order to do this, we need to fundraise enough money to cover travel expenses, publicity, and the cost of building a transportable set.  It will also allow us to keep the cost of performances down, allowing us to offer tickets for the lowest possible price to vulnerable audience members.

 

How Your Donations Help:

  • Every donation, no matter how small, is greatly appreciated and will help us bring the show to new audiences.
  • We're really grateful to our supporters and so are proud to be able to offer a range of fantastic perks to donors and will also be including all donors' names in the show programme.
  • If our campaign is successful, we intend to start touring a 'Shakespeare on the Sofa' show around Edinburgh and the Lothians every year, with the aim to extend our tour to include the whole of Scotland in future years.
  • If we exceed our fundraising target by more than 50%, we can also offer some completely free performances to local hospices.

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you aren't able to contribute to our campaign, you can still help!

  • Please spread the word and let your network know about our campaign.
  • Come and see us at the Edinburgh Fringe, or book us to perform in your home and invite friends and family who can't normally go to the theatre.
  • If you are a business owner, consider sponsoring us or allowing us to display a poster at your business.
  • Follow us on Twitter and like us on Facebook.

 

Thank you!

Some Kind of Theatre

story:
Hattie..."What I Need You to Know!"

Directed by: Byron Nora

Written by: Vickilyn Reynolds

Music & Lyrics by: Vickilyn Reynolds

Stage Manager: Alyssa Champos

Costumes by: Kevin Mayes   

Costumer: Mylette Nora

Wigs by: Sheila Dorn

Vickilyn Reynolds, actress, singer, writer, composer, lyricist and producer born and raised in Philadelphia moved to Los Angeles by way of New York in 1988. Off the heels of her successful run in George C Wolfe's "Colored Museum." Vickilyn has garnered many nominations and awards for her portrayal  of Hattie McDaniel.   It was Vickilyn's brother Ron Richardson, (Tony Award winner) and good friend Larry Riley ( A Soldiers Story) before passing away told her to portray Hattie McDaniel.  After their passing she considered their suggestion and wrote a one woman musical based on Hattie McDaniel's life. Taken seven years to complete, the book and ten songs.  To date Vickilyn has 50 + performances along with great reviews, many awards and wonderful accolades. She is now embarking on a sixteen city tour, starting in Philadelphia in March, 2017.

Hattie...What I Need You to Know! is Vickilyn's purpose although she found herself prejudice towards Hattie McDaniel as being a discredit to the race and all she portrayed were mammy and maid roles. (What else could she have played in 1939.) Upon her research Vickilyn found Hattie McDaniel to not only be a fighter for civil rights but as well housing rights. Hattie McDaniel fought for actors, the chance to become a Sidney Poitier, a Denzel Washington, a Hallie Berry and a Vickilyn Reynolds. After her awakening to who Hattie McDaniel was Vickilyn says, "there is no mistake I resemble Hattie McDaniel so much...it's like my destiny." She said "I don't want this tour to be a success for me I want it more for "Hattie McDaniel" she is so deserving of her story being told on stage and screen."  

Vickilyn Reynolds has been  on a journey  with "Hattie McDaniel." She can use a little help to  complete her destiny.  With your contributions it will help with deposits for venues, airfare, hotel and  other production costs and will be greatly appreciated.  

Vickilyn's quote: "On this journey I have been robbed of money and equipment, lied on, cheated, talked about, mistreated, butte, scorned, talked about, sure as your born, up down leveled to the ground."  "But I got Jesus!"  Thank you to those that can and will help! To those who can't if you know the worth of prayer please pray her success.

If goal is not reached contributors funds will be used towards original purpose.

Please visit :   www.hattiewhatineedyoutoknow.com
story_txt:
Hattie..."What I Need You to Know!"
Directed by: Byron Nora
Written by: Vickilyn Reynolds
Music & Lyrics by: Vickilyn Reynolds
Stage Manager: Alyssa Champos
Costumes by: Kevin Mayes   
Costumer: Mylette Nora
Wigs by: Sheila Dorn
Vickilyn Reynolds, actress, singer, writer, composer, lyricist and producer born and raised in Philadelphia moved to Los Angeles by way of New York in 1988. Off the heels of her successful run in George C Wolfe's "Colored Museum." Vickilyn has garnered many nominations and awards for her portrayal  of Hattie McDaniel.   It was Vickilyn's brother Ron Richardson, (Tony Award winner) and good friend Larry Riley ( A Soldiers Story) before passing away told her to portray Hattie McDaniel.  After their passing she considered their suggestion and wrote a one woman musical based on Hattie McDaniel's life. Taken seven years to complete, the book and ten songs.  To date Vickilyn has 50 + performances along with great reviews, many awards and wonderful accolades. She is now embarking on a sixteen city tour, starting in Philadelphia in March, 2017.
Hattie...What I Need You to Know! is Vickilyn's purpose although she found herself prejudice towards Hattie McDaniel as being a discredit to the race and all she portrayed were mammy and maid roles. (What else could she have played in 1939.) Upon her research Vickilyn found Hattie McDaniel to not only be a fighter for civil rights but as well housing rights. Hattie McDaniel fought for actors, the chance to become a Sidney Poitier, a Denzel Washington, a Hallie Berry and a Vickilyn Reynolds. After her awakening to who Hattie McDaniel was Vickilyn says, "there is no mistake I resemble Hattie McDaniel so much...it's like my destiny." story:
IRT presents

Wandering Bark Theatre Company's

Hedda (Gabler)

 

IN RESIDENCE: September 20- October 10, 2016

PERFORMANCES: Sep. 23-25, 27-30 Oct. 1-2, 4-8 2016
TIME: Tuesday- Saturdays 8pm, Sundays 3pm
At IRT: 154 Christopher st. NYC #3B (third floor)

Ibsen’s simmering, shimmering tale of a woman too large for her destiny gets a fresh adaptation, streamlined into a gilded juggernaut of secrecy and manipulation. Wandering Bark creates a collision of past and present to build a Hedda where the story’s the same, but the devil’s in the details.

Hedda Tesman (née Gabler) has everything, but wants none of it. Sealed in the coffin of a big house, a convenient marriage to a boring husband, and a dead-end existence as a woman in a man's world, Hedda can do nothing but dream and decay. But when an old flame flickers back under her palm, her hungry heart ignites a blaze of lust, deceit, and manipulation that could consume more lives than just her own.

Directed by Joseph Mitchell Parks                     Adapted by Matt Minnicino

Choreography by Brad Landers         

Scenic & Lighting Design by David McQuillen Robertson

Costume Design by Jason Frey                       Sound Design by Kevin Novinsky

Assistant Sound Designer  Jordan Antonucci

Stage Manager   Lyndsey Barratt

Produced by Jack Sharkey

Featuring

Quinn Franzen*     Terence MacSweeny*     Kathleen Marsh*  

Valerie Redd*     Kyle Schaefer*     Susanna Stahlmann*        

*indicates member AEA

 

WANDERING BARK THEATRE CO. is a New York City based group founded in 2011, dedicated to exploring and adapting classical theatre, highlighting the universality of its themes with bold and experimental productions, often incorporating live music, multi-media design, original text, and stylized physicality. http://wandering-bark.org/ 

IRT THEATER is a grassroots laboratory for independent theater and performance in New York City, providing space and support to a new generation of artists. Tucked away in the old Archive Building in Greenwich Village, IRT’s mission is to build a community of emerging and established artists by creating a home for the development and presentation of new work.

Every donation we receive will go directly to fund production costs.

DESIGN BUDGETS (set, props, lights, sound and costume)

MARKETING EXPENSES

ARTIST COMPENSATION

wandering-bark.org

adaptinghedda.tumblr.com

facebook.com/wanderingbark/

JOSEPH MITCHELL PARKS (Director/Co-Artistic Director) New York Theatre credits include: Titus Andronicus (New York Shakespeare Exchange), Short Life of Trouble, The Seagull, Othello (Wandering Bark Theatre Company), Much Ado About Nothing (Secret Theatre), King Lear, Henry IV, A Midsummer Night’s Dream (Shakespeare NYC), The Soldier Dreams (Theatre East). U/S National Tour of Romeo and Juliet (The Acting Company). Selected Film and Television credits include: The Sonnet Project (#115), Gossip Girl, Blood Night and North Crossing. Company member of Theatre East and Shakespeare NYC. Member AEA. Associate Producer for The Acting Company.

VALERIE REDD (Hedda/Co-Artistic Director) New York Theatre credits include: The Tooth of Crime (Columbia Stages), Richard III (Shakespeare in the Parking Lot), Christopher Marlowe’s Chloroform Dreams (Lunar Energy), Eye of God (Theatre East), Short Life of Trouble, The Seagull, Othello (Wandering Bark Theatre Company). Regional Theatre credits include: All My Sons, A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Metamorphoses, You Can’t Take it With You (Mary Moody Northen Theatre). London Theatre: La Dispute (London Soho Theatre and Edinburgh Fringe). Film credits: Nouvelle York,  Shaking. Writing credits: Othello (Adapter), Short Life of Trouble (Creator/Writer/Adapter), The Witches (Writer/Adapter). Valerie made her directorial debut with The Witches.  Member AEA. Training: St. Edward’s University B.A. Theatre Arts (Physical/Devised Theatre), Masters Level/ Postgraduate Classical Acting at The London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art. VALERIEREDD.COM

MATT MINNICINO is a playwright, actor, teacher, and theatre-maker. His words have been spoken at HERE Arts Center, The Pershing Square Signature Center, Theater for the New City, The Flea, Dixon Place, The Cell, The Bushwick Starr, Cloud City, The 14th Street Y, The Tank, and site-specific venues throughout New York City; his plays have been also performed at universities and schools in Virginia, New York, DC, North Carolina, and Colorado, and in the New York, Shenandoah, and New Orleans Fringe Festivals. He is artistically associated with Brooklyn’s Exquisite Corpse Company, Artilliers, Underling Productions, Cradle Theatre, Bicephaly Pictures, and is a frequent actor with Easy Leap and Reckless Bard Productions. He is a teaching artist with the American Shakespeare Center in Staunton, VA, mentors undergraduate playwrights at Columbia University, and has had articles published by HowlRound and The Dramatist. MFA: Columbia.

story:
Help us get Hang up to the Edinburgh Fringe

  • It took actual blood, sweat and tears but Tiannah, Jessica and Kim have graduated from The Poor School and are now working together to bring an exciting play to the Edinburgh Fringe this summer - Hang by debbie tucker green.
  • Fresh out of Drama School all 3 of us are broke but we are also determined to succeed.  So we are working hard to not only perform in, but also produce, the entire production ourselves. 
  • Performing at Edinburgh will give us all an opportunity to showcase our talent to the industry and share all of our hard work with you.
  • Please help us to kickstart this project and launch our acting careers with a bang.
  • We are really proud to be doing this on our own but have realised that we are in desperate need of a little support along the way.  

What We Need to fork out for

All 3 of us are working hard at our day jobs to fund most of the project ourselves and are not looking to make a profit from this experience.   However, any funds we are lucky enough to raise will go towards: 

  • Purchasing the rights:  we have been given permission to perform the play for a long run (26 performances) which is amazing but at £75 plus vat per performance rights don't come cheap.
  • Venue Hire: We have managed to secure a performance slot at C Venues in Edinburgh and having a London Preview at the Lost Theatre are which we are really excited about.  Just need to pay those hefty deposit fees now. 
  • Accommodation: prices in Edinburgh are known to sky rocket during the festival.  At the moment we can afford a shoe box each.
  • Food: After all that lot we'll be lucky if we can cough up for a haggis between us. Size zero is so 2000 and late, so please help us eat. 
  • Travel: with props and costume we are all probably going to drive up to Scotland so a bit of petrol money would be a great way to start.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please do help us spread the word.  The more support and bums on seats the better so feel free to like, share etc to your hearts content.
  • Please also follow us on Twitter @hang_EdFringe for production updates. 
  • Apparently you can also use the Indiegogo share tools! Simples!

story:
It is envisaged that the project lasts 10 months. During this time, our students will learn to dance various dances (salsa, bachata, merengue...), to go to parties with us and be part of public appearances.

After 10 months, we will be ready to share our experiences with all the dance schools and institutions that are interested in it. Because this is the fastest way to expand this story and enable blind people around the world to be able to dance and be part of the community.

Funds raised for this project cover marking equipment rooms with special colors that visually impaired people can most easily see, the equipment for the promotion and monitoring of the project, the cost of transport to the shows, the cost of consulting associates, hiring three instructors of salsa.

Participants:

  • Boban - salsa instructor and author of the project, Jelena - salsa instructor and student of the Faculty of Special Education and Rehabilitation, Milica - salsa instructor,
  • Professional staff from the Faculty of Special Education and Rehabilitation in Belgrade - -  Doc. dr Aleksandra Grbović i Doc. dr Sanja Dimovski,
  • Volunteers.

The project is supported by:

  • White Cane Association, Belgrade,
  • Association for the Blind and Visually Impaired, Belgrade,
  • City Municipality Zemun, Belgrade.

The development of the project, progress of our students as well as the dynamics of spending funds can be followed on our site: http://salsa.rs/home/thedancedoesnotgoblind

-------------------------------------------

Predviđeno je da projekat traje 10 meseci. Za to vreme naši učenici će učiti da plešu  razne plesove (salsu, bachata-u, merengue...), ići sa nama na žurke i biti deo javnih nastupa.

Nakon 10 meseci, bićemo spremni da naša iskustva podelimo sa svim plesnim školama i institucijama koje za to budu zainteresovane. Zato što ćemo tako najbrže proširiti ovu priču i omogućiti slepim ljudima širom sveta da mogu da plešu i budu deo zajednice.

Sredstva prikupljena za ovaj projekat pokrivaju opremu za  obeležavanje prostorija specijalnim bojama, koje slabovide osobe mogu najlakše da vide, opremu za promociju i praćenje projekta, troškove transporta na nastupe, troškove za konsultovanje stručnih saradnika, angažovanje tri instruktora salse.

Učesnici:

  •  Boban - instruktor salse i autor projekta, Jelena – instruktor salse i student na Fakultetu za specijalnu edukaciju i rehabilitaciju, Milica - instruktor salse,
  •  Stručni saradnici sa Fakulteta za specijalnu edukaciju i rehabilitaciju -  Doc. dr Aleksandra Grbović i Doc. dr Sanja Dimovski
  •  Volonteri.

Projekat su podržali:

  • Udruženje Beli štap iz Beograda,
  • Savez slepih i slabovidih iz Beograda,
  • Gradska opština Zemun, Beograd.

Razvoj projekta, napredak naših učenika kao i dinamiku potrošnje sredstava možete da pratite na našem sajtu : http://salsa.rs/home/plesnijeslep

story:
Unstoppable: We Won’t Let Terrorism Slow Us Down - You can help!

Despite the threats, ongoing violence and a society destabilized by ISIS – Iraqi hip hop crews have been working for years with American Voices’ YES Academy programs to build peace, bring smiles, and to create bonds across borders and ethnic and religious lines.

The Baghdad Karada bombing took one of Iraq’s great dance talents and one of the YES Academy family. But you can help the community regroup and rebuild by bringing renowned hip hop dance teacher B-boy Stringz from Detroit to provide free training, room and board to over 30 young Iraqi talents from across the nation. Stringz will lead the choreography of new work in honor of Adel as well as coach the hip hop community to move beyond grief and find their resolve.

  • American Voices is one of the United States' most established cultural diplomacy and engagement organizations. We have provided free intensive summer music, dance and theater programs in Iraq, Lebanon, Sudan and beyond since 2007.
  • The dancers and Stringz will create a new work in Adel's honor as well as hone their b-boying skills and develop a plan for moving the dance community forward in the wake of this tragedy. 
  • The First Step Crew and other Iraqi and Kurdish crews do amazing work for hip hop culture in one of the planet's most inhospitable environments for dance. These young dancers provide a beautiful model for inter-ethnic and inter-religious cultural and social co-operation in a region where the national discussion is sorely lacking in such models. They promote their message regularly through media appearances and public performances. Your contribution will help keep their important work in the national dialog and make some brave and talented young dancers feel more connected to the international hip hop community.

What We Need & What You Get

  • The program expenses include transporting 6 dancers from Basra and Baghdad to the safe working environment of Erbil, Kurdistan, feeding and housing them for 11 days and bringing Bboy Stringz from Detroit to Erbil to lead the program. We have a donated dance space which will allow the dancers to work comfortably. 
  • We will provide regular photo and video updates via our Facebook page YESAcademyKurdistan and First Step Crew. In addition, we will arrange a Skype and Facebook Live-Streamed and Hip Hop Town Hall meeting with all contributors. We will also Live Stream the public concert on August 31!

story:
Short Summary

obra anaïs is a META-nominated theatre ensemble comprised of multidisciplinary artists whose primary discipline is live performance. They use linguistic and gestural material alongside textual interpretation to offer both performer and spectator theatrical experiences that are not tied solely to character and plot but also seek to investigate broader issues. They strive to juxtapose the visceral and the conceptual; in walking this line they oscillate between intimate interaction and moments of theatrical distancing. obra anaïs has been working since November 2015 on bringing contemporary aesthetics to the Montreal theatre scene, with a particular focus on technologically integrated performance.

This October, obra anaïs will present its latest theatre production, an experimental and feminist adaptation of Schiller’s MARY STUART. Mary Stuart tells the drama of the Queen of Scots’ imprisonment and execution under the reign of Elizabeth I, surrounded by the men of Elizabeth’s court and their lust for control. But the goal of this production exceeds historical representation. Anthony Kennedy who has worked as a director both for Listed Theatre in London as well as independent productions in Montreal facilitates the ensemble in crafting a multi-disciplinary feast for the senses, using Schiller’s material as a platform from which to begin exploring themes of toxic masculinity and self-curation. With your contribution, obra anaïs will be able to realize a professional standard of theatre making and cultural work.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $2000 to help primarily with the rental costs of Studio Jean-Valcourt. As an emerging company of artists it is important for us to take greater risks, in this case by opting to perform in a fully equipped and professional theatre that offers access to both French and English Montreal audiences.

Funding will also go towards purchasing materials for set, props and costumes. To give you an idea of the world we are creating: Darah Miah’s set design will be an evolving, almost living environment of furniture pieces, hanging fabrics and chains. Sophie El-Assaad’s costumes will make a hybrid of Elizabethan fashion and the contemporary haute couture. Finally, the video design will be a composition of found footage and living paintings playing on traditions such as the late Renaissance Vanitas.


Finally, we have been working for hundreds of combined hours on this project since August, all voluntarily. We believe artists, as persons engaged in creating and challenging culture, should be recognized for their work - in a very real sense, this means being paid for said work.


That being said, if we don’t reach our entire goal of $2000, the funds will go towards renting the space, which is our number one priority. As previously stated, our main goal is to have the opportunity to produce compelling work and to share it with our audiences, thus hopefully creating meaningful and enriching conversations between people.
 

The Impact

obra anaïs has been working since November 2015, and most of the team has collaborated on projects as early as 2013. In May 2015, obra anaïs created Confiteor [vol ii], an immersive production which has been nominated for five Montreal English Theatre Awards, including Outstanding Emerging Ensemble and Outstanding Set Design. In contributing to this campaign, you are supporting new, innovative art that seeks to connect Montreal’s English theatre to ongoing trends in the French-language Quebecois and European theatre scenes. You are supporting hard-working, socially conscious artists who are passionate by the act of looking at the world differently and collaboratively, through art.

Risks & Challenges

The main challenge involved in our work is doing it voluntarily. As we are not supported by an established theatre, we must, on top of spending time in rehearsals, create our own advertising and outreach campaigns, and take serious financial risks.

To be certain, everyone involved in the project has at least 5 years of experience in their given trade, and this is not our first independent production. We’ve developed marketing and outreach skills along the way, and the designers have worked and volunteered in production shops, at least owning the skills and understanding, if not the most high-end equipment, to get all building tasks done.

Ultimately: we are resilient and passionate enough to put all of our extra time and effort towards creating this project. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute and we of course understand that! Nonetheless, every little penny, nudge, like, share and shoutout helps! Other ways you can contribute to our project are simply by spreading the word in your community about this campaign or sharing the Mary Stuart Facebook event https://www.facebook.com/events/946440598836158/ on your page. Finally, the best way to show your support would be to come to our show! We’re looking forward to meeting you and thanking you in person, Oct 21-30 at Studio Jean-Valcourt du Conservatoire (4750 Henri-Julien, Montreal).


For more information about the show:
Mary Stuart will run at Studio Jean-Valcourt  Oct 21, 22, 26, 27, 28, 29 at 8PM and Oct 22, 23, 29, 30 at 2PM. Tickets are sold at $21.50 (student/senior/industry discount) and $26.50 (general) by phone (514-873-4031, ext 313) or at the door. You can also buy them online at http://www.admission.com/ 


Learn more at https://www.facebook.com/obra.anais/ and at www.obraanais.com

They strive to juxtapose the visceral and the conceptual; in walking this line they oscillate between intimate interaction and moments of theatrical distancing. obra anaïs has been working since November 2015 on bringing contemporary aesthetics to the Montreal theatre scene, with a particular focus on technologically integrated performance.This October, obra anaïs will present its latest theatre production, an experimental and feminist adaptation of Schiller’s MARY STUART. Mary Stuart tells the drama of the Queen of Scots’ imprisonment and execution under the reign of Elizabeth I, surrounded by the men of Elizabeth’s court and their lust for control. But the goal of this production exceeds historical representation. Anthony Kennedy who has worked as a director both for Listed Theatre in London as well as independent productions in Montreal facilitates the ensemble in crafting a multi-disciplinary feast for the senses, using Schiller’s material as a platform from which to begin exploring themes of toxic masculinity and self-curation. story:
What Are We Doing?

A devastatingly touching look at pressures of society, the exuberance of youth, and the power of defiance in the face of petty grudges and yearning for love in Tieline Theater's production of “Romeo and Juliet.”

by William Shakespeare 

Directed by Drew Scott

Presented on Town Center Park’s Rotary Pavilion in Hamden, CT*

Friday, June 24 at 7:00 P.M.

Saturday, June 25 at 2:00 P.M. and 7:00 P.M.

Sunday, June 26 at 2:00 P.M.

Admission: FREE**

*Rain location: TBD

**If you’d like to support us going forward, we do take donations to “Free Will!”

Cast:

  • Romeo - Michael Pray
  • Juliet - Julianne McGourty
  • Mercutio, Lady Capulet - Jess Otterbine 
  • Tybalt, Friar Lawrence - Joshua Dill
  • Lord Capulet - Sean Gardell 
  • Nurse - Elise D'Avella
  • Benvolio/Paris - Alec Farquarson

What Is Tieline Theater?

As alumni of the Quinnipiac University Theater department, there's a tradition we hold dear that's been upheld since its inception. After performing in their first mainstage show all newcomers receive a piece of tie line, presented to them by the veterans of the department.  This tie line is a symbol of inviting them wholeheartedly into the theater family called the "D-Lites" or "Drama Lites" (but we'll save the origin of that D-Lite-ful name for another time).

The piece of tie line has come to represent many things since the tradition started, and though its origins are somewhat blurred, the strongest image is one of unity and bonds. Much like how tie line holds together a theater set; students and alumni of the department are all held together and connected by their experience and the powerful work they've done, no matter where they are.

We have incorporated this idea of being connected into the very core of our performace. "It's like you and your scene partner are attached by a million tiny strings, so everything each of you does directly influences the other." (Timothy Cochran: Professor of Communication and Theater, Holyoke Community College) We want to connect with each other, with other students and performers from near and far, with the audience, and with the community as a whole. 

And so, our goal is to raise awareness of the area's artistic potential.

This project is being used as the cornerstone for future endeavors; including full-length summer shows and workshops. We wish to bring theater to the community and enhance the local arts culture.

What We Need & What You Get

Our campaign last year was able to bring in over $1,300! It helped us tremendously, but we were definitely down to the wire on a lot of things. We're confident we can do even better this year with your help and create an experience that'll leave an everlasting impression on our audiences to come! Here's what your donations will go toward supporting:

  • Housing and food for tech week and performances
  • Posters, flyers, and other miscellaneous publicity
  • Transportation (gas and train fare)
  • Costumes and props
  • Future workshops and endeavors just like this!

As a result, we'll be able to provide:

  • An amazing tale of action, tragedy, and love!
  • Some very fun and unique rewards building off of what we offered last year including a private video link of the performance, behind the scenes footage, and more!
  • Further progress in laying a groundwork to provide this kind of experience for years to come!

The Impact

The goal of Quinnipiac's theater department has always been "Theater for Community," and having come from that very place, that's something we passionately believe in. But that community is both internal and external. By supporting us, you'll not only be strengthening the campus/alumni theater community and the theater community at large, but also extending the Quinnipiac/Hamden theater community beyond the confines of the school year in a location that's ripe for artistic endeavors. We genuinely feel that this project will leave a lasting impression with everyone involved and will not only challenge and bring the cast together, but strengthen the ties between the community and the art that can flourish within it. If theater hadn't been such an important part of our lives, we wouldn't be doing this. If we didn't think that doing great theater that engages the community was important and could enrich people's lives, we wouldn't be doing this. We want to give back to a school and community that's given us so much, but we need your help! And with it, we know we'll give people a unique and very entertaining experience while laying the groundwork for even greater things to come.

Other Ways You Can Help!

If you support our effort and can't contribute monetarily, never fear! Just spreading the word is an INCREDIBLE help. Tell your friends, your family, your co-workers… anyone! Even a little can go a long way, and we deeply appreciate any form of assistance you can provide.

Stay Tuned!

We'll have more exciting updates as we go along! Thanks for your support!

In The Meantime:

Check out the highlight reels of our past two shows!

-Midsummer Lovers-


-Twelfth Night-

story:
EST/LA Has Two Powerful New Plays for You!

Ensemble Studio Theater LA is an award-winning theater company dedicated to creating and producing provocative, entertaining new plays. This fall we have two terrific ones: The Princes of Kings Road by Tom Lazarus and Watching OJ by David McMillan. 

The Princes of Kings Road brings legendary architects Richard Neutra and Rudolph Schindler together on stage. Based on a real life incident, the play imagines what happens when, after years of estrangement, these two icons of architecture coincidentally occupy the same hospital room at Cedars of Lebanon. The production takes place in a space designed by Richard Neutra himself, the Neutra Institute and Museum in Silver Lake and opens on September 12th. Our fabulous cast includes Ray Xifo, John Nielsen and Heather Robinson. 

Do you remember where you were when the OJ Simpson murder verdict came down? We think you might. Watching OJ follows a group of friends and co-workers as they watch the verdict in the O.J. Simpson double-murder trial, revealing racial tensions, differences of perspective and personal secrets that will change their lives forever. This thought provoking production featuring Kareem Ferguson will open at our home in the lively Atwater Village Theater complex in early October to coincide with the 20th anniversary of the historic and controversial verdict. 

We Can't Do It Without You

Developing new work takes time, money and commitment. EST/LA is an all-volunteer company. Our ticket sales pay for only part of our productions, which is why we're reaching out to you. We're looking for $20,000 and every dime will go to making these important new plays possible. 

Check out our perks and give as generously as you can. Can't donate just now? You can help by simply sharing this link on social media.

Your Donations are Fully or Partially Tax Deductible

Because EST/LA is a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit, your donations are fully or partially tax deductible. If you accept one of our perks, your donation is tax deductible minus the value of the perk. If you donate without a perk, your gift is fully tax deductible.

Most importantly, come down to the theater and enjoy these terrific new plays!

But Wait, There's More!  Scroll Down for Posters and Pics of Our Casts.

The Watching OJ poster. The iconic image of OJ Simpson is overlaid with the transcript of the verdict.

The Watching OJ cast includes Kareem Ferguson.

The poster from The Princes of Kings Road. (Yes, that's Rudolph Schindler's illustration of the proposed Neutra/Schindler commission for the League of Nations Palace in Geneva, Switzerland, unbuilt.)

John Nielsen plays Rudolph Schindler.

Ray Xifo plays Richard Neutra.

Heather Robinson plays Nurse Rothstein.

The Neutra Institute and Museum in Silverlake, designed by Richard Neutra, where the Princes of Kings Road will be staged.

story:
Who am I?

I am Mark Anthony Smith. Writer,director, and producer. I am a Master's Graduate at Cal State Northridge, where I received a Masters in Film and Television for Screenwriting. I also have my BA in Theatre from Cal Poly Pomona.

Cal Poly Pomona is where I was introduced to Moliere's work. It is also where I adopted the idea of writing a play in verse! I have been working on this play for six years. Writing a play in rhyming couplets is not easy! But, my dedication and admiration towards Moliere was well worth the hard work! My goal was to accomplish two things! Create a play that would impact an audience of today like Moliere's audience was impacted all the way back in the 1600's. His plays poked fun at hypocrisy, challenged authority, explored sexuality and questioned religion. That's exactly what this play does but in a present time kind of way. Moliere's plays shocked it's audience. And that is exactly what T.I.T.S. does! I am proud of this production and I am very excited for what this play can be! With your help we can put this unique look at theatre on stage!


WHO ARE WE? What makes this play so special is the amazing cast! Here are a few cast members who have been here since the very beginning!


SUMMER STRATTON will be playing Frank Jones. This amazing actress will be taking on the challenge of playing a dude. Summer Stratton was a part of the last one-act production of T.I.T.S. in 2012, and loved her experience so much that she's back for more. 

Isabella Figueres, a Costa Rican born actress now taking on the challenge of playing Mary, a dominatrix lesbian! It's gonna be hot! Isabella Figueres has been in the United States for almost five years now. She is an extremely motivated and passionate actress who left her home country Costa Rica to pursue acting in the United States! She's come a long way and I am thrilled to have her in the cast.


Noel Jason Scott, a horror film fanatic and amazing film actor in general will be playing the father Walter Jones! Noel Jason Scott is a successful film actor who does theater for the love of it! Not only is he a passionate actor and father, but he is also a huge supporter of my work and I am excited to work with him once again!


Joanna Mercedes Hernandez will be taking on the difficult task of playing Sister Salacious, a nun with a potty mouth. Joanna Hernandez is not only an extremely gifted comedic actress, but her passion and dedication to my work has been a huge impact on myself as an artist, I am very thrilled to be working with her on this project and I know her talents will be a great reward for the audience.


Taylor Stone will be playing Shelly. He'll take on the task of playing a woman, and not just any woman, but a major bitch! Taylor Stone is not only a close friend, but another amazing actor who is a huge believer in this project!  

Not only will Lindsey Whitener be composing music for the show, but she'll also be playing Connie Jones. The only female Jones sibling. Lindsey Whitener has been working on projects with me since she was in her teens. Now a woman, and a gifted actress, we are blessed to have her on board. She is not only a great actress, but also a talented musician who has composed music for all my work, including this campaign video.

AND A FEW OF OUR NEW ACTORS

Tommy Franco is taking part in his first production. He'll take on the task of playing Jimmy Jones, the bastard child. 

Ann-Marie Lariccia is also a new wonderful addition to the cast and will take on the  role that influenced the writing of this play-- Eva Jones. The mother with attitude, strength and lots of heart!

Vanessa Toyama is the newest addition to the cast and will be taking on the role of French Canadian Whore! She is a graduate at Cal Poly Pomona with a B.A. in Theatre and will be working with me for the first time! Excited to have her on board!





Short Summary
This play has been in the works for six years! The play started off on my quest to create a piece based on my Aunt Nine-- she pretty much embodies the Jones Family. A vulgar, emotional, outspoken, so honest it hurts, ready to kick some ass if you cross her family in any way kind of person! But beyond that craziness was a person with a big heart! But what was once a short twenty minute one act play in pros at Citrus College about a dysfunctional family and is now a full length Rhyming Couplets play about a lot more than just dysfunction, but is a play that'll force the audience to challenge the ideas that this world is based on and will also force audiences to laugh at it as well!

Here's a little something about our play.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need 2,500 to do this show justice. With hiring a good crew to light us, costume us, and a stage manager to lead us into a great production. Our goal is to put this show up in Hollywood.
  • Contributing to this campaign will allow you to be a part of an ongoing process that has taken six long years. We are offering shirts, tickets, and much more for your help. Just a twenty five dollar donation will do so much for us. So please help support struggling hungry artist.
  • If we reach our goal, we will be able to put up a week long run in a comfortable space in North Hollywood. We will be able to put up a professional show!
  • Our tech crew is the most important aspect of this show. With out a good tech crew, this show will not go smoothly. As my actors do this show for the love and passion of theater, the crew must get paid in order to run a professional show! With your donations, even small donations-- they'll add up to a wonderful budget to put on a kick ass show! 

The Impact

  • The best part of putting this production together is the amazing cast! Especially with the actors that have been here from the very start! These passionate actors will be arriving to rehearsal, filling up their tanks, eating easy mac, and hopefully afford a six pack of PBR after a long rehearsal-- they do this all for the love of theatre. But, after the show is done and we actually finish the run, they'll be paid for their hard work with ticket sale profits. But the show must go up first to get rewarded for their hard work. 
  • This is a show that has started off at nothing. While most believe that putting up a professional show is impossible with out a huge production budget and large scale theatre group,.. this production will happen with your help. Your impact is crucial!

Risks & Challenges

  • This show has been through developmental hell in the past. I'd say it's due to my lack in trust in myself. While we've gone through many producers, finally I have decided to take this on myself. As my first produced professional staged show, I have ten trusting actors who are following me every step of the way. We have battled so many obstacles and are still here ready to put this show up! With a little help from the people around us-- our goal can come true!
  • As producer, I am going to have a one week run of two shows, with a full tech crew supporting the production, in an amazing theater space set up in a safe place. I intend on sharing the profits with all my actors, and I hope to give an audience an amazing show. With the success of this show, I also plan on putting up more productions! Thanks for all your help!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • SHARE, SHARE, SHARE, SHARE, and TALK, TALK, TALK, AND TALK! Spread the word. Share our posts. Tell your best friends!
  • PLEASE SHARE on every social network! Contact us and help out in person!

And that's all there is to it.

Moliere's plays shocked it's audience. And that is exactly what T.I.T.S. does! I am proud of this production and I am very excited for what this play can be! With your help we can put this unique look at theatre on stage!  

WHO ARE WE? What makes this play so special is the amazing cast! Here are a few cast members who have been here since the very beginning!SUMMER STRATTON will be playing Frank Jones. This amazing actress will be taking on the challenge of playing a dude. Summer Stratton was a part of the last one-act production of T.I.T.S. in
 2012, and loved her experience so much that she's back for more.  
Isabella Figueres, a Costa Rican born actress now taking on the challenge of playing Mary, a dominatrix lesbian! It's gonna be hot! Isabella Figueres has been in the United States for almost five years 
now. She is an extremely motivated and passionate actress who left her 
home country Costa Rica to pursue acting in the United States! She's come a long 
way and I am thrilled to have her in the cast. 


Noel Jason Scott, a horror film fanatic and amazing film actor in general will be playing the father Walter Jones! Noel Jason Scott is a successful film actor who does theater for the
 love of it! Not only is he a passionate actor and father, but he is 
also a huge supporter of my work and I am excited to work with him once 
again! 


Joanna Mercedes Hernandez will be taking on the difficult task of playing Sister Salacious, a nun with a potty mouth. Joanna Hernandez is not only an extremely gifted comedic actress, but 
her passion and dedication to my work has been a huge impact on myself 
as an artist, I am very thrilled to be working with her on this 
project and I know her talents will be a great reward for the audience. 


Taylor Stone will be playing Shelly. He'll take on the task of playing a woman, and not just any woman, but a major bitch! Taylor Stone is not only a close friend, but another amazing actor who is a huge believer in this project!   

Not only will Lindsey Whitener be composing music for the show, but she'll also be playing Connie Jones. The only female Jones sibling. Lindsey Whitener has been working on projects with me since she was 
in her teens. Now a woman, and a gifted actress, we are blessed to have 
her on board. She is not only a great actress, but also a talented 
musician who has composed music for all my work, including this campaign
 video. 

AND A FEW OF OUR NEW ACTORS
Tommy Franco is taking part in his first production. He'll take on the task of playing Jimmy Jones, the bastard child.  


Ann-Marie Lariccia is also a new wonderful addition to the cast and will take on the  role that influenced the writing of this play-- Eva Jones. The mother with attitude, strength and lots of heart! 


Vanessa Toyama is the newest addition to the cast and will be taking on the role of French Canadian Whore! She is a graduate at Cal Poly Pomona with a B.A. in Theatre and will be working with me for the first time! Excited to have her on board! 


Short SummaryThis play has been in the works for six years! The play started off on my quest to create a piece based on my Aunt Nine-- she pretty much embodies the Jones Family. A vulgar, emotional, outspoken, so honest it hurts, ready to kick some ass if you cross her family in any way kind of person! But beyond that craziness was a person with a big heart! But what was once a short twenty minute one act play in pros at Citrus College about a dysfunctional family and is now a full length Rhyming Couplets play about a lot more than just dysfunction, but is a play that'll force the audience to challenge the ideas that this world is based on and will also force audiences to laugh at it as well! Here's a little something about our play. 
  What We Need & What You Get  We need 2,500 to do this show justice. With hiring a good crew to light us, costume us, and a stage manager to lead us into a great production. Our goal is to put this show up in Hollywood. 
 Contributing to this campaign will allow you to be a part of an ongoing process that has taken six long years. We are offering shirts, tickets, and much more for your help. Just a twenty five dollar donation will do so much for us. So please help support struggling hungry artist. 
 If we reach our goal, we will be able to put up a week long run in a comfortable space in North Hollywood. We will be able to put up a professional show!
Our tech crew is the most important aspect of this show. With out a good tech crew, this show will not go smoothly. As my actors do this show for the love and passion of theater, the crew must get paid in order to run a professional show! With your donations, even small donations-- they'll add up to a wonderful budget to put on a kick ass show!  
    The Impact  The best part of putting this production together is the amazing cast! Especially with the actors that have been here from the very start! These passionate actors will be arriving to rehearsal, filling up their tanks, eating easy mac, and hopefully afford a six pack of PBR after a long rehearsal-- they do this all for the love of theatre. But, after the show is done and we actually finish the run, they'll be paid for their hard work with ticket sale profits. But the show must go up first to get rewarded for their hard work.  

This is a show that has started off at nothing. While most believe that putting up a professional show is impossible with out a huge production budget and large scale theatre group,.. this production will happen with your help. Your impact is crucial! 
    Risks & Challenges    This show has been through developmental hell in the past. I'd say it's due to my lack in trust in myself. While we've gone through many producers, finally I have decided to take this on myself. As my first produced professional staged show, I have ten trusting actors who are following me every step of the way. We have battled so many obstacles and are still here ready to put this show up! With a little help from the people around us-- our goal can come true! 
 As producer, I am going to have a one week run of two shows, with a full tech crew supporting the production, in an amazing theater space set up in a safe place. I intend on sharing the profits with all my actors, and I hope to give an audience an amazing show. With the success of this show, I also plan on putting up more productions! Thanks for all your help!    Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:  SHARE, SHARE, SHARE, SHARE, and TALK, TALK, TALK, AND TALK! Spread the word. Share our posts. Tell your best friends! 
 PLEASE SHARE on every social network! Contact us and help out in person! 
   And that's all there is to it.

story:
Burning Man: The Musical is a new satirical musical about the collision of Silicon Valley and Burning Man. We've released our opening track to Burning Man: The Musical, and now we need your help to fund the creation of the next two songs. We're developing this new musical a couple songs at a time, and we're publishing content from it on YouTube.

What We Need & What You Get

Based on our experiences creating and filming the opening track, we need your help to fund the following:

  • Finish writing the lyrics to the 2 songs.
  • Compose new music and record it with theater actors in NYC.
  • Film a "making of" video and publish it by Burning Man (August, 2016).
  • Reach Goal: Release "A Burning Mixtape" featuring recordings of half the music from the new musical.

What you get by backing this project:

  • 2 new songs from Burning Man: The Musical
  • Cool perks!
  • Good karma for supporting new theater!
  • If you give above a certain level, you can even be in the video!

End Goal & Challenges

Our end goal is to produce a full-length musical similar in spirit as The Book of Mormon, however, that is a multi-year process. We're currently developing the musical in bite-sized chunks, creating one or two songs at a time and releasing them to YouTube. We're using our fans as our way to workshop and test each song in the musical and see what the response is.

We've learned a lot over the last 6 months creating and filming the opening number, and through that process, we've assembled a fantastic team: writer, composer, director, production manager, film crew, and talented actors, singers, and veteran Burners! We're using the lessons we've learned in producing the opening number to successfully write, record, and film the next two songs over the next 6 months. We've developed our budget and timeline based on our experience creating the first video.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share the first video with your friends.
  • Like us on Facebook, or follow us on Twitter, Instagram, or YouTube.
  • Please visit http://burningmanthemusical.com to learn more.

We'll be sharing more details about the next 2 songs in the musical in the coming weeks. If you want to get involved with the production, email us at burningmanthemusical@gmail.com.

story:
Short Summary

An Epidemic Play is a play that was written during a senior year of high school playwrighting class at The Lehigh Valley Charter High School for the Performing Arts in Bethlehem, PA. I, Tristan J. Shuler, supported by my high school classmates and teachers, was luckily able to produce this as a 25minute play just before graduating high school at the annual New Play Festival. This festival was 100% produced, designed, written, directed, and acted by STUDENTS. Yes, students. Now, years later, the play has developed over the course of time, yet maintained almost every element it had when it was created in that playwrighting class.

Emerging Artists Theatre in NYC has chosen An Epidemic Play to be a part of its New Works Series, in which the play is workshopped and produced for a one night performance in an Off-Broadway theater.

I wrote this play when I was 16 years old. I was in the peak of my senior year of high school angst, and though I didn't know it at the time, a pretty intense year of depression. The day An Epidemic Play performed for the first time in its 25minute form, it was clear that I finally felt 100% expressed and hopeful and optimistic. It was like I was a new person, burden lifted. When I moved to NYC at age 17, I knew that the play was special and meant so much to me, but had no idea that it could possibly go further and this story could be heard by many more people.

Donations towards An Epidemic Play will benefit the ENTIRETY of the production. All actors, designers, and directors are working on the show for free, and its funding proves necessary. In just one week, I have spent $200 on just casting, finding rehearsal spaces, and printing materials. Every dollar donated can make this production a reality, and add to the collaboration that An Epidemic Play truly has always been and will continue to be.


What We Need & What You Get

  • All donations are going directly towards the play's funding. This includes rehearsal space rentals, costuming & props, set building, and marketing materials.
  • All donors can receive some sick nasty gifts from the cast and production team, including shout outs in our program, on our website, complimentary tickets to our show on October 25th, and our utmost love and appreciation!


Other Ways You Can Help

Buy tickets to An Epidemic Play on Sunday, October 25th at 9:00pm! $10 tickets to come :)

Spread the word! Anything helps from facebook shares to tweets to hashtagging #embracetheepidemic. Promo posters and videos will be out each week to share and get your friends and family to come, donate, and support! The message of the show is extremely moving, and the help from all of you is even more.

story:
The Crack Cocaine Project

'It’s just one hunger, one hunger, one hunger, and that’s how it goes…’ – gambling addict

Fixed Odds Betting Terminals, also known as roulette machines or FOB-Ts have been dubbed ‘the crack cocaine of gambling’ thanks to their highly addictive nature.

With stories gathered from all over the country this piece gives a unique insight into the betting shop industry and the lives of people blighted by the fastest growing addiction in the UK.

“This machine thing, is ridiculous. It’s a epidemic, trust me.” – shop manager

This fourth draft comes after eight months spent interviewing gamblers, addicts and their families, shop staff, non-gamblers, campaigners, MPs, psychologists, industry leaders, CEOs, and attending a parliamentary inquiry.

This story is happening now. I am still in contact with the people who have told me their stories and their circumstances are constantly changing.

'We NEED to have a discussion about gambling in this country, because it's become. So. Normalised...' - Gambling addict

This play needs to be seen as soon as possible to catch the zeitgeist of government beguiled by big business, predatory capitalism unleashed, and the vulnerable fleeced and ignored.

Big money vs the little guy. The story of our time.

“Nature abhors a vacuum. I think that’s fundamentally it. It’s either you fill it with people and love and connection or you fill it with fuckin shit and addiction…” – ex-gambler

Crack Cocaine gives the audience a chance to peel back the shop front and hear stories from the high street bookie, a world hidden in plain view. It’s a social-issues play, but more importantly it’s a play about the fundamental struggle we all face- our addictions.

'Addicts are not aliens. That's absolutely the fundamental thing. They're not different... they need love and compassion and support, just like most human beings... and they're trying. They're trying to get better. Being an addict is not fun.' - Marc Lewis, PhD. Neuroscientist, addiction expert and ex-addict.

 

 - According to Action On Addiction, gambling addiction is the fastest growing addiction in the UK.

- A study by Politzer suggests “problem gamblers negatively affect 10 to 17 people significantly in their lives”

- UK Gambling Prevalence Survey in 2010 that suggested that the number of ‘at risk gamblers’ stood at around 3 million- this was seven years ago...

 

About Audacity

Audacity Theatre Company is a brand-new organisation set up by Patrick Tolan. The company is dedicated to bringing about social change through theatre that tells stories from overlooked or ignored voices in society.

Back in 2013 I helped co-found New Mutiny Theatre Company, run by passionate practising professionals to create thought-provoking and exhilarating classical theatre experiences for family audiences.

In the past year Audacity has collected over 40 hours of interviews from around the country. From betting shops to boardrooms, from Westminster to the high street: the whole range of relevant views and opinions has been sought. That wealth of material has then been painstakingly edited into scenes and sequences forming a logical, emotionally engaging story arc and then precisely transcribed into a ninety-minute script.

I launched Audacity this year having worked as an actor for three years and appearing in London Road on its second ever run at the Bristol Old Vic, then in the consequent film in 2015. My imagination was caught by the verbatim style and how it could be crafted into something spectacular when combined with other forms.

In December 2016, Audacity held its first research and development. Five directors attended including: Hal Chambers (Tucked In), Andrew Whyment (Squint), Anna Simpson (Quintessence), Chloe Mashiter (Headlong) and Sinead O'Callaghan. This spurred the project forward onto a more polished draft which is now ripe and ready for development.

The Team

Hal Chambers - Director - Most recently he has directed work for Les Enfant Terribles, Eastern Angles, Company of Angles, York Theatre Royal, Seabright Productions, Soho Theatre, Polka Theatre, RBL Theatre Company, and Greenwich Theatre.

Gareth Taylor - Choreographer - is a creative associate at Curious Directive who produce innovative work that explores life through the findings of science.

Jim Hustwit - Composer -composer, producer and songwriter, scoring for theatre, television and film. He received the Peoples Music Award in 2010.

Max Johns - Designer - is a recipient of a BBC Performing Arts Fellowship in 2015. Recent work includes productions at Bristol Old Vic and West Yorkshire Playhouse.

Jo Walker - Sound Designer- is a multi-instrumentalist and specialises in devised work. His recent works include: Erik Satie - Faction by Alistair McGowan, and Pioneer by curious directive.

Actors are currently being approached to make up the cast.

 

What We Need

Brass tacks:

  • We need to pay for 9 creatives' time for two weeks. For context, Equity minimum for actors is around £450 a week. Whether we can pay this kind of minimum to all our team depends on how much we can raise.
  • Other costs also need covering like insurance, expenses for research visits from two ex-gambling addicts and campaigners, logistics, set, etc.
  • Credits and and special thank you's in all our future programmes for all donators!
  • We have private donations and funding in kind amounting to around £2,600. Our budget currently stands at nearly £6,600.
  • If we fail to reach our goal we will evenly distribute what funds we do have amoung the cast and creative team to cover their costs and pay them as well as possible.

The Impact

This piece is an urgent and crucial examination of gambling culture in the UK. Addiction as an issue is gaining more and more spotlight in the public discourse -as it should- but too often the focus is solely on subtance abuse and alcoholism. Behavioural addictions are often ignored or belittled as deserving of less support. Gambling is so normalised in our society that any discussion of protecting vulnerable people from its pitfalls go largely unheard against the cacophony of advertising and promotion, as bookies chase huge profits.

Crack Cocaine doesn't do a wash on this issue. The CEO of the Association of British Bookmakers, the ex-chairman of Paddy Power, and a pro-gambling MP all feature in the play and offer their arguments for the status-quo. The result, when put against the stories of gamblers, shop staff, and gambler's families, is an honest and important debate.

This piece also presents a fresh and inspiring take on addiction that could genuinely help people struggling with addiction in their lives.

What we have a the moment is a full-length verbatim script which makes for a fascinating staged documentary. But in order to have the biggest impact this must be developed into an exhilerating and enthralling theatrical experience for paying audiences. This is why we are bringing together music, set and sound design, and choreography to create a unique and compelling storytelling style to complement the existing material.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Spread the word and make some noise on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram
  • Use the Indigogo share tools for easy sharing

Thank you for your time and consideration. I hope you can help us make this important project happen!

Patrick Tolan,

Audacity Theatre Company.

story:
Mission Statement:

ARTrelief™ is dedicated to using and promoting the use of all forms of art to support health, joy, awareness, development, education, social-economical adjustment, cultural inclusion, equality, dignity and integrity in the community. It is dedicated to including low income individuals, individuals with disabilities and individuals suffering from chronic illness, as well as their families. It acknowledges cultural and religious freedom, tolerance and diversity as positive values in our society.

At ARTrelief™, we strive to make our services easily accessible by anyone. We approach health as a work of art. We believe health is a practice, a continuum where our mind, body and spirit strive to achieve balance, flow, harmony, transparency, generosity, connectedness and wholeness. We believe that people have the right for immediate relief when in crisis, that relief needs to result in making people feel empowered, and that information and resources belong to the public.

New floors for low cost dance/movement

classes and workshops, for all ages and all abilities:

Having a Movement and Dance floor which can be accessible to all people is very important to us, and we welcome people from all walks of life. The space is currently carpeted and it is used for:

  • Community play space
  • Dance and movement space
  • Yoga
  • Music therapy groups for adults with developmental disabilities
  • Theatre improvisation workshops
  • Expressive arts workshops
  • Birthday parties

 We want to be able to offer more Dance/Movement classes for all ages and all abilities, and stay close to our mission to keep costs low so it can be inclusive to all people. Our current rates vary from $6 a day to $15 per hour, depending on the offering, averaging at an $8 per hour rate.

We need $5,000 to be able to raise the current cement floors (which are not safe for joints), and replace the carpet finish in our movement room with a smooth wood floor, safer for walkers, sliders, crawlers and wheelers. A small part of the funds raised will also be used to expand the movement space, and create shelving to store props and toys. 

Any leftover funds will go towards purchasing new gross motor material, bolsters and yoga props.

Ways You Can Help

  • Contribute
  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!
