It acknowledges cultural and religious freedom, tolerance and diversity as positive values in our society.
At ARTrelief™, we strive to make our services easily accessible by anyone. We approach health as a work of art. We believe health is a practice, a continuum where our mind, body and spirit strive to achieve balance, flow, harmony, transparency, generosity, connectedness and wholeness. We believe that people have the right for immediate relief when in crisis, that relief needs to result in making people feel empowered, and that information and resources belong to the public.
New floors for low cost dance/movement 
classes and workshops, for all ages and all abilities:
Having a Movement and Dance floor which can be accessible to all people is very important to us, and we welcome people from all walks of life. The space is currently carpeted and it is used for:

Community play space
Dance and movement space
Yoga
Music therapy groups for adults with developmental disabilities
Theatre improvisation workshops
Expressive arts workshops
Birthday parties

 We want to be able to offer more Dance/Movement classes for all ages and all abilities, and stay close to our mission to keep costs low so it can be inclusive to all people. Our current rates vary from $6 a day to $15 per hour, depending on the offering, averaging at an $8 per hour rate.
We need $5,000 to be able to raise the current cement floors (which are not safe for joints), and replace the carpet finish in our movement room with a smooth wood floor, safer for walkers, sliders, crawlers and wheelers. A small part of the funds raised will also be used to expand the movement space, and create shelving to store props and toys. 
Any leftover funds will go towards purchasing new gross motor material, bolsters and yoga props.
Ways You Can Help

Contribute
Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign
Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!

story:
Kunstler, a two-person play by Jeffrey Sweet, is a portrait of the famous radical attorney, William  Kunstler, rebellious to the last as he appears as part of a guest speaker program at a law school, very aware that the young black woman introducing him isn’t thrilled with the assignment.  As he tells the dramatic stories of his key battles during the Sixties, he also finds himself defending his kind of law to this smart, critical young woman who views him as a dinosaur. 

One of the leading figures of the Chicago theatre movement, Jeffrey Sweet's plays have picked up awards from the American Theatre Critics Association as well as the Jeff Award, a Best Plays citation, and critic's choices from the NY TIMES, THE LA TIMES and THE CHICAGO TRIBUNE.  Actors who have played in his writing include Amy Morton, Alan Bates, Jon Cryer, Jill Eikenberry, Reed Birney and Jack Klugman (who appeared in THE VALUE OF NAMES in six theatres). 
 

Kunstler was written specifically for Broadway veteran Jeff McCarthy (who received terrific reviews last season as one of the leads in Southern Comfort at the Public Theater and was one of the original stars of the Tony-winning Urinetown).  Jeff is joined by Nambi E. Kelley, a leading Chicago actor-writer (she recently received raves both as the star of the Goodman’s production of Two Trains Running and for her hit adaptation of Richard Wright’s Native Son).

The director is Meagen Fay, one of the most highly-regarded alums of Chicago’s famed Second City troupe and a guest star on almost every TV show worth your time (including Mad Men and Transparent).  Kunstler was a family friend (she called him “Uncle Bill”) who collaborated with her lawyer uncle on some of his most controversial cases.  (In fact, Abbie Hoffman and Jerry Rubin crashed in the family house during the Chicago 7 trial and she had waffles with them in the morning.)

The Creative Place International, Inc. in association with ANDTheatre Company (Artistic New Directions), two non-profit theatre companies  (donations are tax-deductible) have joined forces to bring this compelling play to an off-Broadway audience.  

The Creative Place International,Inc. is a Small Professional Equity Theatre based in Saratoga Springs, New York and resident at the National Museum of Dance. The Creative Place is dedicated to developing family audiences, producing new work, and participating in international cultural exchange.  For over 30 years, New York City based ANDTheatre Company (Artistic New Directions) through its development program has provided a place for playwrights to create work through their choice of readings, workshops and improvisational exploration and has provided initial development support for Kunstler.

Kunstler has been presented twice before, once in Regional Theatre (Hudson Stage), where it was praised by the New York Times as “skillful, wise and revealing,” then as part of the New York Fringe, where Time Out dubbed it a “critic’s choice.”  (Among its fans were Mike Nichols, Sheldon Harnick, Marshall W. Mason and Tonya Pinkins, who shlepped up the stairs to a garret to see it.)  This production will continue Kunstler’s journey from Regional Theatre to Fringe Festival, Off Broadway and beyond, bringing this “gripping” (New York Theatre Review) work to a wider audience and launching it into the national repertoire so the true story of a remarkable and complex man can be shared around the country and the world!

story:
Short Summary

The World Crime League is a new Minneapolis-based theatre company devoted to staging new works with a bit of an edge. We got our start in the 2016 Minnesota Fringe Festival with Andrew Rosdail's premiere play, Writer's Block. We love theatre with dark comedic vibe and a hint of the macabre. More importantly, we want to provide a platform for up-and-coming artists to express themselves and flex their creative muscles.

What We Need & What You Get

We're not looking to make a killing on this endeavor. Producing quality theatre is expensive. It costs money to rent and use the space, build our sets, and pay the many wonderful actors and technicians who are devoting their time and energy to this project. We need all the support we can get to bring these terrifying pieces to life.

The Phoenix Theater cost us $1250.00 to rent out for the week. Additionally, we will be putting money into the set, lighting design, sound design, and stipends for the artists. The more you contribute, the more resources we'll have to devote to bringing you great theatre. 

The Impact

You have the opportunity to support local theatre. As any member of the theatre community will tell you, we're not in it for the money. We're in it for the artistic fulfillment.

There is a great need in the Minneapolis Theatre Community: The need for theatre with an element of horror. We're hoping to scare the pants off of our audience members.

While we're a young company, we have had success in theatrical productions before. Andrew Rosdail wrote, directed, and produced his original play Writer's Block in the 2016 Minnesota Fringe Festival, and the production was a huge success. Additionally, Andy Rakerd and Geoff Conklin worked together in the 2015 Minnesota Fringe Festival to bring the world premiere of Love and Persuasion  to the stage, and they were awarded an encore performance on the last day of the festival at the Rarig Xperimental Theatre. This is our first foray outside of the Fringe Festival, but with your help, we believe we can establish ourselves as a force to be reckoned with in the theatre community.

 

Risks & Challenges

The World Crime League is a team of young working professionals endeavoring to make great theatre with limited funds. We're hoping to use lights, sound, limited sets, and a little blood to bring these stories to life. We have the vision and the know-how, but we don't have the benefit of a big theatre company backing us up. With your help, we hope we can bring a professional-quality production to the stage!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Come on out to our show! It's at The Phoenix Theatre in Minneapolis from February 9-12. Tickets will be around 15 dollars, and Sunday is "Pay What You Dare Day!"
  • Like the World Crime League page on Facebook and share our posts on social media.
  • Get out and talk about us! Word of mouth is the best kind of advertisement we can get.

story:
Short Summary

Cyclamen Theatre is a group of theatre/performance-makers from Dublin, including director Sionnán Ní Nualláin and writer James Ireland. We are raising funds to tour our new work The Elephant to Fringe Arts Bath.

In July last year our friend Christy passed away.

THE ELEPHANT is a maze-like immersive theatrical experience with every performance different. It’s our story of Christy, of Gods, and of blind men trying to describe an elephant.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking €500 to fund our tour to Fringe Arts Bath, for a four-night performance run and then an extended visual arts exhibition until June 11th.

This will fund (or in the event of us not reaching our goal, part-fund) the following:

Festival registration fee and venue costs
Travel for two crew members and one actor for the duration of the performance run
Accommodation for two crew members and one actor for the duration of the performance run
Set and costume design & transportation

To thank you for your faith in us we’ve compiled a few little thank yous you can check out on the side tab if you should decide to fund us. One part of the project we’ve been very excited about is the unconventional script James has written, which includes original artwork we’ve been able to use to inform our performance decisions. So you’ve an opportunity to hold a little piece of the script we’ve been working with these past months in your hand if you should choose to donate.

We are also holding fundraisers in Dublin to help us reach our goal that you are more than welcome to attend – such as our spoken word poetry night on May the 19th at Players Theatre, which will also include a rehearsed reading of The Elephant – your first chance to see our work even before audiences in Bath!
 

Why this piece, and why now?

We feel that art needs new forms. The Elephant isn’t a conventional theatre or performance piece – it includes audience interaction where the audience decides not only how moments in the performance will go, but which parts of the puzzle in Christy’s life they will get to witness.

Storytelling in theatre is no longer enough: we want to break down the barriers and create a full expanse of experience. The things that are happening in the world are really happening and we can no longer disengage as humans. Art must begin to reflect that, we can no longer stare passively at a pretty story onstage. This felt to us like the truest way of trying to present what happened: something we felt the more we’ve tried to work on the less we actually understand.

As we continue to develop our piece through production in Fringe Arts Bath and hopefully beyond, we wish to give the audience something they can't escape taking home.

 

About the company

Cyclamen Theatre was set up in Dublin in 2013, and has successfully produced three full-scale theatre shows in Dublin (Mercury, New Theatre 2016; Fireplay, New Theatre 2015; The Dispersal of Wildflowers, White Lady Art as part of 10 Days in Dublin 2013). Our collective members have also produced work for theatre and exhibition spaces across Dublin and the UK (including Space Venues @ Edinburgh Fringe; Pleasance Theatre Edinburgh and Islington; Samuel Beckett Theatre Dublin; Smock Alley Theatre Scene & Heard and Collaborations festivals; Bram Stoker Festival Dublin; The Players Theatre and its curated festivals Shakespeare Festival, MythFest, and Celtic Twilight; The Lab on Foley Street; NCAD Graduate Exhibition).

 

And finally

If you believe in our project and are looking for more ways to contribute, you can start by sharing our content on social media and telling all your friends!

story:
All-Femme St. Joan Cast. 2017.

We’re About It

We are a collective of Chicago theatre makers committed to woke, dope art whose mission is to combine quality theatrical work with social justice. Our inaugural show is an all-femme production of St. Joan – where we examine the ways privileged women in power oppress other women via a text structured around men oppressing a woman.

We are raising money to cover the expenses of producing a play in Chicago, which includes paying for artist fees, production budgets, show rights, rehearsal and performance space, etc. Producing a show is expensive, so every single contribution, large or small, is much appreciated!

With your help, this play will reach hundreds of audience members who will be able to consider and discuss this new imagining of St. Joan. With an inclusive cast of 17 femme-identifying artists, we will be able to engage our artists and our audiences in a broader conversation about the ways in which ALL women can be supporting each other. We hope to eventually tour this show nationally and internationally to bring a femme-powered, multi colored cast to as many people as possible, and you can be a part of launching that journey!  

The Hook Up

We want to raise $8,000 to cover the following fees

  • Rehearsal and performance space 
  • Production costs (set/props, costumes, marketing, show rights, etc.)
  • Cast & creative team.

In return for your generosity, the perks you could get include:

  • A personalized "Thank You" email
  • A dope sticker
  • A program signed by the cast & creative team
  • An invitation to the final dress
  • Two (2) free tickets to a select performance of the show 
  • An invitation to one rehearsal or tech rehearsal
  • Your name in the program
  • Two (2) free tickets to opening night and the after party

Y'all Ready?

This production reflects the reality in which we are living, where feminism and women’s rights movements blatantly overlook women of different gender identities, sexual identities, colors, and sizes. We forget, or choose to ignore, the lack of intersectionality and inclusivity when it comes to the human rights all femme-identifying persons deserve. In one way, this production is a reminder that only through advocating for the voices of all women can we achieve true equality. In another way, it is a celebration, a thrilling theatrical adaptation featuring a team of artists whose inclusivity and dedication mirrors the backbone of Chicago’s theatre. 

One of our goals as a team is bringing in audiences and backers of all backgrounds in order to cultivate conversations around this play that explore questions of feminism, intersectionality and everything in between. 

We are committed to social justice through theatre, and your contribution will help!

Rise Up

This is the kind of theatre we want EVERYONE to have the opportunity to see. The inclusivity of our cast will mean little if it is not reflected back from our audiences and our community . A risk within theatre for social justice is often forgetting and/or excluding the communities we try to elevate onstage. We challenge ourselves to navigate this risk through inclusive marketing, an open invitation for dialogue on our social media, and the guarantee that no ticket will cost more than $15. 

The Hustle is Real

We know $8,000 is A LOT of money. If you can't donate - no worries! Here are other ways you can help spread the word about us and make all-femme St. Joan a success

  • SHARE: Tell your friends about us, and share this campaign on Facebook!
  • LIKE: Like us on Facebook 
  • COME: Come see the show this fall at Greenhouse Theatre in Chicago, we would love to have you in the audience! Oct 6-29, 2017!

THANKS!

--the all-femme st. joan team

story:
Part of the magic of Oscar Wilde is derived from the fact that his renowned, Gothic masterpiece, The Picture of Dorian Gray has been interpreted and staged in many ways. But here, the creators of “THE EXTRA-ORDINARY CABARET OF DORIAN GRAY”  have done something decadently different. "Dorian Gray" as you've never seen before. When we say ‘creators’, we are not just talking about writer Linnie Reedman and composer Joe Evans, but the entire cast. This has been a truly collaborative process so far, and continues to be so, as we all club together to take up a wonderful invitation to be part of this year’s Edinburgh Festival. The commitment and enthusiasm of the cast and creative team have been inspiring. And we want the process to continue.

Still reeling from the reception received from the performance at the Spiegeltent (where audience reaction includes phrases such as “hauntingly sexy”, and “insanely beautiful”) we are now in preparation for the run at the Leith Volcano – a beautiful but derelict gothic church in the heart of Leith, Edinburgh – the perfect setting for the show.

However, this is not a cheap enterprise. We at Ruby In The Dust, a nonprofit company, are counting on a successful campaign to raise money to fund the production.  Whilst the cast and creative team are all mucking in to make this work, there are still essentials that cannot be avoided before we even start on that journey.

Specifically transport and accommodation, which comprises over half of the budget for the show’s run in Edinburgh. Your help in meeting these costs will ensure the company are able to make this transfer to Edinburgh a reality. Just to reach our destination, put a roof over our cast's head and secure the venue we need £3,000 now. That is the ultimate goal - but any pledge to get us going will be in valuable - however small or large. The perks listed to the right are merely guidelines. Any amount is okay. Anything goes!

Written and directed by Linnie Reedman, the story is set in a fantasy, steampunk world, and stitched together by the narration of the sinister character of Mr Isaacs, a theatre manager who is out to get revenge on Dorian for the "murder" of his protegé Sybil Vane. The tale unfolds in a series of cabaret sketches with original music by Joe Evans, with choreography by Penelope Simons, and innovative design by Belle Mundi.

Riculously talented Rada graduate, Kit Young, takes on the role of the exotic Dorian Gray, alongside tragic love interest Sibyl Vane, played by Hero Douglas - directly related to Lord Alfred Douglas, the friend and lover of Oscar Wilde, whose father, the Marquess of Queensbury, brought about Wilde’s arrest and subsequent sentence to two years hard labour at Reading Gaol. Meanwhile Lord Alfred (who coined the phrase “the love that dare not speak its name” – often falsely attributed to Wilde) was forced into exile. The multi-talented cast also includes Lewis Rae, Joe Cushley, Christine Holman, Jo Ashe and Sophie Judd.

Ruby in the Dust was formed by director/writer Linnie Reedman and composer/musician/writer/ Joe Evans. Together, they’ve brought over a dozen productions to the stage that run the gamut from the fringe to the West End. They’ve proven their skill at integrating original and interpolated music into the text. Of Bonnie and Clyde, The Times critic wrote that it conjured a “powerful visual and musical atmosphere.”  They’ve won raves for their musical shows and because the stamp of authenticity that they place on every production is simultaneously true to its roots and boldly original, they’ve also been able to use music that already claims a steadfast audience and introduce it to new ones.  They received the blessing of the Cole Porter Estate to use several Porter compositions for their production of Hutch in 2013. But they are mainly noted for incorporating original music into their productions. Their adaptation of the F. Scott Fitzgerald classic, "The Great Gatsby"  has enjoyed three runs to date, and been developed with Royal Shakespeare Company’s director Adrian Noble. The Telegraph said of the production  that it “grips throughout.”  

This adaptation of Dorian Gray began its life as a one night gala presentation in London’s Café Royal. Just before it closed its doors for its major refurbishment, the venue was transformed to its heyday glory by taking the story back to its birthplace: staging the show, on Oscar Wilde’s birthday, in the beautiful Domino Room - which was where Wilde would hold initial readings of his works, and dine with his lovers. 

"Wildly Atmosphreci" - The Guardian

"Heady, seedy seduction" - The Times

THE CAST

 

CREATIVES:

Linnie Reedman – Writer

Joe Evans – Composer

Penelope Simons - Choreographer

James Lloyd Pegg – Associate Director

Belle Mundi – Designer
story_txt:
Part of the magic of Oscar Wilde is derived from the fact that his renowned, Gothic masterpiece, The Picture of Dorian Gray has been interpreted and staged in many ways. But here, the creators of “THE EXTRA-ORDINARY CABARET OF DORIAN GRAY”  have done something decadently different. "Dorian Gray" as you've never seen before. When we say ‘creators’, we are not just talking about writer Linnie Reedman and composer Joe Evans, but the entire cast. This has been a truly collaborative process so far, and continues to be so, as we all club together to take up a wonderful invitation to be part of this year’s Edinburgh Festival. The commitment and enthusiasm of the cast and creative team have been inspiring. And we want the process to continue.
Still reeling from the reception received from the performance at the Spiegeltent (where audience reaction includes phrases such as “hauntingly sexy”, and “insanely beautiful”) we are now in preparation for the run at the Leith Volcano – a beautiful but derelict gothic church in the heart of Leith, Edinburgh – the perfect setting for the show.
However, this is not a cheap enterprise. We at Ruby In The Dust, a nonprofit company, are counting on a successful campaign to raise money to fund the production.  Whilst the cast and creative team are all mucking in to make this work, there are still essentials that cannot be avoided before we even start on that journey.
Specifically transport and accommodation, which comprises over half of the budget for the show’s run in Edinburgh. Your help in meeting these costs will ensure the company are able to make this transfer to Edinburgh a reality. Just to reach our destination, put a roof over our cast's head and secure the venue we need £3,000 now. That is the ultimate goal - but any pledge to get us going will be in valuable - however small or large. The perks listed to the right are merely guidelines. Any amount is okay. Anything goes!
Written and directed by Linnie Reedman, the story is set in a fantasy, steampunk world, and stitched together by the narration of the sinister character of Mr Isaacs, a theatre manager who is out to get revenge on Dorian for the "murder" of his protegé Sybil Vane. The tale unfolds in a series of cabaret sketches with original music by Joe Evans, with choreography by Penelope Simons, and innovative design by Belle Mundi.
Riculously talented Rada graduate, Kit Young, takes on the role of the exotic Dorian Gray, alongside tragic love interest Sibyl Vane, played by Hero Douglas - directly related to Lord Alfred Douglas, the friend and lover of Oscar Wilde, whose father, the Marquess of Queensbury, brought about Wilde’s arrest and subsequent sentence to two years hard labour at Reading Gaol. Meanwhile Lord Alfred (who coined the phrase “the love that dare not speak its name” – often falsely attributed to Wilde) was forced into exile. The multi-talented cast also includes Lewis Rae, Joe Cushley, Christine Holman, Jo Ashe and Sophie Judd.
Ruby in the Dust was formed by director/writer Linnie Reedman and composer/musician/writer/ Joe Evans. Together, they’ve brought over a dozen productions to the stage that run the gamut from the fringe to the West End. They’ve proven their skill at integrating original and interpolated music into the text. Of Bonnie and Clyde, The Times critic wrote that it conjured a “powerful visual and musical atmosphere.”  They’ve won raves for their musical shows and because the stamp of authenticity that they place on every production is simultaneously true to its roots and boldly original, they’ve also been able to use music that already claims a steadfast audience and introduce it to new ones.  They received the blessing of the Cole Porter Estate to use several Porter compositions for their production of Hutch in 2013. But they are mainly noted for incorporating original music into their productions. Their adaptation of the F. Scott Fitzgerald classic, "The Great Gatsby"  has enjoyed three runs to date, and been developed with Royal Shakespeare Company’s director Adrian Noble. The Telegraph said of the production  that it “grips throughout.”  
This adaptation of Dorian Gray began its life as a one night gala presentation in London’s Café Royal. Just before it closed its doors for its major refurbishment, the venue was transformed to its heyday glory by taking the story back to its birthplace: staging the show, on Oscar Wilde’s birthday, in the beautiful Domino Room - which was where Wilde would hold initial readings of his works, and dine with his lovers. 
"Wildly Atmosphreci" - The Guardian
"Heady, seedy seduction" - The Times
THE CAST

 
CREATIVES:
Linnie Reedman – Writer
Joe Evans – Composer
Penelope Simons - Choreographer
James Lloyd Pegg – Associate Director
Belle Mundi – Designer

story:
Third Friday Durham Dance Series

My name is Myra Weise and I am the founder / director of Proxemic Media, a new arts administrative consulting and producing company. With the modern dance scene proliferating in downtown Durham, and Third Fridays Durham so far only including arts galleries, studios and buskers throughout the city, we thought now was the perfect time to add a dance series to the vibrant scene. 

Third Friday Durham Dance Series will take place this August through November. Each third Friday will feature two choreographers / companies with repeat performances at 8:30pm and 9:30pm. Performances will be free to the public with the success of a crowdsourcing campaign! 

Funds will help support regional artists, help keep performances free to the public, and will aid in the cost of technical details and marketing efforts. Supporters will also be contributing to the vibrant cultural atmosphere in downtown Durham that the city has become known for in recent years. We hope you will join us! 

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking to raise $3000 in 30 days to help make this dream of a dance series a reality. 

Two-thirds of the funding will go towards paying regional artists. (Two companies per third Friday; four Fridays in the series. Each  Friday will contain different companies.)

One-third of the amount raised will subsidize performances so that they are free to the public, and will also contribute to the cost of technical details and marketing efforts. 

We couldn't do this without you! As a small token of thanks, here are some perks you'll receive with your donation: 

$10 - our undying gratitude & a shout out to the wide world via Facebook

$25 - the above + a handwritten postcard of an artistic image from one of the performances

$50 - the above + a darling Proxemic Media t-shirt... art. get closer to it. 

$150 - the above + a home cooked meal and chats on the state of the arts with Proxemic Media's founder/director Myra Weise 

No matter how much we raise - every penny will go towards making this dance series happen. With Weise's arts administrative experience spanning a decade, this new series is sure to manifest an incredible new outlet for regional choreographers/companies to have their work shown. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Not able to contribute financially but would still love to help out?! We value your presence as an audience member! Please come by one of the third Fridays, August through November, to check out one of the performances (repeat performances each month at 8:30pm and 9:30pm). 

Want to contribute by volunteering? We'll need a few volunteers each month to assist with greeting folks and perhaps even pouring sips of wine or water for audience members. 

You can also help by spreading the word! Thanks to incredible organizations like American Dance Festival, Duke Performances and Durham Independent Dance Artists, the dance scene is proliferating exponentially each year.  Proxemic Media is thrilled to bring dance to the vibrant Third Fridays Durham! Tell your friends and family - it will be another event on the quintessential Durham bucket list!

story:
Nikola and His traveling Lux Concordia

About the Creator

Hi I’m David Geddes (Writer, performer, creator) and I’m impassioned by the performing arts and what it means to be human. I’m a professionally trained Actor and Graduate from:  The Adelaide Collage of Arts (2013) The Michal Chekov Acting Studio in NYC (2016) and the Pochinko Clown Method Canada Manitoulin Island (2016)

My last show HIM (Winner of the Weekly Emerging Artist Fringe Award 2015) was a great success performing 22 shows for its debut at the Adelaide fringe and was afterwards bought and flown to the inaugural gay and lesbian Glitter festival in the Gold coast through the Honey Pot program for its second season. I’m proud to have worked with developer and Mentor Daisy Brown. I’ve also worked on numerous theatre shows, films and developments over the past 7 years in the industry.

This Production “Nikola and His Traveling Lux Concordia” follows a sold-out run at the 2017 Adelaide Fringe. We - myself and ‘Gail Fay’ my director and co-writer, are taking our 2nd season to Edinburgh with an intense redevelopment of the show which has evolved into a feast for the senses filled with more humor, action and sheer absurdity. And we need your help to make it happen!

We are so ardent about this show and its existential exploration because we want to engender a curiosity into what makes us real and how we are all profoundly connected.  Are we ‘just’ human or are we literally 'expressions of the universe'?  These are important and often overlooked ideas in society and our aim is to bring more awareness love and light to audiences…and the human condition in general.

Any contribution will have such a huge impact. Supporting this venture to Edinburgh will not only expand audiences but also provide an essential springboard for further tours and developments to make the impact of this show even more meaningful.

What We Need & What You Get:

We need 5000 Aus Dollar which is equal to about 3000 British Pounds to help cover production and living expenses for the (25 show) season of Nikola and his Traveling Lux Concordia this August in Edinburgh, Scotland.  Expenses include accommodation, living expenses, completion of venue hire, promotion, poster and flyer distribution, insurance, plus any ancillary expenses.

Any profits will go into the project and be used to help fund ongoing tours. And we have a bunch of awesome personalized and heart felt perks to show our undying gratitude! All donations above $5 also get a complementary digital book explaining all the influences from philosophical and scientific meanings to Nikola Tesla and his involvement in classified government projects.

Check them out! ^_^

With your support we can get this show on the road and be potentially curated by another festival as with the previous show HIM. Not only did this help further David’s career but provide an opportunity to make a small living doing what he loves: contributing back to society with fun, love and purpose.

Taking a show to Edinburgh is risky. It’s the largest Fringe Festival in the world and it’s easy to get lost in the crowd. But we have a show that has the ability to stand out with an important and meaningful message for the world.

Your help in covering these basic expenses will be vital into making Edinburgh and future ventures a viable possibility. The intention for this season is to ‘build momentum’ to get an important message ‘out there’.  

The Reason:

What drives David?

So if you’ve made it this far down the page, oh my goodness THANKYOU!

If you are unable to give your financial support, then the best thing you can do is simply share this Indiegogo page! You can use the Indiegogo links or even just copy the hyperlink itself. The simple act of sharing alone can help 10 fold.

Lastly David really wanted to share with everyone why we he is so fervent about this project. 

“When I see or encounter suffering in the world I usually do one of two things: cry or numb myself, sometimes even into catatonia.  The latter is not really a healthy or proactive way to live life and yet… numbing or distracting ourselves is how I think a lot of the world survives on some level. We have to, right? 

For example we may tend to switch off to the news because it doesn't affect us directly and we usually want to get by without feeling bad about the world. We may just ignore the homeless man on the street. There’s nothing ‘wrong’ with these actions, but we've become desensitized to a deep notion that we often forget, that we are profoundly connected to each other, despite what we might otherwise think.

I believe everyone experiences the suffering of the world through the collective unconscious. Just like the protagonist of our show. The more we truly listen to ourselves (with an open heart and honesty- without self-deception or desensitization) the more we are attuned to this collective unease, and naturally… it is uncomfortable, painful even.  To acknowledge this can often create a feeling of helplessness or overwhelm.  To make meaningful impact in the world often seems unrealistic, impossible and ultimately pointless and I know there are many that share this perspective.

Personally when I look at  many of the worlds  issues, particularly the lack of love and compassion, I can see it all steams from a place of fear, fear of the unknown, fear of not having total control, fear often associated with money. This fear comes almost always from a survivalist mentality.

As long as we continue living in a paradigm of “survival” of ‘someone else must lose in order for me to win’, there can never be the coherence we desire in life. People say it can never change but the objective truth in the matter is - anything is possible. But how do we shift from a paradigm of survival to one of actually “Living”?

From a spiritual and philosophical standpoint I challenge people to question ‘why live at all?

Is it really just about survival? What is the meaning of life?  On that note why does life exist at all?

These are questions that underpin the very notion of what it really means to be alive and yet, for the most part, are completely ‘unaddressed’ in how we live our day to day lives, particularly in the materialistic and economic environments we find ourselves in.

Personally I found ‘that meaning’, is something powerful and life affirming when discovered through a spiritual AND scientific exploration. But it’s not an objective answer… it is, instead, subjective (a private one). Only the individual can bring meaning to their life and it’s my fervent passion to get people asking the question - what is Spirituality? Who am I really?

I'm not talking about religious beliefs per se but rather a ‘personal’ probe into the spirituality of science and the science of spirituality which, in short, is what we explore in this show. I want to give credence to the fact that this investigation is vital if we want to transcend such notions like “survival of the fittest”. I do not want to stand by as a victim of this notion, so I’ve created this work as a philosophical rebellion against this paradigm of ‘separateness’. The show aims to engender an awareness of how we are all intimately and profoundly connected.  My aim is to bring more light and love to the human condition.”  - David Geddes

Though this philosophy may appear deep and heavy the show is actually quite light hearted and life affirming and is teeming with existential playfulness and "woo woo".

Thankyou so much for reading this far, and thank you in advance for your support.

With Love and Light, David  Geddes and Gail Fay

story:
Refuge Theatre Project started with a handful of college grads and an idea. In just three years RTP has produced seven musicals, countless cabarets, events and workshops that have reached an audience of over 10,000. 

Refuge Theatre Project's 2017 Production of High Fidelity won Best Set Design, Best Director and best Production of a Musical in the 2017 Chicago non-equity Jeff Awards. 

We did all of this with seed money from our meager college grad saving accounts and ticket sales.

The past three years have shown what a valuable and high quality experience we bring to the Chicago arts community. To continue producing we need your help.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Refuge Theatre Project needs to raise a $20,000 base of funds to be able to continue with our 2017 season and plan 2018.  We rely on transparency with our audience so look below to see the cost breakdown coming up through the end of the year. 

For your donation, we won't leave you empty handed. Refuge will be handing out a wide range of gifts including invitations to actual rehearsals, prime seating at production, free tickets and even an exclusive dinner with the team!

The Impact

Over the past 3 years, Refuge has proven itself as a valued member of the Chicago storefront theatre community. Our mission to bring under-produced and under-appreciated musical theatre to the city of Chicago in traditional and non-traditional venues has been at the forefront of innovation of musical theatre.

As we move forward, Refuge will continue to expand it's production quality, pushing the envelope in what audience members consider to be immersive and engaging productions. Without your help and support, it is impossible to achieve this dream. 

Please consider making a donation and sharing this with friends. Your contributions help a young theatre company keep doing what they love.

story:
Did you know that each year, 1 in 6 people will be victims of a violent crime?

Everyone deserves care and help, whether they can afford it or not



At Broadway Unlocked, we want to #giveback to the organizations who work tirelessly to help survivors of violent crime.


So, from now until Tuesday February 23, 2016, we'll be bringing theatre-lovers around the world together to raise funds an organization that provides free treatment, therapy and services to survivors of violent crime - the Crime Victims Treatment Center of NY, as well as similar organizations around the country, like MOCSA in Kansas City, MO.

 


WHO ARE WE?

 

 

We are theatre geeks. Technology nerds. Actors, musicians, designers, writers, photographers, theatre-goers, lovers of the arts.

 

And we're part of a passionate community that can

make a difference.

 

Did you know that each year, 1 in 6 people will be victims of a violent crime? That's crazy. Just think about your Facebook friends... it's extremely likely that it's affected every single one of us, personally or through those we love. In fact, so many of our friends and family have been impacted by assault, abuse and/or violence, we made a short video about it

 

So we joined up with Google Fiber and Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS to launch the Broadway Unlocked #giveback Campaign & Concert.

 


WHY SHOULD YOU JOIN US?

 

It means a so much to us that you are willing to speak up for survivors, and raise money for the organizations that support them.

 

So we want to do a little something for you!

We're putting on a rockin' Broadway Benefit Concert on Monday February 22 - and we're streaming live, in real time on YouTube - so all of you guys who us raise $25,000 can join us "on Broadway", for free and from the comfort of your own home!

Here's a little peak at what you can expect!

 

 

Check out the awesome talent we have lined up so far - and stay tuned here. We'll keep updating performers as they join up for the concert!


Featuring star of ABC’s Nashville, Kyle Dean Massey,Ali Stroker, star of Glee and Spring Awakening with Bobby Cronin, winners of Britain’s Got Talent, musical theatre boyband Collabro and international Elphaba Dee Rosicioli with Kait Kerrigan & Brian Lowdermilk, star of the feature film Into the Wood Lilla Crawford with writers of the upcoming Broadway show Tuck Everlasting Nathan Tysen & Chris Miller,  Smash songwriter Drew Gasparini and his band Saint Adeline, Taylor Louderman, Krystina Alabado and Spencer Kiely with writer Joey Contreras, a sneak peek at the upcoming Broadway show Nerds with composer Hal Goldberg

and more to be announced.


 


Oh, and here's some of the pics from past year's #giveback concerts

 

 


One Last Note

The #giveback campaign & concert is the only significant source of non-restricted funding for the Crime Victims Treatment Center. So in addition to helping keep one of the most important survivor services programs operating (oh, just that), you're helping to provide money that can be used to do things like:

  • Continue to fund the CVTC Volunteer Rape Crisis and Domestic Violence Emergency Room Advocate Program, that provides immediate assistance to survivors of sexual assault and domestic violence - ensuring they receive compassionate and knowledgeable care and support in the ER

  • Provide integral non-restricted emergency funds to survivors. Past year’s funds helped purchase furniture for a woman and her two toddlers who had escaped a life-threatening partner and found a safe apartment of their own, clothing for rape survivors whose clothing must be kept for evidence, emergency transportation for people fleeing abusive partners, and many other necessary things to which survivors normally have limited or no access

You've helped us raise over $125,000 for organizations like CVTC and MOCSA over the past five years. That's INCREDIBLE!

And this year is going to be our

biggest year yet.

 

Thank you for donating - and be sure to keep your eyes out for updates from the campaign! We'll be putting out a daily vlog on our road to the #giveback concert, and we've got lots of cool mini-funding challenges with awesome rewards - you won't want to miss it!

See you at the #giveback concert!

Jess, Jermaine, Avery, Dustin, Rachel, JW, Nathan, Carl, Chris, Amie, Monique and the rest of the Broadway Unlocked team

Technology nerds. Actors, musicians, designers, writers, photographers, theatre-goers, lovers of the arts. And we're part of a passionate community that canmake a difference. Did you know that each year, 1 in 6 people will be victims of a violent crime? That's crazy. Just think about your Facebook friends... it's extremely likely that it's affected every single one of us, personally or through those we love. In fact, so many of our friends and family have been impacted by assault, abuse and/or violence, we made a short video about it So we joined up with Google Fiber and Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS to launch the Broadway Unlocked #giveback Campaign & Concert.  

WHY SHOULD YOU JOIN US? It means a so much to us that you are willing to speak up for survivors, and raise money for the organizations that support them. So we want to do a little something for you! We're putting on a rockin' Broadway Benefit Concert on Monday February 22 - and we're streaming live, in real time on YouTube - so all of you guys who us raise $25,000 can join us "on Broadway", for free and from the comfort of your own home!Here's a little peak at what you can expect! 

 
Check out the awesome talent we have lined up so far - and stay tuned here. We'll keep updating performers as they join up for the concert!Featuring star of ABC’s Nashville, Kyle Dean Massey,Ali Stroker, star of Glee and Spring Awakening with Bobby Cronin, winners of Britain’s Got Talent, musical theatre boyband Collabro and international Elphaba Dee Rosicioli with Kait Kerrigan & Brian Lowdermilk, star of the feature film Into the Wood Lilla Crawford with writers of the upcoming Broadway show Tuck Everlasting Nathan Tysen & Chris Miller,  Smash songwriter Drew Gasparini and his band Saint Adeline, Taylor Louderman, Krystina Alabado and Spencer Kiely with writer Joey Contreras, a sneak peek at the upcoming Broadway show Nerds with composer Hal Goldberg and more to be announced.   
Oh, and here's some of the pics from past year's #giveback concerts   

One Last NoteThe #giveback campaign & concert is the only significant source of non-restricted funding for the Crime Victims Treatment Center. So in addition to helping keep one of the most important survivor services programs operating (oh, just that), you're helping to provide money that can be used to do things like:Continue to fund the CVTC Volunteer Rape Crisis and Domestic Violence Emergency Room Advocate Program, that provides immediate assistance to survivors of sexual assault and domestic violence - ensuring they receive compassionate and knowledgeable care and support in the ERProvide integral non-restricted emergency funds to survivors. Past year’s funds helped purchase furniture for a woman and her two toddlers who had escaped a life-threatening partner and found a safe apartment of their own, clothing for rape survivors whose clothing must be kept for evidence, emergency transportation for people fleeing abusive partners, and many other necessary things to which survivors normally have limited or no accessYou've helped us raise over $125,000 for organizations like CVTC and MOCSA over the past five years. That's INCREDIBLE!And this year is going to be ourbiggest year yet. Thank you for donating - and be sure to keep your eyes out for updates from the campaign! We'll be putting out a daily vlog on our road to the #giveback concert, and we've got lots of cool mini-funding challenges with awesome rewards - you won't want to miss it!See you at the #giveback concert!Jess, Jermaine, Avery, Dustin, Rachel, JW, Nathan, Carl, Chris, Amie, Monique and the rest of the Broadway Unlocked team

story:
FROM THE PLAYWRIGHT...

Ok, Take 3 of "From Where I Sit".  Standby... and ACTION!!

Hi, I’m Bill Vila. You might not know me, but you will. I want to tell you about a wonderful new play I wrote about the work I do - as a long-haul, over-the-road bus driver. Now before you go "so what?" let me ask you this:

How many TV shows, movies or plays depicting work of policemen, firemen, doctors, even plumbers and prostitutes have you seen? I bet quite a few. 

Can you say the same about a bus driver (and NO, Ralph Kramden does not count)?  Well, that’s where I come in.

Look, I'm pretty sure the only times you think of (or hear about) bus drivers are when “we’re late,” an accident or when someone gets hit, to name a few. I want to shift the tide of negativity (which rains upon us regularly) and bring to your attention how we view our work and dare I say our passion - for driving a bus.  There’s a lot of us worldwide who LOVE driving a bus, but our stories are not being told. I propose to change that by sharing with you some of my antics and to dispel the notion that 

“Lookie here, lookie here, I got the job ‘cause I can steer”

was the motivation for doing this work.

People, if I had the money to do this production the way I’ve envisioned it, this would have been done YEARS ago, but instead of hoping I’ll hit the lottery or book a national network TV commercial, I need YOUR help to make it happen and since life doesn’t exist in a vacuum, it’s time for the driver to ask passengers for help.

I have an EXCEL chart detailing all the financial specifics for the FIRST STEP and will gladly make it available as a PDF to you upon request.

All of our perks will acknowledge your contribution with a profound THANK YOU in our program, ‘cause let's face it: if you don’t “pay the fare,” there’s no bus.  Now, that said, the deeper you contribute, the more you’ll (and we’ll) get out of it.

You like music? We have a theme song we’ll provide (written by the playwright - me) as a CD (or equivalent). We have free tickets to the mounted Showcase (and tickets for Opening Night!), as well as an opportunity to hang at the OPENING NIGHT PARTY, if you so desire.

My producer (EMP Theatricals) is committed to mounting this production ‘cause simply put, she gets me – "it has to be done!" – SO, if we’re unable to reach our time-sensitive goals now, we’ll launch another campaign, and another, and another, UNTIL we reach the FIRST STOP.  A new bus of the type I drive usually weighs around 50,000 pounds standing still and EMPTY.  I’m asking YOU to help push it up a hill – the hill being the inaugural performance of "From Where I Sit." And from where I sit, with your help, we'll keep the wheels turning.

Thank you all in advance for your contributions and for spreading the word!

story:
About the Show:

The final piece of the Kennedy Center Award-winning play series The Suicidal Comedies,  Cracks follows a gifted young biochemist named Nicole who is trying to unboil an egg.  When she meets Kat, a tech developer trying to stop Global Warming, romance sparks between the two women. But first, Nicole must confront the explosive ending of her last relationship, with the help of a giant egg named Humpty Dumpty.

Cracks explores the ways in which mental illness shapes not only our own lives, but the lives of those around us. It is funny, insightful, and immensely powerful, and we can't wait to share it with you.

About the Company:

The team behind the Kennedy Center Award-winning The Suicidal Comedies is thrilled to announce that the final play in the series, Cracks, will make its debut at this year’s FringeNYC.

As a series, The Suicidal Comedies won the Jean Kennedy Smith Playwriting Award from the Kennedy Center.  The first two plays in the series have been produced across the country, but both started at FringeNYC, where Chemistry won FringeNYC’s Excellence in Playwriting Award, and Coping won FringeNYC’s Excellence in Acting Award and was voted a FringeFAVE.

Other FringeNYC shows that members of our team have worked on include Recipe for Success with Chef Michael Denardi, I Was Loved by a Rat, Portrait and a Dream, and Meet Murasaki Shikibu.

 

What We've Done So Far:

  • Applied and been accepted into FringeNYC 2018
  • Assembled an incredibly talented cast
  • Created our rehearsal schedule
  • Designed our beautiful set
  • Created a kick-ass logo
  • Launched our Social Media Campaign

What We Still Need: 

As much as we are trying to keep our production on a limited budget, our actors and production team spend endless time and energy to create meaningful, poignant work. Everyone deserves to be compensated for their time, not just in gratitude and applause (Although we love both)!  And there are lots of other expenses that go into bringing a show to life. Here are some of the costs we need your help to cover:

Stipend for one actor: $300

Stipends for our Producer, Writer, Director, Marketing and Press Director, Lighting Designer, Composer, Set Designer, Costume Designer, Stage Manager, Graphic Designer, and Photographer: $1300

15 dozen hard boiled eggs (come see the show to find out what they’re for!): $100

Rehearsal Space: $800

U-Haul rental to transport our set: $250

Insurance to cover our actors during rehearsal and performance: $100

Press Mailing services, so we can share our story with reviewers, press agents, and industry folks: $150

Costumes, Set, and Flame-Proofing: $950

Digital Advertising: $200

While some of the funding will be raised via ticket sales, we are hoping to raise $8,500 to cover the difference.

REMEMBER, NO DONATION IS TOO SMALL. Even $1 buys us half a dozen eggs!

 

Who We Are:

 

Production Team:

Writer: Jacob Marx Rice

Director: Anna Strasser

Producer: Margaret Gandolfo

Press and Marketing Director: Diana Levy

Stage Manager: Sophia Leewah

Graphic Designer: Alec Strasser

Sound Designer: Randall Benichak

Lighting Designer: Rachel Szymanski

Set/Costume Designer: Susanne Houstle

Videographer: James Monohan

Photographer: Lizi Myers

Cast:

Kat: Wilson Douglas

Nicole: Anya Krawcheck

Allie: McLean Peterson

Humpty: Ben Russell *

*Pending Equity Approval

 

Ways You Can Help:

If you're in New York City... come see the show in October! That is the best support we could ask for. The proceeds we make from the show will go to cover some of the costs not covered by this campaign. 

Not able to come see the show?!

A ticket to see us at FringeNYC is $22. Consider donating the cost of a ticket to the campaign.

If you cannot come see the show or support us financially, but you would still like to help us out - please make some noise for us! Like our page or share our posts on Facebook or Twitter. That makes such a difference for us, and you never know who will end up coming to see us and spreading the word about our show!

Use the links above (you'll see them to the left of the video) to let your family and friends know about Cracks.

When and Where You Can See It:

This year, Fringe is working a little differently! Rather than going directly to the theatre, you’ll meet at the central FringeHUB, located at 685 Washington Street, where a Fringe Ambassador will take you to the venue.

Please note:

There is NO LATE SEATING during performances. Please plan on arriving at least 15 minutes early to make sure you don’t miss the show.. 

Cracks Performance Schedule:

Friday, October 19 at 7pm
Saturday, October 20 at 3pm
Sunday, October 21 at 7:15pm 
Wednesday, October 24 at 5pm
Friday, October 26 at 9pm

Tickets go on sale September 1st at FringeNYC.org

 

General Admissions Tickets: $22

Senior Citizen and Children Under 12: $16

story:
Why Twelfth Night?

It's a great story. But, beyond that, the way that this particular world tempers expansive humor with profound sorrow is unique. The brand of absurdity it affords as the characters engage in their struggle for footing in an ever-changing world can feel incredibly timely. Laughter and tears are near neighbors here.

The intimacy of the Powel House and the ensemble of passionate, capable artists afford a rare chance to invest in the full humanity the play offers. 

Director Dan Hodge has assembled a company of actors ranging from recent college graduates to seasoned Philadelphia favorites, with an eye toward cultivating the promise of the former while challenging the prowess of the latter. This fosters internal mentorship, combining depth and experience with energy and bravery - showcasing artists in a way that invigorates the Powel House audiences, and bringing Twelfth Night to life in a way never before felt in this city.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Every cent raised goes directly to the acting company and the space. With no overhead costs, everything you give has a tangible result in the room – or buys our time in the room itself! 

Regardless of what we raise, the budget is set at a mere $4,500 with over 50% going directly to actor salaries. 

So, what do you get?

Seats of your choice in the intimate Powel House Ballroom, reserved in your name with a postcard signed by the entire cast.

An invitation to one of two exclusive events:

TOBY’S PARTY! – A raucous evening of jokes, laughter and music with the cast, with Toby’s requisite “cakes and ale.”

MALVOLIO’S GARRET – An night of chat and theatre talk with the cast and director. While Malvolio tends toward “daylight and champagne,” you are more likely to find good wine and hearty cheese…

 

The Impact

A Great City deserves Great Art. Not only will this production sparkle with humor and sadness, it serves the greater purpose of challenging artists both new and established to reach for the fullest of their craft. It is an investment in the present project and the future growth of each company member.

Twelfth Night will be free to the public at every performance – we will solicit donations with every dollar being split evenly among the acting company. This radical model removes any obstacle between your personal (and financial) investment in the show, and the welfare of the artists bringing the work to you.

And this is only the beginning. The success of this project promises more productions that emphasize the humanity and intimacy that lay within these great plays. This could be the beginning not only of a stunning ensemble, but a sea change in how we engage with Shakespeare’s works in this city. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends! And not just the kind of friends who cut checks – the kind of folks who like going to dinner and seeing a show. Or the kind of friends who cry at the movies, or even at a good commercial. The kind of friends who bring the whole of themselves anywhere.

And call (or email) the folks at the Powel and tell them how glad you are that they present projects like this. 

If you’re feeling particularly whimsical, you could swing by with a pie or some cold beer on a performance night. It’s not unlikely that your generosity could gain some stage time of its own!

story:
Who We Are:

Blacklist Theatre is a collective of Raleigh based theatre artists Elaina Mittleman, Hannah Johns, Caroline Carter, Sarah Koop, and Katy Koop. Our mission is simple: to elevate marginalized voices by providing a space for underrepresented perspectives and underproduced works. Blacklist seeks to push the boundaries of community members’ understandings of each other, as well as notions of what theatre can be.

What We’re Doing:

For our first project, we will be mounting Elaina Mittleman’s one-woman-show, Suspended, a piece about mental illness and the places it takes us. This is a project close to our hearts at Blacklist Theatre because it is something that affects each one of our members every day.

Why Should You Support This Project?

According to the National Alliance of Mental Illness (NAMI),

“Mood disorders, including major depression, dysthymic disorder, and bipolar disorder, are the third most common cause of hospitalization in the U.S. for both youth and adults aged 18–44.”

In addition, 37% of students with a mental health condition between the ages 14­–21 and older who are served by special education dropout, which is the highest dropout rate of any disability group.

In addition, as you may have seen on the news, more of today’s youth are being diagnosed with anxiety than ever, women are 40% more likely to develop a mental illness than men, and despite online communities like #TalkingAboutIt, there is still a profound lack of support in our culture for promoting mental health.

 

It’s not just a national problem, but a local one as well. Here’s a fact sheet on North Carolina via the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention:

Mounting Suspended for our community is a chance to bring this issue to the forefront. We can shed light on how mental illness can impact marginalized groups and create great art in the process.

Where Your Money is Going:

We're starting this theatre company from scratch, which means we have $0 in the bank. When you support this show, here's what you're paying for:

  • Venue Rental-$2000 for 1 Week
  • Set, Lighting, Sound, and Costumes- $200, to be safe so we have everything we need
  • Emergency Expenses- $100, because you never know what’s going to happen
  • Royalties- $150 for a 3 Day run for the Playwright and Blacklist

For a donation of $1 or more, you are helping us mounting this show and your name will be listed in the program and your name will be read aloud at the pre-show speech every night.  

Just can't donate right now? Shares and RT's are FREE! Please share this fundraiser as much as possible!

story:
Who am I?

"What if I fall? Oh, but my darling, what if you fly?”

                                    -Erin Hanson

I have a voice and something to say. Oddly, this realization came to me only recently. I discovered I want to make a noise! Please  donate and help me cause a commotion! 

I Came To Make Noise is my writing and directorial debut. With your help, I will show my vision to the world. Through dance, beatbox and spoken word, 3 women share their fears, faults and journeys to self-awareness. You can help me bring I Came To Make Noise to the 2018 Hollywood Fringe Festival. 

You’d think the daughter of an artist, who watched her Dad impact the lives of so many with his music, would have instinctively known she had something to say? A dancer, whose first memories are recording music videos on VHS and playing them over and over to learn the moves exactly, not listening to her own body? A choreographer, who has been blessed to help others tell their stories, ignorant of her own story? 

All that changed in 2016 when I was nominated for an NAACP Theatre Award for Best Choreographer for Dreamscape, which depicts the death and inner life of a young woman, “Myeisha Mills.” I realized: I have a voice and people are listening!  It’s a thrilling time in my life. I hope you will be a part of this amazing journey! 

My name is Carrie Mikuls and I am here to make noise! 

This is a story I want to share with others in hopes that it will touch them as it has touched me. The issues of race, politics, and sexual assault are in the forefront of America. I believe by pushing these issues further and continuing the dialogue I Came To Make Noise will make a positive influence on the world. I want to talk about, process and shake-up the issues that affect many others, and me the best way I know how: Through my art.

 

What We Need & What You Get

I will need to raise $6,000.00 to bring this dream to a reality.

Venue and rehearsals: $1,480.00

Media: $1,020.00

Cast and Crew: $2,600.00

Stage Design and Costumes: $400.00

Video: $200.00

Indiegogo Fees: $300.00

The show will go on!

We’ve chosen a flexible funding campaign so that even if we don’t hit our goal of $6,000.00 we can still produce the show. Supporting my journey in the creation of this piece is important and fun. You can donate to different tiers and receive cool bonuses like: a special a thank you on social media pages, a personalized thank you video from the cast, and tickets to the show.

The Impact

When first creating this show I was inspired by this quote from Buddha,

"Teach this triple truth to all: a generous heart, kind speech, and a life of service and compassion are the thing which renew humanity."

This is the way I try to move through the world. With our current political climate and, seemingly, so much negativity surrounding us, I have to find a way to bring positivity into the world. The issues in this piece are hard to talk about, but we have to start making noise and informing each other! I know the audiences will identify with the insecurities, pain, and emotions that are exposed-raw on stage. Focusing less on our differences and more on our similarities; we are human, we are enough.

Risks & Challenges

We received The Hollywood Fringe 2018 Scholarship! Producing this show is worth the risks and challenges.

I am terrified and thrilled to be taking such a HUGE artistic leap and life-changing goal! I am ready to walk this path. With your help the road will be easier. 

I will learn valuable lessons and grow from this experience. In order to succeed I have to take the risks. It reminds me of the quote by Erin Hanson,

"What if I fall? Oh, but my darling, what if you fly?

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute, that's ok! Please make some noise about I Came To Make Noise and tell your friends. Please share our page on Instagram, FB, Twitter, Snapchat, or anywhere else that moves you. And please come see the show in June!

 

Follow my progress @

FB-facebook.com/carrie.mikuls

Instagram-@cmikuls

Twitter-@camdncer
story_txt:
Who am I?
"What if I fall? Oh, but my darling, what if you fly?”
                                    -Erin Hanson
I have a voice and something to say. Oddly, this realization came to me only recently. I discovered I want to make a noise! Please  donate and help me cause a commotion! 
I Came To Make Noise is my writing and directorial debut. With your help, I will show my vision to the world. Through dance, beatbox and spoken word, 3 women share their fears, faults and journeys to self-awareness. You can help me bring I Came To Make Noise to the 2018 Hollywood Fringe Festival. 
You’d think the daughter of an artist, who watched her Dad impact the lives of so many with his music, would have instinctively known she had something to say? A dancer, whose first memories are recording music videos on VHS and playing them over and over to learn the moves exactly, not listening to her own body? A choreographer, who has been blessed to help others tell their stories, ignorant of her own story? 
All that changed in 2016 when I was nominated for an NAACP Theatre Award for Best Choreographer for Dreamscape, which depicts the death and inner life of a young woman, “Myeisha Mills.” I realized: I have a voice and people are listening!  It’s a thrilling time in my life. I hope you will be a part of this amazing journey! 
My name is Carrie Mikuls and I am here to make noise! 
This is a story I want to share with others in hopes that it will touch them as it has touched me. The issues of race, politics, and sexual assault are in the forefront of America. story:
We're square product theatre.

Maybe you already know us, but if you don't, here's some info:

square product theatre was founded in 2006 with an eye toward providing affordable, inclusive, professional theatre to the Boulder/Denver community. We've presented a variety of new, innovative performance work including:

  • 16 World Premieres
  • 11 Regional Premieres 

We've showcased our original work in Denver, Austin, and Chicago, in addition to our home base of Boulder, Colorado.

We love collaborating to create and present new, challenging, and thought-provoking work. We hope you'll check us out.

About Ranch Dressing and Other Coping Mechanisms:

In late 2015, square product presented the world premiere of Ranch Dressing and Other Coping Mechanisms,  a new solo show from Kelsie Huff, beloved and award-winning creator and performer of HUFFS, Brusier: Tales from a Traumatized Tomboy, and This Show Might be Terrible. We believe in the hilarity and beauty of this show, and are thrilled to have the chance to stage it in New York as an Official Selection of the United Solo Theatre Festival.

Here's a show description:

Imaginary sharks lurking in everyday toilets. Violent encounters with Santa Claus. Indulgence in murderous fantasies. Road trip games gone horribly awry. Chicago-based comedian and storyteller Kelsie Huff's hilarious and poignant journey to sobriety reveals an America in which vice is a part of life, legacy is an everyday battle, and the biggest challenge is learning to accept who you are.

Recommended for: adults only (not suitable for children), recovering alcoholics, people with dysfunctional families, anyone traumatized by Steven Spielberg's "Jaws".

Our hope is that our participation in the United Solo Festival will provide us with a platform that will help us continue to showcase our original work at venues across the United States.

What We Need & What You Get

We're shooting for $1,250. Funding will be used to compensate artists and production personnel, as well as to help cover the costs of travel.

If you donate, you'll get some totally rad perks! Like what, you may be wondering. Well: we’ve got high fives, we’ve got personalized mix CDs, and our undying affection. What more could you want? 

The Impact

We're a critically acclaimed, award-winning theatre company. We take our work seriously, but we have a good time, and so does our audience. 

Here's the deal: we believe theatre has the power to make a difference. We aren't traditional. We're risk takers. An investment in square product theatre is an investment in something different. Are you brave enough to take the leap? We believe you are.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone is in a position to help out financially. If you fall into this category, it's cool: we still love you. A lot. We hope you'll take a second to help us spread the word.

  • Forward our email blast to people you think might be interested.
  • Let your friends and family know on Facebook and Twitter
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Come out and see the show! You can get tickets here:  http://unitedsolo.org/us/ranchdressing-2018/ 

Hey: thanks. We won't let you down. We promise.

story:
Did you know there are 15 types of breast cancer? Well, neither did I until 2016, when my world was rocked by a breast cancer diagnosis. Overnight, I went from being a healthy, vegan runner to a cancer patient. The idea for a solo show came from the journals I kept during my treatment and a private online journal I shared with family and friends called Caringbridge.  I also recorded video of certain key moments in my treatment process and posted them on the YouTube channel “Keep Abreast with Heather.” It's a video blog of my breast cancer journey. It's a way for my future children to know me. Here's my original first post https://youtu.be/wecmakxELCE 

When I was diagnosed, I had insane decisions to make, difficult things to choose. I survived and I'm trying to do something positive from a negative. 

I  share my experience in my solo show Chemo Barbie: My Lady Bits’ Journey Through Breast Cancer, which made its world premiere last June as part of the Hollywood Fringe Festival selling out and winning an Encore Producers’ Award. Right after the Hollywood Fringe Festival I performed it as  part of the Portraits of Humanity Festival, then in the Outdoor Voices Festival, and most recently in Solofest, the West Coast's largest solo festival. 

About Heather

I’m classically trained with a BFA from Hofstra University in NY and I work a lot in comedy since my background is in sketch writing, storytelling and improv at UCB and the Groundlings, both American comedy schools.

Chemo Barbie began as a monologue. I performed a couple monologue’s from my experience at WeSpark Cancer Support Center, as well as USC, and other places. Soon, others were asking to hear more of my experience. Working with my director Jessica Lynn Johnson, http://www.jessicalynnjohnson.com/ , I started to experience a catharsis in putting a show together based on my experience and a joy in the knowledge that it could help others. 

The script is crafted from Heather’s hand written journals, Caringbridge account, Youtube Channel: Keep Abreast With Heather, text messages, emails, Storytelling shows, and computer journal.

I’m now one year  removed from treatment and I continue to be cancer free. Not everyone can live to tell about their journey. It’s an honor to do this.

Why Edinburgh?

Going to the Edinburgh Fringe has been my dream since I was a student studying in London. Cancer made me realize my mortality and so I’m trying to accomplish as much as I can while I am able. As I say in my show, “We only have the moments we’re in. The past is done. The future isn’t written yet. Focusing on the moments we’re in is tangible.”  Instead of thinking about the things I want to do, I’m doing them now, because that’s really all we have in life. 

I’m so excited to have signed with Fringe Management Company to take the show to Edinburgh and hopefully beyond! I do still have to come up with payment for things such as flight, room, board, and a deposit for venue plus all the promo stuff. 

What's the Money Going to?

$4,500 includes (marketing, printing, publicity services, poster & flyer distribution)

$500 Fringe Fee (programme)

$650 Tech Operator for 25 performances

$3,300 Venue 

$5,000 Accommodations (I’ll be living there for 6 weeks)

$3,500 Fee for Fringe Management to research and negotiate venues, press, set up interviews.

$1,500 my flight round trip.

If you love me, but cannot contribute financially? Help me spread the word! It's free and only takes a few seconds by sharing on social media or at work or via emails. Please feel free to get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Indiegogo has great share tools so feel free to share away! 

Why this show is so important

I want people to see what a patient goes through. It's told from a cancer patients point of view. For most people we only have a “movie” version of what cancer is like, which is usually bald, vomiting, and death. I am lucky and had none of this. I cold capped so I kept my hair. I took anti nausea pills so no vomiting. I found it early and so my survival rate is 98% with the tailored treatment I had. Without it, I’d pass away. I did have severe depression though, insomnia, chills, night sweats, day sweats, panic attacks, toe nail loss, exhaustion, went into menopause and then back out. The list goes on and on. Things I and most people have no idea are side effects until you or a loved one lives it.

Chemo Barbie takes you into the mind of a cancer patient from diagnosis to treatment. What a patient goes through from doctor meetings, testing, treatments, and peoples reactions around them. It shows the strength and support that develops with some friends and family while others shy away or leave altogether.

People say crazy things to cancer patients like, "chemo doesn't work, I can't get cancer because I have to drive my kids to school, your cancer is causing too much stress in my life and I need to make my life as stress free as possible, living in LA gave you cancer." 

What I'm finding with each performance is that people really feel more connected to a friend or loved one who is going through some form of trauma. It doesn't have to be cancer. This show affects people giving them hope, inspiring them, and creating empathy. I think if more people understood what a patient goes through they’d be more compassionate and understanding. 

This show is funny. It’s a comedy because what we go through is so insane that one has to laugh.

From my press release : 

Chemo Barbie is an inspiring story told with painful honesty, comedic charm and tear-jerking dignity that takes you into the mind of a cancer patient from diagnosis to treatment. Keller shows what a patient goes through from doctor meetings, testing, treatments and people’s reactions around them. It shows the strength and support that develops with some friends and family while others shy away or leave altogether. Crafted from Heather’s hand written journals, videos, texts, emails, storytelling and an online chronicling of her experience, Chemo Barbie is a show spoken and performed from the heart that tells the gritty, funny, heartbreaking and uplifting journey of a young woman conquering cancer while living life as normal as possible.

Reviews

"Openly and boldly sharing in a cathartic series of vignettes, Chemo Barbie takes you on an hour-long journey that will make you laugh, cry and take inventory of all the people and joys in your life, and all without yanking too hard on your heartstrings. In a uniquely funny show about fighting breast cancer...yes,  I said funny... the Reel Housewives of Theatre West actress and marathon runner Keller takes the audience along on a one-hour ride through her two-year journey, treatment, endurance, and recovery. The show is bold, honest, and blunt. The vivacious and effervescent Keller covers everything from her initial diagnosis, a painful-and mostly annoying-drug port insertion, chemo drugs, body changes, fatigue-fighting, acting auditions, a fickle industry (as well as fickle friends), coping with loss and knowing real love. "

-LA Beat  

"If there were an award for the most tender, emotional and inspirational show at Fringe, then Chemo Barbie would win hands down...Heather Keller is a powerful actress with the emotional strength to make her journey relatable to her audience as well as inspire them to live...Believe me when I tell you that seeing Chemo Barbie is a life-changing experience I will cherish forever. This show is a MUST SEE...Don’t miss your opportunity to be inspired."

-Indie Voice Blog

 

"Heather Keller proved to be funny and talented and able to summon up details about her battle with cancer which made her ordeal very real for the audience.  She was able to articulate the shock of dealing with cancer at such a young age (her 20s), while also making it okay for us to laugh and experience the various stages of her “journey.” Very inspiring…”

-Bitter Lemons’ Fringe Binge

 

“Caricaturing her own tantrums, drama, and vanity, (Keller) presents an honest, laugh-out-loud funny account of an actor’s changing relationship with her body…Nothing is sacred in Chemo Barbie as comedy becomes Keller’s vehicle for her anger and frustration, and she makes no apologies for her narcissism in the face of mortality."

-The Lancet Oncology Journal
