story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Tyler West and I am a physical comedian. My one man show ABEYANCE has been accepted so far to the San Diego International Fringe Festival in June and The Minnesota Fringe Festival in August.  
  • What is a Fringe Festival? A Fringe Festival is a usually weekend of performances that highlight any forms of theatre from puppetry, dance, music, visual arts and much much more! It's a way for artists to create material and perform them in front of an audience. It's fast paced, uncensored, and lots and lots of fun!
  • Each Fringe Festival picks out the artists/performers by random, and luckily this year I have been accepted to two! So far, at least. 
  • The San Diego International Fringe Festival and The Minnesota Fringe Festival (happening in Minneapolis) are some of the biggest festivals in the country. 
  • So this campaign is to help support my expenses when traveling.

What I Need

  • You donations will help fund travel expenses, as well as room and board. It's a one man show, so luckily you're just helping get me and my show out there to America!
  • Your donations will also cover each Fringe Festival's expenses like the application fees, registration fees, and publicity; like flyers and posters to help get the show seen. 
  • Your donations will also help pay for food, because I gotta eat some time! 
  • If we don't reach our goal, that's okay! Every bit helps, and is very much appreciated. 

The Impact

  • I have been working on ABEYANCE for over a year now, and I first performed it at the Tucson Fringe Festival. This was a crazy first for me, having never performed or been to a Fringe Festival before. The experience was unforgettable with the new people I met and the shows I saw. After that I was hooked an wanted to share my show with others. 
  • ABEYANCE was the winner of two awards from the Tucson Fringe Festival. The first being "Best Solo Show" and the second was "The Spirit of the Fringe" Award. Both of these are a true honor, because they were voted on by the audiences which made it even better.  
  • I love making people laugh and performing, and ABEYANCE (I hope) makes people happy and forget about the outside world for just an hour. And that's why I want to share it with as many people as I can. 

Risks & Challenges

  • I put this show together all by myself, with the help of a few colleagues. And even though I'm not a professional Fringe Festival artist who has been touring for years, I think I have the passion and drive to get me these places.
  • I have already been accepted and assigned to these festivals. So I geared up and ready to go! Having a community to support this project is amazing, but if I didn't have it I would have gone anyway!
  • Donating money can be scary, but I promise you each and everyone of your dollars will be used to help cover for gas, plane tickets, taxis, hotels, food, registration fees, printing posters, and other resources that help share ABEYANCE to the fringe audiences. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't donate (which is totally okay!) share this link with your friends and family to see if they can help!
story_txt:
Short Summary

My name is Tyler West and I am a physical comedian. My one man show ABEYANCE has been accepted so far to the San Diego International Fringe Festival in June and The Minnesota Fringe Festival in August.  
What is a Fringe Festival? A Fringe Festival is a usually weekend of performances that highlight any forms of theatre from puppetry, dance, music, visual arts and much much more! It's a way for artists to create material and perform them in front of an audience. It's fast paced, uncensored, and lots and lots of fun!
Each Fringe Festival picks out the artists/performers by random, and luckily this year I have been accepted to two! So far, at least. 
The San Diego International Fringe Festival and The Minnesota Fringe Festival (happening in Minneapolis) are some of the biggest festivals in the country. 
So this campaign is to help support my expenses when traveling.


What I Need

You donations will help fund travel expenses, as well as room and board. It's a one man show, so luckily you're just helping get me and my show out there to America!
Your donations will also cover each Fringe Festival's expenses like the application fees, registration fees, and publicity; like flyers and posters to help get the show seen. 
Your donations will also help pay for food, because I gotta eat some time! 
If we don't reach our goal, that's okay! Every bit helps, and is very much appreciated. 


The Impact

I have been working on ABEYANCE for over a year now, and I first performed it at the Tucson Fringe Festival. This was a crazy first for me, having never performed or been to a Fringe Festival before. The experience was unforgettable with the new people I met and the shows I saw. After that I was hooked an wanted to share my show with others. 
ABEYANCE was the winner of two awards from the Tucson Fringe Festival. The first being "Best Solo Show" and the second was "The Spirit of the Fringe" Award. Both of these are a true honor, because they were voted on by the audiences which made it even better.  
I love making people laugh and performing, and ABEYANCE (I hope) makes people happy and forget about the outside world for just an hour. And that's why I want to share it with as many people as I can. 


Risks & Challenges

I put this show together all by myself, with the help of a few colleagues. And even though I'm not a professional Fringe Festival artist who has been touring for years, I think I have the passion and drive to get me these places.
I have already been accepted and assigned to these festivals. So I geared up and ready to go! Having a community to support this project is amazing, but if I didn't have it I would have gone anyway!
Donating money can be scary, but I promise you each and everyone of your dollars will be used to help cover for gas, plane tickets, taxis, hotels, food, registration fees, printing posters, and other resources that help share ABEYANCE to the fringe audiences. 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't donate (which is totally okay!) share this link with your friends and family to see if they can help!

story:
After over a decade and 33 million hits it's time for an upgrade to one of the world's most popular play download website - alexbroun.com

alexbroun.com is where students, teachers, community groups and theatre companies go to download great plays they can read, enjoy and perform quickly and cheaply - all written by me, Alex Broun.

It caters for actors and theatre-makers from 9 to 90 and people love my plays from Western Australia to Wisconsin from Tokyo to Toronto and Dubai to Denmark.

A short play costs just AUD$2.99 and a full length play AUD$4.99 - and that includes royalties for performances!

But technology moves fast and the site has become outdated and sometimes doesn't work properly ... sometimes people don't get the plays they've ordered! )-:

Also it's hard to update so I can't put up all the great news about productions of my plays happening all over the world.

My plays are most popular with a young adult audience and they are used to cutting edge, fun, easy to use and great to look at websites - currently alexbroun.com just ain't cutting it!

It's like a museum when it should be like a fun park!

So we desperately need alex.broun.com V2.

How can you help

I've identified a great new web designer Element 8 in Dubai who can do a super cool redesign of the site for just US$5,000 (around AUD$7000.)

I've be sharing all the stages of the development right here on the campaign so you can a sneak peak of how it's going to look - but for now I can tell you it will be fun to use, great to look at and super easy for you to purchase your chosen scripts.

You can donate as little as $10 to $1000 and there are some great perks like free scripts, a thank you on the website and in social media, a copy of my book on How to write a 10-minute play, one of my highly acclaimed free online playwriting courses and you can even commission me to write a play for you on any subject you like.

My friend Phillip McDonald commissioned me to write a play in my Pozible campaign in 2013. The result was Grace - which has gone on to be one of my most successful ten minute plays.

I also encouraged and guided Phillip to write his own play based on the same idea, The Last Three Blondes, which that went on to reach the finals of Short+Sweet in Sydney - he even beat Grace to reach the finals! So success all around.

The New Site

With your help I can complete a brand new-look website that will attract even more actors, directors and theatre companies to my plays and hopefully you'll see even more of my play on stages across the globe.

Students and small independent theatre groups love my plays as its so easy (and cheap) to access them from my website, and once they've downloaded the plays that also gives them permission to perform the plays for a whole year so they don't have to go through the time-consuming and expensive business of applying for rights to perform the play.

I am delighted to say that i am already one of the world's most performed short playwrights, some people even kindly refer to me as the "Shakespeare of short plays" - and I'm not stopping them!

To date I have had 123 different short plays, produced in over 1750 productions in 48 countries around the world and my plays have been translated into eight languages.

The three most popular countries for my plays are the USA with a huge 815 productions, Australia with 441 productions and India with 99.

I've had my plays produced in 49 US states with only Hawaii and New Hampshire to collect the full set. (Come on Hawaii and New Hampshire - do one of my plays!)

My three most popular plays are 10,000 cigarettes, with 279 productions, The First Fireworks, with 218 and The Kill with 63.

With your help my plays will receive even more productions.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, and I totally understand that, you can still help by please spreading the word about the campaign.

Please get the word out and make some noise about my campaign, you can that very easily by using the indiegogo tools to share the campaign on social media.

story:
Who are we?

We are a group of artists that believe movement can be healing, sustained, and reflected in the present world we engage with.  An interdisciplinary art collective based in Los Angeles, CA, Raze the Whitebox uses methods in Butoh, performance art, vocal and visual arts to facilitate a nonjudgmental space.  These methods transform our internal and external experiences, opening a dialogue with all bodies as we learn to digest our full humanity together.

 

What do we do? 

We hold weekly workshops in dance studios and alternative spaces.  From the work explored in the studio setting we present a bi-monthly performance series highlighting works in progress, finish works, and other outside artist in hopes to support our reach and expansion.  Raze the Whitebox is actively engaged with the local underground, national and international art communities, spanning from local Los Angeles street happenings and national festivals such as The Paseo in Taos, New Mexico to international festivals including Borderland Noise Festival in Tijuana, Mexico.

During our weekly open studio sessions we explore the Ankoku-Butoh method, a Japanese avant-garde form of dance born from the ruins of World War II.  This provides a meditative and holistic base for us to confront the light and dark of life.

Using Butoh as the base, we welcome each individual to share methods to expand our spectrum of exploration.  These methods include Body Weather methods, working with dichotomies, open eye imagining/ meditation, theories of flow, metamorphosis, athletic conditioning (endurance for ecstatic dance), locating and strengthening the connection between the body and voice, sensation work (meditations to awaken body and mind sensitivity), and play (playing with forms {playing within parameters}).

An inclusive aspect of our sessions is the witness/feedback experience.  This gives voice to the expanding vision and landscape by exchanging in active dialogue.

Sessions are open to every body as a way to check in with growth and potential, and the wide capacity a collective can offer.  It leans heavily on the avant-garde but strives to make it approachable and attainable.  Our practice is a remembering of something that came before that is so embedded in ourselves that it is a part of well being.

From our examinations in the studio, we construct collective group performances called Meditative Plays.  Plays as in the verb, not the noun.  Sometimes choreographed, sometimes improvisational: meditative plays serve as a ritualistic opening for what needs to be played out and processed in performance.

The goal is not only to curate a work that affects viewers but also shifts the present and personal experience of the participants.  Concepts span the personal to the political.  These happenings would be presented in theaters, galleries and public spaces, to name a few possibilities.

 

What We Need

Raze the Whitebox Collective is going to Hawaii and Tokyo and we would love for you to help us get there!

It is important to us to honor our lineage and learn from our elders so as to stay true to the spirit of Butoh itself.  So it is of deep interest for Raze the Whitebox to participate in a 7 day workshop with the Harupin-Ha Dance Theater.  This dance theater is born of Koichi and Hiroko Tamano who have been sharing Ankoku-Butoh in the west since the dawn of the Butoh movement originating in Japan.  Hiroko and Koichi Tamano, our sensei, will be facilitating the workshop as well as directing the piece to be performed.  This workshop in Hawaii will culminate in a performance that we will then rehearse and tour in Tokyo, Japan.  We will also take this opportunity to connect with Butoh dancers in Hawaii and Japan and cultivate this growing community, further expanding our practice and cultural awareness. 

Your donated money will support our collective members' travel and lodging expenses during the workshop and rehearsal/performance period of this upcoming Hawaii/Japan trip.

The support from this campaign will be used accordingly: 

  • $5600 for 3 member’s flights to Hawaii and Tokyo and back to Los Angeles 
  • $800 for food expenses 
  • $1000 for lodging expenses in Tokyo, Japan
  • And $100 for any remaining production costs 
  • Totaling in $7500

Your support will also be used to help solidify the collective as a non-profit that will provide a space and community for touring artists interested in working with the Butoh method in Los Angeles.  This is the beginning of our traveling journey as Raze the Whitebox will tour to different communities and cultures to share the open studio and meditative play experiences.  Working towards sharpening our sensitivities to facilitate and collaborate with artists of many mediums and styles, further defining our shared vision.

 

& What You Get​

Supporting us will give you access to our studio sessions,  bi-monthly performance series and digital studio access.  Our digital studio access will provide you an experience of our methods from the comfort of your current landscape, whether its on the westside of LA or your vacation home in France.

For our biggest supporters we will provide intimate and exclusive presentations of our current works in the form of an immersive dinner party or curated event.

We will also include items such as custom drawings, custom wooden crafts, and more perks to be added.

 

The Impact

Our practice is intentionally inclusive of every body, individual and culture, holding the pillars for a truly collaborative space.  Each mover is equally autonomous and engaged in the co-creation of the shared experience.  Methods can be adapted for any environment, body, and voice, being sensitive to community and discovering what resonates with the group.

Much like we approached “Hull’, the meditative play performed at the Soundpedro 2019 , we will make our process transparent and allow the community to experience our studio sessions.  Not only does this allow the community to have an immersive way to understand art, but it blurs the worlds between creator and audience.

Raze the Whitebox will hold bi-monthly performances at our shared living and event space located in West Jefferson Park, a historically impoverished community.  This will enliven the community by housing local and international artists that will join us in creating community based performances and workshops, sharing a variety of artistic disciplines.

As these happenings occur, we will share them digitally on social media and online streaming platforms, inviting people to be involved and engaged with Butoh in their own lives on a global scale.  Easing the transition between the digital and physical experience, we learn to dance together.

In the long term we hope to develop a center for Butoh and other esoteric ways to explore art.  We hope to provide international, national, and local artists a gateway to the community in LA.  A very exciting potential is to provide young adults accessibility to an avant-garde art community, providing venues and research space.

 

Risks & Challenges

The limited time to acquire this support for Hawaii and Japan is definitely a challenge.

Through the use of digital and physical engagement and your promotional support we will use our connections to reach a wider audience, efficiently and directly.  We will offer a variety of performance happenings and opportunities to be involved with our projects.  Over the next few months we will be holding a regular live performance series consisting of solos and group performances as a benefit for future travel plans to Hawaii and Tokyo in May 2020.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We would appreciate it if you could share our mission with your community and promote to people you feel would resonate with us.  Have a space or idea you’d like us to engage with?  Show up to our live shows and participate in the performance series.  Try out our open studio sessions and feel it in all your senses.  Share a creative dinner date with us.  Become a part of the collective!

story:
TERMINUS tells the story of Eller--a poor, white matriarch-- and her mixed-race grandson, Jaybo, who live together down by the railroad tracks in rural Georgia. When Eller's mind begins to fade, her violent past in the segregated South haunts her from the very walls of the old family home. And as she descends terrifyingly closer toward a horrifying truth, Jaybo’s capacity to love his grandmother is put to the test.

In a lyrical style that blends psychological realism with expressionism, TERMINUS is a family drama that allegorically asks how are white Americans haunted by and continually complicit in the sustained trauma against black Americans. This play metaphorically examines how America is built upon trauma perpetuated against black bodies and in particular how the narrative and mythology of whiteness is built consciously and unconsciously on that trauma. The first draft was written in 2012, and right at this very moment, it’s terrifying how prescient this play feels.

TERMINUS received its premiere at The VORTEX in Austin, TX in 2016 and ran to critical acclaim, receiving the Austin Critic’s Table Award for Best Drama and an unprecedented eleven B. Iden Payne Awards including Outstanding Script and Best Drama. Described as “a masterful work of great power and beauty,” (Broadwayworld.com) and “part of an important, groundbreaking cycle of American work that we can only hope will receive the widespread national attention it deserves.” (Austin-American Statesman).

We are confident that Monk Parrots’ production, directed by the inimitable Lucie Tiberghien and starring Obie & Drama Desk Winner Deirdre O’Connell (Scarcity, Fulfillment Center ; TV: The Path, The Affair; Film: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind) will be a rich realization of this shattering and honest story . 

We want you to become part of the story.

We've already raised $15,000 and need your support to help raise the final $10,000.

Your gift will go directly toward the upfront costs of artist and designer fees, rehearsal space rental fees, and hard materials for scenic and costumes.

Monk Parrots is a 501(C)(3) organization, so your gift is tax-deductible and as a bonus, it comes with an array of benefits--show posters, autographed scripts, social media love and for $75 and above access to advance priority tickets. Since TERMINUS is a limited engagement with only 16 performances in NYTW's intimate 65-seat theatre, a ticket will be hard to come by! Get yours today!

And if you can't contribute financially, please help us get the word out about this campaign by sharing it via email and social media!

With immense gratitude,

Jessie Dean & Luke Leonard

Co-Artistic Directors

Monk Parrots

story:
Short Summary

House of Jack is a dance organisation based in Leith, Edinburgh that focuses on street and urban dance, founded by award-winning hip hop dancer, teacher and choreographer, Ashley Jack. 

Since launching two and a half years ago, House of Jack has been gathering momentum, offering dance classes and workshops for both kids and adults, as well as youth company training, events and performances.

Our student numbers have continued to grow and we enjoyed a large amount of attention during 2019, with our young dancers invited to perform at the Festival Theatre (a curtain-raiser for Rosie Kay Dance Company's '10 Soldiers', and at 25 Live), at the Lyceum (as the Sugar Army in Oona Doherty's 'Hard to be Soft' in the Edinburgh International Festival - this week named as The Guardian's number 1 dance show of 2019 in the UK!), and at the Scottish Parliament's 20th Birthday, among many other events, as well as our adult dancers having performed at The List Hot 100 event.  Our second Christmas Show, on 24 November 2019 at the Church Hill Theatre, involved all House of Jack's young people from Primary 1 up to our youth dance companies, and was a sell-out success!  We can't wait for what 2020 brings! 

However, Shapes Studio, where all classes and workshops have been held until now, was unable to renew their lease beyond the end of 2019, leading us to work very hard to secure a new studio for House of Jack, so that we would be able to continue providing training for all our students!  The new studio will be House of Jack's very own studio, located within Ocean Terminal shopping centre and opening in mid-January 2020.  It will have safer, step-free access, lots of free parking, a reception and waiting area, and lots of amenities on-hand in the centre. 

What We Need & What You Get

We're very happy to have been able to secure a new studio for House of Jack, and excited about the future there, however this necessary move inevitably involves a lot of unavoidable costs!  We're looking for funding to help cover the costs of installing a wall to divide the studio and reception areas, soundproofing, mirrors, music system and to lay dance flooring in the studio. 

We would very much welcome any donations you feel able to give (see the 'Huge Thanks' and 'Eternal Gratitude' items on the list!) but we're also offering lots of lovely perks in return for funding, including entry to our launch weekend disco, limited edition t-shirts, hoodies, snapbacks, water bottles, private tuition sessions, and videography sessions!

We've set our funding campaign to flexible funding - we'd love to reach (beyond) the full funding goal set here, but whatever amount we do manage to raise will all go towards as many of the costs as possible.

The Impact

House of Jack is a non-profit organisation, focusing on providing street dance training and events to Edinburgh and Scotland. We aim to be as accessible as possible, such as by keeping class prices low, providing free rehearsal sessions, not asking students to pay for performance costumes, and so on, to give as much benefit as possible to our community. 

Going into 2020, we really hope to be able to provide the best facilities we can, in a well-equipped studio, so that we can continue providing training to all our students of all ages, and working towards our goal of becoming a centre of excellence in urban dance. Funding will make all the difference in getting us off to a good start and having a sustainable future! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to directly help by funding this campaign, we'd appreciate it so much if you could share our funding page with others, to spread the word as much as possible!  :)
story_txt:
Short Summary
House of Jack is a dance organisation based in Leith, Edinburgh that focuses on street and urban dance, founded by award-winning hip hop dancer, teacher and choreographer, Ashley Jack. 
Since launching two and a half years ago, House of Jack has been gathering momentum, offering dance classes and workshops for both kids and adults, as well as youth company training, events and performances.
Our student numbers have continued to grow and we enjoyed a large amount of attention during 2019, with our young dancers invited to perform at the Festival Theatre (a curtain-raiser for Rosie Kay Dance Company's '10 Soldiers', and at 25 Live), at the Lyceum (as the Sugar Army in Oona Doherty's 'Hard to be Soft' in the Edinburgh International Festival - this week named as The Guardian's number 1 dance show of 2019 in the UK!), and at the Scottish Parliament's 20th Birthday, among many other events, as well as our adult dancers having performed at The List Hot 100 event.  Our second Christmas Show, on 24 November 2019 at the Church Hill Theatre, involved all House of Jack's young people from Primary 1 up to our youth dance companies, and was a sell-out success!  We can't wait for what 2020 brings! 
However, Shapes Studio, where all classes and workshops have been held until now, was unable to renew their lease beyond the end of 2019, leading us to work very hard to secure a new studio for House of Jack, so that we would be able to continue providing training for all our students!  The new studio will be House of Jack's very own studio, located within Ocean Terminal shopping centre and opening in mid-January 2020.  It will have safer, step-free access, lots of free parking, a reception and waiting area, and lots of amenities on-hand in the centre. 

What We Need & What You Get
We're very happy to have been able to secure a new studio for House of Jack, and excited about the future there, however this necessary move inevitably involves a lot of unavoidable costs!  We're looking for funding to help cover the costs of installing a wall to divide the studio and reception areas, soundproofing, mirrors, music system and to lay dance flooring in the studio. 
We would very much welcome any donations you feel able to give (see the 'Huge Thanks' and 'Eternal Gratitude' items on the list!) but we're also offering lots of lovely perks in return for funding, including entry to our launch weekend disco, limited edition t-shirts, hoodies, snapbacks, water bottles, private tuition sessions, and videography sessions!
We've set our funding campaign to flexible funding - we'd love to reach (beyond) the full funding goal set here, but whatever amount we do manage to raise will all go towards as many of the costs as possible.

The Impact
House of Jack is a non-profit organisation, focusing on providing street dance training and events to Edinburgh and Scotland. We aim to be as accessible as possible, such as by keeping class prices low, providing free rehearsal sessions, not asking students to pay for performance costumes, and so on, to give as much benefit as possible to our community. 
Going into 2020, we really hope to be able to provide the best facilities we can, in a well-equipped studio, so that we can continue providing training to all our students of all ages, and working towards our goal of becoming a centre of excellence in urban dance. Funding will make all the difference in getting us off to a good start and having a sustainable future! 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you're not able to directly help by funding this campaign, we'd appreciate it so much if you could share our funding page with others, to spread the word as much as possible!  :)

story:
Support House of Lanvin and help us bring exquisite Ballroom to our fans.

OUR STORY

In all competitions, contestants that participate do so knowing that there can only be one winner. The majority of the participants will end up losing and there is a general acceptance of that fact before the competition begins.

 

Over the last several weeks, our friends, family, and fans from around the world have been enjoying watching us on the debut edition of the first televised ballroom competition reality series LEGENDARY on HBO Max!  We were given the chance to be crowned LEGENDARY and compete for a $100,000.00 cash grand prize. One of the biggest cash prizes in ballroom history.

 

To be LEGENDARY in the ballroom scene  means;

  • Consistent wins
  • Countless Memorable Moments
  • Dominating Categories

 

We put our all into every single ball so that we could bring our audience to the edges of their seats to witness pure ballroom and entertainment at its finest.  We carefully thought out our wardrobe, choreography, gave all 5 elements of vogue every episode, and did every split, dip, and turn possible to ensure we did what needed to be done to become the ultimate superior house. We even saw our baby girl Makaylah climb a wall in episode 8 to save our house during a “battle for your life” moment and do multiple backflips in 6-inch heels in episode 6 after jumping out of an egg during this show.  We were the most consistent house and the only house with 4 superior trophy wins.

 

When the finale episode aired and we weren’t  crowned the winners against our competition, so many of our friends, family, and followers felt that we robbed and there hearts were completely broken.  Although we are extremely grateful to have made history by being on the first season of Legendary, many of you have expressed your concerns, frustrations, and pain.  We have gotten countless DMs, emails, phone calls, text messages,  and beyond regarding your feelings of us being robbed and treated unfairly.  We here you.  We see you. We feel your pain, your love, and your support.

 

Although we can not go back and change decisions that were made, you can actively help us continue to deliver our artistry to the world.

 

THIS IS NOT THE END OF THE LEGENDARY LANVINS

 


 

 WAYS TO SUPPORT AND WHAT YOU GET

We decided to organize a fundraiser to allow our friends, family, followers, and LGBTQ + organizations, and any other organizations across the globe the opportunity to donate from their hearts and give whatever contribution they’d like to support our efforts to give you the best quality entertainment possible in ballroom culture on network television.

 

In return for your backing and most importantly, as a way of showing our appreciation, House of Lanvin will be giving special items from our product lines, virtual dance lessons and other wonderful rewards.  When you contribute to our Indiegogo campaign, you will make it possible for us to give back to our community in the best way we know how: by presenting exquisite ballroom entertainment to our fans.

 

Your contributions will also help us give back to our community by:

-Holding free workshops for the LGBTQ+ community
-Launch our fan merchandise line
-Fund categories at Balls
-Host Balls
-Support Ballroom DJs and Commentators
-Cover production cost for the House of Lanvin
-Continue creating virtual content (Concept videos, photo shoots, etc)
-Create more safe spaces for the LGBTQ+ community to express themselves freely by renting studio spaces/venues

 

We are seeking to raise $100,000 to support our mission to enrich our diverse community of fans and supporters from all around the globe and to ensure that an exposure to our unique brand of arts is available to the broadest possible audience. Kindly check the rewards section on the right for more information. If none of the rewards seem to pique your interest personally, they would make excellent gifts for friends and family members.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

 

If you would not be able to help now, or in the future, there are other ways you can assist or contribute. you can share this project in the following ways;

Message It Forward - This is when somebody sends you an important message and you "Message It Forward" by sending that message to everyone in your contact. Tell people to help spread the word about our campaign.

Endorse Us - Share our campaign. Copy & Paste our campaign link above to your: Facebook, Tweet It (Twitter), Pin It (Pinterest), Picture It (Instagram), Blog It(Blogger/WordPress/Tumblr...), or Link It (Linkedin). Social Media is a key marketing technique and will be a vital factor in the fulfillment of these aspirations.

If you have any questions or inquiries, don't hesitate to get in touch!  Thank you for your time reading and participating.

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

 

As of now the only major risk we are likely to face on this campaign is a delay in delivering the physical rewards to backers. Nevertheless, we have contacted a reputable logistics company and they have assured us they will make sure the rewards get to our contributors as soon as possible. I will keep you, my valued contributors, apprised of any and all updates, especially any delays that may incur.

--

With much gratitude and sincere appreciation, 

 

Carlos, Zay, Packrat, Makaylah, and Mother Eyricka Lanvin

IG: https://www.instagram.com/legendary_houseoflanvin/

Twitter: https://twitter.com/legendarylanvin
